entries.title: Extraplanar
entries.content: An Extraplanar creature is any creature that originates and lives in another plane of existence. It cannot be found in the universe unless it came through a portal from another dimension, or it was summoned.

entries.title: Yokai
entries.content: Yokai are a category of Fiends. Consistent, exceptionally evil acts from the most heinous and powerful individuals and organizations can cause the creation of legendary fiends that become forces of nature themselves. These events strip away the identities of those that propagated them and their victims, burning away their souls before their time is up, and leaving them with no desires except for the game itself.

entries.title: Abomination
entries.content: Abominations are terrors born from the unknowable and the otherworldly. They cannot be reasoned with. They are utterly insurmountable nightmares that humanity has no hope of escaping. From the darkest depths of space, the ocean and other mysterious realms, aberrations are often alien creatures uninterested in the conventions of traditional life. Others are strange mixes of the organic and inorganic in unfamiliar animalistic shapes. Abominations are characterized by organized domination, horrific departures from traditional violence, hiveminds, and eerie motives.

entries.title: Beast
entries.content: The Beast group contains a wide variety of mundane animals, ranging from nimble rodents and cunning predators to massive herbivores and resilient scavengers. Whether encountered in dense forests, treacherous mountains, or bustling urban areas, these beasts are simplistic and feral, reminding players of the wilderness's unpredictable nature and the survival instinct that drives all living things. Beasts are mostly unintelligent one-trick ponies, and are quick to flee when their trick fails, or when their opponent proves more dangerous than their value in meat. Herbivorous beasts typically only fight in self-defense, and will flee unnecessary battles.

entries.title: Celestial
entries.content: Celestials are the creatures from higher planes, all which serve a specific purpose towards furthering the order of the universe. They range from Angels, divine messengers of holy gods that aid in the fights against chaos, to Inevitables, single-minded beings that enforce the laws of the universe and root out those that try to break them. Creatures in this group tend to respect and bargain with others in the same group, as they all have similar goals. An Angel may bargain with Death to reincarnate a necessary ally, or consult with an Inevitable to learn of how to stop a reality-warping ritual. All Celestials are Extraplanar.

entries.title: Construct
entries.content: Constructs encompass all constructed beings, ranging from ancient golems animated by arcane forces to intricate automatons powered by sophisticated machinery. Most constructs are created by an intelligent mind, but some are formed from natural primal magic. Their purpose can vary greatly, most serving as simple guards or weapons, while technological or intelligent constructs may be made to write, convey information, and research. Most constructs tend to have a "master" when made, or a method of establishing control over it. Their minds tend to work like programs, working entirely within the scope of their directives, or with a single-minded purpose - however, autonomous, free-thinking constructs are not unheard of.

entries.title: Elemental
entries.content: Elementals often blur the line between a "being" and a hazard or force of nature. They are manifestations of elemental magics, be they nearly-invisible dust devils pushing and pulling their victims, or vaguely humanoid plasma leaving a trail of fire in their wake. As entirely magical creatures, their behavior tends to be unpredictable, and their presence is often unexpected. They may form spontaneously when there is an area of uncontained concentrated mana, such as when a ritual fails, or when a specific element is present in abundance, such as in a volcano. Spontaneous elementals often use their violent magics to spread the presence of their element further from the source, or defend its element from being extinguished. Many elementals will disappear on their own when there is nothing for them to act on.

entries.title: Fey
entries.content: Fey are whimsical nature-bound creatures that live on the border between fantasy and reality. Many appear dreamlike or nightmarish, or like the results of hallucinations, often with nonsensical anatomy and far too many colors. Fey tend to serve mundane, but otherwise natural purposes in the world, such as the spread or cleansing of disease. Some represent concepts or ideas that are otherwise neutral, such as fey of happiness, sadness, marriage, censorship, and flavor. Fey cultures often appear whimsical and mischievous, contrasting sharply with the more straightforward attitudes and behaviors of humanoid cultures.

entries.title: Fiend
entries.content: Fiends are chaos incarnate. They seek to destroy the natural order in any way they can, usually by killing, burning, and corrupting everything that exists until there is nothing but suffering and ruination left. Many come from lower planes, such as devils and demons that form from the recycled souls of deceased mortals. These fiends are made from pure malice, making them almost impossible to trust or convert. There is no humanity left in them, all that remains being used only to trick and outsmart mortals. They often reflect the worst of the humanoid races, as traits that are normally considered sinful become manifest in their abilities. Luckily for the material plane, most extraplanar fiends need assistance or coordination to escape The Abyss from which the come. Despite this never-ending blasphemous source, many of the most powerful Fiends often come from the material plane itself, known as Yokai.

entries.title: Humanoid
entries.content: Humanoids represent the humanoid races, as well as anything sufficiently humanoid to use the same weapons and armor that a human does. They tend towards using tools, techniques, and teamwork to defeat their enemies, rather than natural attacks or abilities.

entries.title: Monster
entries.content: Monsters are a magical and significantly more intelligent step up from otherwise mundane creature types. They are rare mythical creatures, larger than life and saturated with power, ranging from the inescapable Minotaur to the mighty Dragon. They almost always come with incredible magic powers, such as deadly breath weapons, teleportation, and even illusions.

entries.title: Ooze
entries.content: Oozemorphs are amorphous creatures that are biological in nature. Despite their apparent homogeneity, they are equipped with many of the same faculties as other living creatures, such as membranes, means of digestion, and ways to detect and react to stimuli. They are usually mindless, taking on the roles of dangerous traps and hazards to catch and devour unsuspecting victims. Intelligent Oozes are more active, often using their durability and physical properties to overwhelm their victims.

entries.title: Plant
entries.content: Plant creatures are made of plant matter. This group also encompasses Fungi. This group ranges from towering treants to carnivorous vines to networks of mycelium, but typically show off a high degree of symbiosis and adaptation to their environment and local creatures. It is often difficult to tell friend from foe apart in this group, as an unidentified pod could just as easily be a source of food as it could be a lure into a pit of thorny vines.

entries.title: Titan
entries.content: Titans are enormous, long-lived and usually ancient creatures similar to Humanoids. They are almost always intelligent, and often have their own societies and cultures. This is the realm of giants and mythical beasts of incredible proportions.

entries.title: Undead
entries.content: Undead are souls wearing flesh that no longer lives, powered by foul magic that binds spirits into servitude beyond death. Respect for the dead in many cultures comes from experience of what happens when the dead are desecrated, as lynching, mass murders, fires, and other horrific deaths where the death is not properly honored can result in the creation of naturally-occurring undead. Undead created naturally typically have unfinished business, obsessions, or grudges against those that wronged them. They are often lucid of the facts surrounding their demise, and do everything in their power to correct their qualms - after which they must be put to rest. Undead created by outside forces are constantly suffering a cruel fate, forced to live in broken bodies and without a will of their own. Casters that engage in this magic must be wary, as every day that passes runs the risk of letting the latent memories in these spirits manifest into wills of their own with their only desire being to destroy the caster that enslaved them. In the same vein, a caster that respects the wishes of a created undead can use their unfinished desires to their advantage, using alliances over enslavement to form lasting bonds until they are put to rest.

entries.title: Bestiary
entries.content: The Bestiary is a collection of creatures that populate the world, usually as fighting threats. The bestiary is separated into 2 sections: Monster Qualities and the monsters themselves. Monster Qualities are not always exclusive to bestiary creatures, but are much more common on them. Many qualities that appear frequently are not described in bestiary entries and are instead described there in order to save time/space.

entries.title: Monster Quality
entries.content: Monster Qualities are abilities, such as techniques or senses, that are most common on non-player creatures. This is a list of common special abilities and their descriptions, used to save space on bestiary entries. | | | | --- | --- | | | |

entries.title: Achievement
entries.content: Achievements are archetypal tasks that provide some kind of tangible benefit after completion. You do not need to opt into an achievement, instead they can be claimed retroactively after accomplishing a task.

entries.title: Backstabber
entries.content: Achievement ==Requirement== - Murder 3 people you once considered allies, or who at thought you were an ally (before you turned on them). If you murder someone in a position of great power, like a powerful guild leader or king, it counts as 3. ==Reward== - You have a 6th sense for when people trust you. By observing how they react to your presence in a brief interaction (such as an introduction), you can tell whether they trust you, are indifferent towards you or if they distrust you.

entries.title: Battle Scars
entries.content: Achievement ==Requirement== - Get defeated by a critical hit and survive in 3 different encounters. Or get crit 3 times in the same combat and survive. ==Reward== - The scars you get from battle are deeply entrenched in your memory. Your memories of combats you have encountered cannot be magically removed. By touching them, you can perfectly recall past events, as long as they happened in the thick of combat. Other creatures can touch your scars to share in the experience of the memory

entries.title: Critical Pet
entries.content: Achievement ==Requirement== - Use stealth to initiate combat on a creature by patting its head 3 times. This pat can have no mechanical effect such as delivering a spell or attacking. ==Reward== - You unlock the "Pet" skill. It uses your stealth bonus. If you sneak up on a creature and pet their head (again, no additional mechanical effect), you establish dominance, giving you a +2 bonus to skills for the subsequent social or combat encounter. If a creature within reach is smaller than you, you can pet them as a free action 1/turn for no mechanical benefit (no save).

entries.title: Archetype
entries.content: A Class Archetype is a specific branch of thematic abilities that are added to the original class. Unless otherwise stated, nothing is lost or replaced by selecting an Archetype.

entries.title: Character Creation
entries.content: There are several things for you to decide when deciding what you're writing down on your character sheet. Start with a theme, aesthetic, fighting style, or a particular character type you want to mimic from popular media. These are in order of necessity for actually playing the game, but not necessarily in the order that is most convenient to any individual's workflow. | | | | | --- | ------------------ | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | 1 | Class | Classes tend to be very specifically tailored to certain themes, often through the use of archetypes (subclasses).Some classes have choices pre-built in, like what type of techniques you know, a martial artist's fighting style or a necromancer's starting minion. | | 2 | Race | Races come with a variety of benefits. Primary race features help define what role they generally fit, while secondary features are generally more interchangeable. Human is kind of the "default" which is generally good for all characters and isn't very difficult to roleplay. | | 3 | Ability Scores | All ability scores do something on their own, without considering effects from classes. Different classes tend to get different mileage from each choice. | | 4 | Skills | Skills generally determine the type of things that your character does that are less specific. Rogues and ninjas might be known for stealth, but anybody can take the skill. Most skills are tailored towards out of combat interactions, but some, like athletics, stealth, and acrobatics, have a variety of applications. | | 5 | Feats | Feats are customization options that usually give static bonuses, new options in combat, and generally serve to tailor your character towards a specific play style. | | 6 | Background | This section helps inform what your character was up to before they became an adventurer and provides you with unique sets of starting gear. | | 7 | Equipment | Decide what type of weapons, armor, and equipment you want. All characters start off with 1,000g to spend as they wish. | | 8 | Backstory | Think about what your character wants, the kinds of tie-ins they have to your world and the kinds of tragic events that happened that led to them brooding in corners of bars. Writing backstories can be fun, but you shouldn't feel obligated to write a specific number of pages or wordcount like it's some silly school assignment. How much you put into table top is how much you get out of it. The most important part of character design is making sure you, your DM and your players are all interested, or at the very least not annoyed, by your character. | | 9 | Random Charts | Under the random charts section, there is a "character creation" tab that allows you to decide details about your character if you are uncertain about how big or small, old or young you want your character to be. |

entries.title: Class
entries.content: Classes are the fundamental basis from which you obtain abilities. Classes get a set of numerical bonuses to aid them. Every class has listed HP, Skills, Mana, and at least one Save bonus. Stats can be flat front-loaded amounts, per-LV bonuses, or both. Most characters will get their core abilities front-loaded at level 1. All classes get access to some type of Techniques, which can be martial techniques or spells. Technique points granted through class usually have some form of restriction. Even levels are mostly dedicated to class features that directly increase the classes power. This includes gaining access to new combat abilities, increasing the power of old ones, and getting their own special attacks. Odd levels are mostly dedicated to getting the next tier of techniques. As such, class features are usually sparse. If any are included, they are usually minor increases in power or they are flavorful inclusions. You also get a Feat every odd level. Most classes require selecting an Archetype at level 1, which grants more specific thematic abilities.

entries.title: Progression Outside of Class
entries.content: Boons/Banes - Gained at level one as a result of having positive or negative luck. Feats - Gained at level 1, and every odd level after. Technique Points - Gain one that can be used on any school of techniques at level 2, and every even level after. Achievement - Can be gained at any time, even retroactively, when certain conditions are met, varying based on the achievement.

entries.title: Aran
entries.content: Fighter Archetype. Cleave through waves of enemies, eventually gaining the strength to spin through entire armies. Aran is the premier AoE DPS martial. 1 - Smash Swing You can use Great Cleave at-will. This special attack becomes Smash Swing. 1 - Combat Step Elusive If you Defeat an enemy during Smash Swing, you may activate Combat Step as a Swift Action to move an additional 10 feet without spending your movement. You can continue Smash Swing from the new location. At level 2, you can Combat Step an additional time after the first as a Free Action. At level 4, Combat Step is a Free Action. As long as you don't move or take any additional actions after Smash Swing, you can use any other attacks you get from your weapon's AS or Superior Attacks to Defeat an enemy and qualify for Combat Step. 2 - Combo After Defeating an enemy with a melee Attack, you get another Superior Attack that must be used before the end of your turn (doesn't work off-turn). 4 - Body Pressure You can attack all group-type enemies normally and without penalty, and deal double damage to them. In addition, you cannot be flanked. 6 - Combo Drain Healing Striking an enemy with Smash Swing heals 2 hp. Only works in the adrenaline of true combat. Not even sparring triggers this. 8 - Aero Swing If you Smash Swing while in the air, you may spend all of your remaining movement to hover in place until the start of your next turn. You may use this to Fly using your Combat Steps, should you Defeat enemies in the air. 10 - Adrenaline Rush Superior Attacks deal maximum damage against opponents you struck with Smash Swing on the same turn.

entries.title: Dark Knight
entries.content: Fighter Archetype. Stand stalwart in the face of danger, an immovable obstacle that your opponents must fight tooth and nail to merely walk past, let alone survive. Outside of combat your massive skill bonuses can allow you to sense what others don't, and sniff out liars. Based on the Maplestory class of the same name. 1 - Evil Eye Supernatural You can manifest an ominous looking eye that floats around you, enhancing your senses and giving you a palpable aura of menace. You get Proficiency in Intimidation and Insight. You get a 4+½LV bonus to Perception, Insight and Intimidation. You also add this bonus against uses of Intimidation against you. You can choose to make this eye disappear once per turn as a Free Action, but you lose the bonuses to Perception and Intimidation. 1 - No Escape All effects that grant Elusive movement do not function against you while you wield a reach weapon, allowing you to make AoOs against a much larger number of creatures. If a creature tries to move around you safely using Acrobatics while you wield a reach weapon, you add your Evil Eye bonus to your Reflex against them. 1 - Hyper Body Passive. You get a +4 bonus to Fortitude. Your HP increases by 6+4/LV. Standard Action, At-Will. Buff. Touched ally gains an additional 4/LV HP for 10 minutes. This is based on their level. Up to 3+CHA allies can benefit at once. This buff ends when you are Defeated. 2 - Stalwart You take half damage from Fortitude Saves. When you pass a fort save, it deals no damage and has no additional effect. 4 - Polearm Mastery You can make an unlimited number of AoOs, and they have +4 ACC. 6 - Dread Fear Enemies that end their turn in your reach must make Will saves or be Shaken 1. Minions do not get a save. 8 - Dark Impale Supernatural Concentration Action-Attack, At-Will. Attack with a Pierce reach weapon. On hit, you leave a phantom copy of your weapon in the creature. The creature is unable to leave your natural reach and is Anchored. You can still use your weapon, but it is otherwise subject to Concentration rules, and the effect ends if you or the target are moved out of reach. If you impale a second creature, the first is freed. 10 - Placeholder

entries.title: Explorer
entries.content: Explorers are the generalist healers with a handful of utility abilities that assist with travel. They promote treating creatures with mercy whenever possible, and in the most extreme examples, can make death impossible. Their aura is powerful enough that existing near them makes you safer. 1 - Aura of Mercy Supernatural Creatures in your Protective Aura cannot die. This aura has a distinct, personalized visual component that interferes with stealth. 1 - Lucky Break Immediate Action, At-Will. Add LUK to a Roll in your Protective Aura. You cannot add LUK twice to a given Roll. 1 - Compassion Mind-Affecting When you use Channel Energy, enemies in range that were aggressors/not acting in self-defense are Pacified for 5 rounds (Will negates). They get a new save at the end of their turns if you or your allies take aggressive actions versus their allies, and it ends immediately if you or your allies take aggressive actions towards them. If there are no enemies left, initiative ends, and this ability can be extended for up to 10 minutes as long as you try resolving the conflict peacefully. 2 - Cure Supernatural Healing When you use Healing Touch, creatures get a new save against any lingering effects that would normally give additional saves (such as Poisoned and some Mind-Affecting effects). Does not apply to permanent status like Cursed or Drained. 2 - Endure Elements Creatures that touch your Aura of Mercy receive a blessing for 1 hour. This blessing allows them to exist inside of otherwise hazardous environments without harm. Blessed creatures ignore environmental effects like toxic volcanic gas, thin air at extreme heights, extremes in temperature, the vacuum of space or the pressure/lack of air in underwater environments. This does not make you immune to hazardous weather, such as hail, windstorms, lightning, or quicksand; only passive effects that prevent you from existing are blocked. 4 - Mystic Door Supernatural Teleportation One Minute Cast Time, Limited. When you rest in a settlement of at least 100 people, you can mark one of the doorways, portals, or similar entrance in the place you rested as your Mystic Doorstep. As long as you are within 10 miles of the place you slept, you can conjure a Mystic Door that links to the Mystic Doorstep for one minute. It is the same size as the entry you marked. It takes one minute to cast. Any creature can take the portal back simply by walking through it, but it is one-way. Once the Mystic Door disappears, so does your Mystic Doorstep. This effect does not require line of sight. 4 - Focus Dispel Supernatural Standard Action, Recharge. Touch a creature. On an ally, one harmful Spell or Supernatural effect immediately ends, unless it is permanent. On an enemy, this functions as Dispel. For cursed items, this allows the safe removal of the item, but requires a caster level check. 6 - Blessing of Restoration Supernatural Healing You recover from all stacks of Drained every time you rest, regardless of conditions. As a Standard Action, you can touch a creature to transfer a stack of Drained from them to yourself. A creature can only be affected by this once each week. 8 - Elemental Protection Supernatural Gain resistance to a Damage type, except for Magic. Allies in your aura also gain this. You can change what you're resistant to when you Short Rest. 10 - Angel Ray Your Holy Arrow applies Focus Dispel, and has +10 Range.

entries.title: Healer
entries.content: Healers are magicians that combine natural talent, a breadth of experience, and a compassion for life that results in abilities that lift spirits and mend wounds, both literally and metaphorically. A healer's mere presence commands a high degree of respect, as even a single healer behind the scenes can turn the tides of a battle. For this reason, healers are often involuntarily pulled into conflicts that do not concern them, as every government, army, church, and adventuring group seeks out their abilities, and every enemy of said groups seeks to eliminate them. | Basic Statistics | | | ----------------------- | ------------------------------- | | HP | +12/LV | | ACC | +1 | | Skills | 4 | | Saves | +2 Will | | Mana | 2+2/LV | | Other | +4 and Proficiency Medicine | 1 - Techniques You gain full progression in Academy and Vitalism. 1 - Healing Touch Supernatural Healing Action-Attack, At-Will. Touch a creature to restore SP+CL HP. This ability cannot restore creatures above 50% HP, but any excess becomes Temp HP. This can be done through a Staff. 1 - Channel Energy Supernatural Healing Standard Action, Limited. Heal all allies with 60 Ft for 3 SP+CL HP. Add +1 SP every odd level. 1 - Holy Arrow Supernatural Holy Healing As an Action-Attack, conjure a magic bow and make a Ranged Attack with 20ft range. If it hits, the target takes Holy Damage equal to Healing Touch. If this attack passes through allies, apply Healing Touch to them. This can be used through a Staff. This Ranged Attack counts as being made from a Bow Weapon. 1 - Protective Aura Allies gain +1 to Saves while within 10 Ft of you. This bonus increases by 1 at levels 4 and 8. This aura is suppressed when you are Defeated, or activated or deactivated as a Free Action on your turn.

entries.title: Marauder
entries.content: A Marauder focuses on aggressive movement to strike weak targets, surprising back lines and avoiding threats to gain unfair advantages. | Basic Statistics | | | ---------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Other | +2 and Proficiency Acrobatics, +4 Athletics, +2 Stealth | 1 - Ability 1 - Passive 1 - Speed Boost Swift Action, At-Will. Dash. You can run on walls or ceilings with this movement. You fall at the end of your turn if you are not on the ground. 1 - Maim When you hit a Surprised creature, perform an AoO, or succeed at a Combat Maneuver, the target's Speed is reduced by 5, stacking. This lasts until they spend a Standard Action or an ally uses Aid, which removes one stack. If their Speed is reduced to 0, your next hit against them cripples them permanently, inflicting Affliction - Hamstringed. 1 - Stowaway You gain Hide in Plain Sight when holding or using containers as cover. 2 - Sure Footing Your movement isn't slowed by difficult terrain, and you need not make checks to keep your balance in precarious situations, such as when stepping on ice or grease.

entries.title: Monk
entries.content: 1 - Stunning Fist Your first Unarmed Attack against a creature inflicts Stunned (Fortitude negates) for one Round. This occurs once per day per creature.

entries.title: The Boss
entries.content: The beast that thrives in the middle of the fight, taking a beating and striking back twice as hard. | Basic Statistics | | | ----------------------- | ------------------- | | HP | | | ACC | | | Skills | | | Saves | | | Mana | | | Other | +2 Intimidation | 1 - Vital Spirit When below half HP, Gain FH 1. 1 - Haymaker Action-Attack, Recharge. Can only be used below half HP. Gain Temp HP equal to a quarter of your HP until the start of your next turn, and deal the same amount as Magic Damage in a 30ft cone (Reflex halves). You can target one creature in melee range with an Unarmed Attack, which deals its damage and applies a -2 penalty to their save. The cone then originates from them. 2 - Skull Breaker On your turn, when you land Unarmed Attacks against two different creatures, are Grabbing two creatures, or do some combination of Attacks, Combat Maneuvers, or Grabs, you pull them adjacent to each other and attempt to Stun them for one round (Fortitude negates). Once stunned, a given creature is not susceptible to being Stunned again until you Recharge. 2 - Meat Shield Immediate Action, Recharge. When targeted with an attack, redirect the attack to a creature that you are Grabbing. 4 - Flying Pigs Gain Foe Throw as an Innate Technique. You can use it as a Free Action. You can apply Skull Breaker when you hit two targets. 4 - Convincing Fists Gain +4 Intimidation against creatures you have hit with an Unarmed Attack since you last rested. 6 - No Guard Free Action, At-Will. Provoke an AoO. If anyone chooses to take their shot, they automatically hit you, but they also Provoke from you, and you can automatically hit them if you so choose. This can be combined with Haymaker to use it as a Free Action and automatically land the Unarmed Attack. 8 - Bulk Up On any round you do not make an Attack or cast a Spell, you gain Resistance to all damage until the start of your next turn. 10 - Showstopper Action-Attack, Limited. Become Unstoppable as you move up to your speed and snatch a creature, and continue moving up to your speed in a straight line with the creature as you carry them through the air. When you land, the target and adjacent creatures take your Haymaker damage and are Staggered (Fortitude halves and negates).

entries.title: Martial Artist
entries.content: Masters of mind and body that perform incredible feats of talent and willpower with their weaponized bodies through grit, asceticism, or flashy techniques. | Basic Statistics | | | ----------------------- | ----------------------------------- | | HP | +12/LV | | ACC | +2 | | Skills | 4 | | Saves | Fortitude, Reflex, Will | | Mana | 2+2/LV | | Other | +2 Acrobatics | 1 - Techniques You gain 1 Technique point at level 1, then another point every 2 levels after. entries.title: Bandit
entries.content: Rogue Archetype. A professional thief, a blur of shadows around the battlefield taking everything their opponents have and stepping back before they realize what happened. Your very shadow steps out to reach into people's pockets when they aren't looking. 1 - Pickpocket Crits drop coins around the target. When collected, roll Critical Damage to see how many you get; if you collect them, it's worth quadruple. You can collect the coins as a free action, but other creatures must spend an action to collect or otherwise move the money. Before it's looted or moved, the coins are Blood Money. This ability represents taking something away from your opponent with each hit. If you use it while sparring or against allies to "farm" money, they may need that money back to replace the golden tooth they lost, jewelry you pilfered, the kidney you stole etc. DM discretion. 1 - Cunning Action: Steal You can use Cunning Action to Steal. You can use Steal to produce Blood Money once per creature. Your Cunning Actions have +10 reach. 1 - Coin Explosion (Recharge) Action-Attack. Explode ALL of your Blood Money, dealing your Critical Damage for every pile exploded in their tiles and adjacent tiles. The damage stacks, including with overlap (Reflex halves). You are immune to this damage. Even though each explosion is a separate instance of damage, creatures only roll their save once against all of them. 2 - Band of Thieves Companion Summoning You can easily find and hire goons to call upon for aid. These are humanoids with half your HP (including when summoned), and +1 DEX and LUK. They are half your level. They have no other abilities or statistics of their own (no techniques, feats, class features, etc). You may equip them as you please, and Summon them as a Cunning Action as per a Summoning Contract. They take their turn on your turn - the player controls them. They can use Steal and Critical Hits to create Blood Money for you, using your statistics. They have their own limit for Steal. 4 - Grand Larceny When you use the Steal action, you can Steal from everything in reach. 4 - Coin Collection Gain +20% Wealth. 6 - Assaulter Teleportation Action-Attack, At-Will. Teleport to an enemy that is Surprised, up to 30ft, and Attack. 8 - Advanced Dark Sight Steal no longer ends Dark Sight. Natural Crits no longer end Dark Sight. 10 - placeholder

entries.title: Rogue
entries.content: Masters of stealth, infiltration, and execution. The rogue is "that guy" someone knows who's the man for the job. The rogue is the guy who knows people higher up in town as much as those in the underbelly of society. Out-skill and outsmart your foes with the power of planning, tactics, and playing dirty. | Basic Statistics | | | ----------------------- | ------------------------------------ | | HP | +10/LV | | ACC | +1 | | Skills | 8 | | Saves | Dex | | Mana | 2+1/LV | | Other | +2 Stealth+2 Luck Checks | 1 - Techniques You gain full progression in Scoundrel and Warfare. 1 - Ability 1 - Passive 1 - Sneak Attack Surprise Attacks have +20 Crit Chance. In most cases, this means all Surprise attack hits are Critical Hits - you have a 100% critical hit rate with them. ~={blue}1 - Critical Edge Add another d10+LUK to your Critical Damage. ~={blue}1 - Backstep Once on your turn, during or after movement, you can move backwards on the path you took Elusive 10 ft without spending movement. ~={blue}1 - Cunning Action Once per round, gain an additional Standard Action or Swift Action that can't be used to Attack or cast a Spell. This must be a different action than you use with your regular standard or swift action. ~={purple}1 - Dark Sight Immediate Action, Recharge. Gain the ability to use Stealth anywhere and Hide on the same action, as well as cause all Accuracy checks against you to fail. Lasts five turns, or until you Attack, cast a Spell, or otherwise take an offensive action. Creatures that are not using Detect do not get additional checks to spot you. 1 - Haste Buff Standard Action, At-Will. Grant a touched ally +10 Speed and Jump for 10 minutes. Up to 3+CHA allies can benefit at the same time. You gain this benefit passively. ~={blue}2 - Evasion You take half damage from Reflex save effects, and no damage when you pass the save. ~={blue}2 - Rogue Talent You gain a Rogue Talent every even level. ~={blue}4 - Stroke of Luck (1+LUK) times per day, you can force a specific serendipitous event as a free action. Advantageous scenarios could be something like a cart of hay to catch your fall, or a bird smashing into a window to get a guard to investigate. Things with a DC of 15 or lower happens automatically. Anything higher requires a roll. ~={blue}6 - Uncanny Dodge Stealth, Blindness, and Invisibility do not cause attacks to Surprise you. ~={blue}8 - Reliable Talent If you Roll less than 10 on a Skill check, instead roll a 10.

entries.title: Spirit Walker
entries.content: Summoner Archetype. Spirit Walkers are those that specialize in harnessing the power of malevolent fiends from the material plane. They invoke these beings to impose their will upon their enemies and the world to achieve their objectives. While the summoned spirits, fiends, and planar creatures are typically evil, these abilities can be employed for either good or ill. | Basic Statistics | | | ----------------------- | ------------------------------------ | | HP | | | ACC | | | Skills | | | Saves | | | Mana | | | Other | +4 and Proficiency in Invocation | You can use unique rituals to call specific powerful fiends to your side, or to influence your fate. 1 - Adversary Kishin Shōkan Requesting Adversity from a Adversary Kishin is a one minute ritual. When invoking a Kishin, you are choosing to deliberately and unequivocally escalate the difficulty of a particular quest or journey. You must clearly communicate your desires and plan, knowing the Kishin's sole purpose is your suffering and demise. Each wish you make to it grants tougher challenges, and should you overcome these additional challenges, proportionally greater rewards. It functions by manipulating fate, making your journey difficult through united foes, prepared adversaries, and inherent animosity. You can only choose the amount of hardship to inflict upon yourself; the Kishin decides how this hardship manifests. The Kishin grants suffering of any scale, from mild annoyances to lethal curses. The most common method it uses is to cause all of your enemies to converge on you at once. The second most common method is adding an army of undead to the ranks of your enemies, either through simple alliance, or by animating your foes the moment they are defeated. Kishin Characteristics The Kishin is a fierce deity of hardship and calamity. It aims to amplify bloodshed and amplify your torment. On manifestation, it appears as a translucent humanoid with short horns, adorned in elaborate robes, and blindfolded. Its sinister smile, bearing shark-like teeth, is its only distinct feature. Kishin may manifest physically to deliver aid to your foes in person. ==1 - Shikigami (Companion)==[](#id-1-combat-step-elusive-1) You have a spiritual assistant that follows you around and is able to

entries.title: Avatar
entries.content: An Avatar is a creature that is bound to a Summoner, and vice versa. Use the following to determine its statistics. Its statistics are not reduced from being a summoned creature. For ease of play reasons, it is assumed that your Avatar generally does as you wish, and that you are allowed to control all of its actions in combat, though it does still have a will of its own. | Basic Statistics | | | ----------------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------- | | HP | 24+10/LV | | ACC | +2 | | Skills | 4 | | Saves | None | | Mana | 2+1/LV | | Other | +1 AP/LV+4 to Saves against Mind-Affecting Effects | Techniques An Avatar has access to all of the techniques of its Summoner. It gains full progression in Warfare. Language Your Avatar speaks one language of your choosing (that you know), plus any language native to its plane of origin. Form Avatars vary in form, and the form they take determines what innate qualities they have. | Form | Ability Scores | AC | AP | Other | | ------------------- | -------------- | --- | --- | --------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Humanoid | +1 STR | 0 | 2 | MediumCan equip Weapons and Armor, ToolsHas 2 Arms and 2 Legs | | Bipedal Monster | +1 STR +1 DEX | +3 | 5 | MediumHas 2 Arms and 2 Legs | | Quadrupedal Monster | +2 STR | +2 | 3 | Large+10 SpeedHas 4 Legs | The following are modifiers that can be applied to the base form. | Form | Ability Scores | AC | AP | Other | | ---------- | -------------- | --- | --- | ------------------------------------ | | Flying | -1 STR | -4 | -2 | Fly Speed, -4 HP, -2 HP/LV | | Undersized | -1 STR, +1 DEX | 0 | +3 | -1 Size, -4 HP, -2 HP/LV | | Oversized | +1 STR, -1 DEX | 0 | -2 | +1 Size (Max Large), +4 HP, +2 HP/LV |

entries.title: Summoner
entries.content: Summoners are diverse spellcasters that focus on their ability to summon powerful creatures to their aid with greater ease and effect than others. Their signature ability is that of summoning an Avatar, a typically extraplanar being that is bonded to the Summoner, which can be far more powerful and useful than a typical summoned creature. Their bond allows them to share abilities, allowing superior self-contained teamwork. All Summoner abilities are Supernatural. | Basic Statistics | | | ----------------------- | ------------------------------------ | | HP | +10/LV | | ACC | +1 | | Skills | 2 | | Saves | +2 Will | | Mana | 2+2/LV | | Other | +4 and Proficiency in Arcana | 1 - Techniques You gain 2 technique points at level 1, then another 2 points every 2 levels after. These technique points can be used on any path. You gain full progression in Academy. 1 - Planar Avatar Summoning, Companion You gain the service of a specific outsider on your journey. See more in the Avatar section. Standard Action, Recharge. You may summon or dismiss your Avatar without any equipment or staff needed. It is assumed your Summoning Contract is embedded into your and their bodies, such as in the form of a tattoo. There are no limits to how many times you can summon them, or for how long. Should they be Defeated, they gain Summoning Sickness. However, you can choose to self-inflict Drained 2 during a long rest to remove the condition from them prematurely. Your Avatar is usually assumed to be from another plane of existence, such as a demon from the pits of hell. It can summon you to its aid just as you can. While summoned, an Avatar has a leash range of 5000. If it leaves this range, it is dismissed. Unless you arrange with your DM for your Avatar to have its own busy life, it is assumed to always be available to be summoned at a moment's notice. Work with your DM to ensure the way it is incorporated into the game is to your liking. It's okay to have an Avatar that has no responsibilities on its home plane, and is otherwise not an important part of the story. It's a major part of your character, after all. 1 - Summon Ally You can use Summoning Contracts as an Action. You cannot have a regular Summoning effect at the same time as your Avatar. 1 - Life Link Standard Action, At-Will. Transfer up to half of your current HP to your Avatar. The Avatar also gains this ability towards you. 1 - Share Senses Standard Action, At-Will. Experience the world through any of your summoned creature's senses for one round. The Avatar also gains this ability towards you. 1 - Ally Switch Teleportation Immediate Action, Limited. Trade places with an ally within 30. This can be used in response to an attack or ability, causing it to affect the other person as they appear in that location. 10 - Conjure Ally You can Prepare any one Conjuration Companion Technique from Technique trees you have not unlocked. You can only select from Techniques that are normally unlocked through Technique Points.

entries.title: Concealment
entries.content: Concealment is a Circumstance that is gained when a creature's position is being obscured from another's Senses. Usually, this means an effect like fog or darkness is partially or totally hiding a creature from another, resulting in Partial Concealment or Total Concealment, but this may take other forms against creatures that have other senses. Concealment is a condition that's relative to the senses of other creatures. If you have Dark Vision and your opponent doesn't in a situation with Darkness, you have concealment against them, but they don't have concealment to you. Attacking from concealment, even Total Concealment, does not Surprise by default. You still need to use Stealth as normal.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Cover/Concealment.md

entries.title: Cover
entries.content: Cover is an environmental Circumstance that increases your AC and Reflex by 4. Standard Cover is received against Ranged Attacks and AoEs that target you while there are obstacles between you and the source of the attack that obscure a large portion of your space, and that cannot be pierced by the attack. Better forms of cover result in Improved Cover and Total Cover. Examples include peeking around a pillar, over a trench, or behind a low wall.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Cover/Cover.md

entries.title: Improved Cover
entries.content: Improved Cover is an environmental Circumstance that increases your AC and Reflex by 8. Improved Cover is received against Ranged Attacks and AoEs that target you while there are obstacles between you and the source of the attack that obscure almost all of your space, usually intentionally designed to allow attacks only in one direction, and that cannot be pierced by the attack. Examples include arrow slits and murder holes., as well as ranged weapon attacks against Submerged targets.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Cover/Improved Cover.md

entries.title: Partial Concealment
entries.content: Partial Concealment is a Circumstance that grants +4 AC. When you have Partial Concealment, a creature can still see you, but in a limited capacity. Either they can only see your shadow, they're trying to avert your gaze, or there are poor environmental conditions/magic at play.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Cover/Partial Concealment.md

entries.title: Total Concealment
entries.content: Total Concealment is a Circumstance that grants +10 AC. When you have Total Concealment, a creature cannot see you at all. Either they are Blinded, you are completely hidden in an environmental or magical effect, or you are Invisible.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Cover/Total Concealment.md

entries.title: Total Cover
entries.content: Total Cover is an environmental Circumstance that makes you Untargetable. Total Cover is received against Ranged Attacks, AoEs, and Targeted Abilities that target you while there are obstacles between you and the source of the attack that leave no way to reach you, and that cannot be pierced by the attack (in the case of Ranged Attacks and Area Effects.)
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Cover/Total Cover.md

entries.title: Abbreviations
entries.content: AC - Avoidability Capacity AKA Avoidability or Avoid ACC - Accuracy AoE - Area of Effect CC - Debilitating Status AKA Crowd Control DM - Dungeon Master HP - Hit Points LV - Level NPC - Non-Player Character PC - Player Character CHA - Charisma DEX - Dexterity INT - Intelligence LUK - Luck STR - Strength WIS - Wisdom AoO - Attack of Opportunity AS - Attack Speed Crit - Critical Hit DC - Difficulty Class AKA Target Number Dismissible - Dismissible
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Abbreviations.md

entries.title: AC
entries.content: Avoidability Capacity (AC) is the measure of how difficult it is to hit you. Targets must meet or exceed your AC with an Attack to Damage you or succeed at a Combat Maneuver. By default, your starting AC is 10, and you add your LV, DEX, LUK, and Armor, and adjust it based on Circumstance.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/AC.md

entries.title: ACC
entries.content: Accuracy (ACC): What you add to your Attacks to beat a target's AC. By default, you add your LV, DEX, and bonuses from your Class to your accuracy.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/ACC.md

entries.title: AoE
entries.content: Stands for "Area of Effect." It is used as shorthand to describe an attack that affects a wide area, such as an explosion, or a line of fire from a dragon's breath. Area attacks have a point of origin. When the origin is a creature, such as with a breath weapon, determine Cover from one specific point in its occupied space. If the origin is a targeted point in space, such as with an explosion radiating outward, that point should be used to determine cover.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/AoE.md

entries.title: CC
entries.content: A Debilitating Status (CC) is one that impedes your movement or prevents you from taking actions normally.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/CC.md

entries.title: Circumstance
entries.content: Circumstance is any in-game situation, event, or position that conditionally applies a bonus, penalty, or Status to a creature. Circumstances can apply to different creatures in different ways, usually based on positioning or the presence or absence of abilities - for example, having a low wall to grant you Cover will work for any creatures on the other side of the wall, but not on the same side as you. One creature may see you while you're in a cloud, while another cannot. You may be above one creature, but another creature may be above you. Therefore, these effects are circumstantial.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Circumstance.md

entries.title: DC
entries.content: Difficulty Class (DC) is the target number that a Roll must reach to be considered a success.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/DC.md

entries.title: DM
entries.content: Dungeon Master (DM): The person running the game. This person is the arbiter of the rules, tasked with creating the world, playing all NPCs, and ensuring a fun and fair experience for the players.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/DM.md

entries.title: DR
entries.content: Damage Reduction (DR) is a rare form of defense that reduces incoming damage by a flat amount, noted as a value (DR x). If not specified, DR applies to physical damage, and DRA applies to all Damage types. All DR stacks. Stacking defenses works in the way that protects the most - such as applying DR after Resistance. If an effect's damage is reduced to 0 with DR, then any associated non-damaging effects are negated.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/DR.md

entries.title: FH
entries.content: Fast Healing restores a listed amount of HP at the start of the creature's turn. Fast Healing can heal a Defeated creature, but it does not remove the Defeated condition.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/FH.md

entries.title: Flanking
entries.content: Flanking is a Circumstance that grants +2 ACC against a target that you and an ally are Threatening from opposite sides.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Flanking.md

entries.title: Initiative
entries.content: As a Turn-Based Game, Initiative decides who goes first. Initiative is d10+Reflex. Some bonuses apply specifically to Initiative. Whoever rolls higher goes first. Ties are broken first by the higher bonus, then PCs take priority. In the event where there are two parties that don't immediately fight, initiative starts when someone takes an aggressive action, such as casting a spell or drawing an arrow. In these cases, where both parties are aware of each other, initiative gets rolled immediately before any actions happen, but the individual that took the aggressive action gains a +10 bonus to their Initiative. This means being the first to say "I attack!" usually means going first. Certain types of underhanded tactics can affect who goes first, such as using Hands to draw a concealed weapon or Deception for a sucker punch. Anyone that is not aware of combat is placed below anyone that was aware when initiative was rolled, regardless of their initiative result. This usually happens as a result of Stealth or an attack against sleeping opponents.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Initiative.md

entries.title: Lv
entries.content: Level (LV): the level assigned to a creature or effect is used to represent their relative strength in the setting. Level is added to all Rolls (Attacks, Saving Throws, Skills, etc.)
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Lv.md

entries.title: Minion
entries.content: Minion is a Circumstantial label assigned to a creature as it relates to another. A creature that is 1/3 of the level of another or lower is a Minion compared to it. A level 0 creature is always considered a Minion to any creature of a higher level.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Minion.md

entries.title: Natural
entries.content: A Natural result on a Roll is the result without any bonuses or penalties.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Natural.md

entries.title: NPC
entries.content: Non-Player Character (NPC): Any character that is played by the DM. These characters usually get placed after PCs to favor the players.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/NPC.md

entries.title: PC
entries.content: Player Character (PC): A character controlled by a player, and not the DM. Players are the main characters of a story, and thus gain port priority in some aspects. Sometimes, a DM will play a special character alongside the players that is treated like a PC. This is normal, but the players can veto such a character's PC status if they feel it is inappropriate.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/PC.md

entries.title: Potency
entries.content: Potency is the default DC of abilities used by a creature. This is usually 10+LV+LUK.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Potency.md

entries.title: Roll
entries.content: The default die roll for resolving things. This is used to determine the variance expected. In Malon's Marvelous Misadventures, this is a 15-sided die, rolled until a result of a Natural 1 shows up. The amount of rolls (including the one that results in the natural 1) is totaled as the result. For example, if it took 12 rolls, then the result of this "roll" is 12.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Roll.md

entries.title: SP
entries.content: Spell Power Many Spell and similar abilities have their variable effects based on Spell Power. Spell Power is decided by your Staff of choice (usually d6) plus your INT. Spells often include Spell Power in their total damage. When they do, they may also add Spell Power when Upcast.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/SP.md

entries.title: Supernatural
entries.content: Supernatural abilities encompass any ability that is magical, but not a Spell.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Supernatural.md

entries.title: Threaten
entries.content: The area a creature threatens represents where they can make attacks. This usually only applies to melee attacks. This area also marks where it is typically not safe to perform certain actions, or risk getting hit with an AoO.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/Threaten.md

entries.title: XP
entries.content: Experience is a meta-currency gained through prioritizing primary campaign events that allows players to influence the story/chronological order of things in order to accomplish personal goals quickly and get back into the action faster. As a baseline, 10 XP is the equivalent of one in-game day of events. Experience is rewarded for spending time working towards campaign goals in an active manner. This mainly means exploring dungeons, splitting heads, and overthrowing governments - anything that is both related to the main campaign objectives, and is not part of downtime events (such as recovering from an Affliction or Crafting). XP is rewarded based on the time required to complete the mission, with additional bonuses for overcoming particular challenges. The purpose of XP is to reward taking action. While downtime is an important part of roleplay, it's easy to justify staying in town making safe money or doing side quests to save up for a shiny new weapon or achieve personal goals if there isn't an obvious time constraint on important story events. It's easy to hold off on an important event and try to squeeze a few more days of crafting into your schedule. Instead, XP serves to reward taking action immediately, without penalizing downtime events like crafting.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Abbreviations and Terminology/XP.md

entries.title: Ability Scores
entries.content: These are representations of a creature's innate or cultivated affinities. These represent the mind, body, and spirit. The ability scores are Strength, Dexterity, Luck, Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma. Every Player Character gets 3 points to increase their ability scores as they wish, starting from 0 in each. You can decrease a single ability score to -1 in order to gain an additional point. The maximum points you can invest in a given ability score is 2.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Ability Scores/Ability Scores.md

entries.title: Carry Weight
entries.content: A creature's Carry Weight represents what it is capable of lifting and moving around with without much effort. The default value is 100, but some factors may change this. A creature can lift and drag twice as much as their carry weight, but is staggered while doing so. | Bonuses to Carry Weight | | | ------------------------ | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Strength | +50% for each point, additive (or half for a negative point) | | Size | Quadruple Carry Weight (and weight) for each size above medium. (or 1/2 Carry Weight and 1/4 weight for each size below medium) |
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Ability Scores/Carry Weight.md

entries.title: CHA
entries.content: Charisma (CHA): Your leadership and personal magnetism. >Positive charisma enhances your Companion creatures. You can grant Companion creatures one of your Feats per CHA. >For every point of CHA, you gain another Companion slot. >You cannot control Companion creatures with negative CHA.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Ability Scores/CHA.md

entries.title: DEX
entries.content: Dexterity (DEX): Your agility, hand-eye coordination, and general sneakiness. >You add DEX to your Reflex Save. >You add your DEX to your ACC and AC. >You add DEX to Initiative. >Every point of DEX adds +5 to your Speed and Jump. >Negative DEX subtracts from these values.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Ability Scores/DEX.md

entries.title: INT
entries.content: Intelligence (INT): Your knowledge, magical expertise, and logic capacity. >You add INT to SP >You gain an additional Technique Point. >You gain an additional Skill Proficiency per point of INT >You gain two additional Languages per point of INT (listed in the Skills section under Linguistics) >Negative INT subtracts from Spell Power You lose a Skill Proficiency per negative INT
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Ability Scores/INT.md

entries.title: Luck Check
entries.content: When the chance something will happen or fail to happen is based purely on chance, you attempt a Luck Check. You just roll a d10, add (or subtract) LUK and compare the result on the die to the DC.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Ability Scores/Luck Check.md

entries.title: LUK
entries.content: Luck (LUK): Your ability to turn tides and benefit from unlikely outcomes. >You add LUK to Avoid. >You add LUK to Potency. >You add LUK to Luck Checks. >You add LUK to Critical Damage. >You can add LUK to a Roll as an Immediate Action (that did not already add LUK). >Negative LUK subtracts from Avoid, Potency, Luck Checks, and Critical Damage.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Ability Scores/LUK.md

entries.title: STR
entries.content: Strength (STR): Your fortitude, athleticism, and endurance. >You add STR to your Fortitude Save. >You add STR to physical attack Damage, such as with weapons and unarmed attacks. >When you wield a weapon in two hands, you add twice your STR to damage. >You add STR to ACC when using a Combat Maneuver. >Every point of STR increases your Carry Weight by 50%. >Negative STR subtracts from your Fortitude Saves. >Negative STR halves your Carry Weight.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Ability Scores/STR.md

entries.title: WIS
entries.content: Wisdom (WIS): Your faith, decision making, habits, diligence, and discipline. >You add WIS to your Will Save. >You add WIS to your Mana. >You gain 50% more XP per point of WIS. >You gain a Feat per Wisdom. >Negative WIS subtracts from your Will Save, Feats, and reduces your XP gain to 50%.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Ability Scores/WIS.md

entries.title: Burrow
entries.content: Burrow Speeds allow Movement through dirt, clay, and other particulate turf, but not solid rocks (unless otherwise stated). Burrowing leaves a temporary hole the size of the creature that burrowed for a few rounds, depending on the sediment type, unless the creature takes measures to avoid this. Starting to burrow is a Swift Action that Provokes as if leaving a Threatened space.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Movement/Burrow.md

entries.title: Difficult Terrain
entries.content: Difficult Terrain is a Circumstance that represents reduced movement due to physical blockage. This can be because of wading through knee-deep mud, flying through dense brush, or burrowing through particularly rocky turf.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Movement/Difficult Terrain.md

entries.title: Fly
entries.content: Fly Speeds allow Movement in any direction. They may remain in the air as long as they have a Fly Speed - Flying targets get +4 AC against Ranged Attacks while flying. A creature that is Entangled or Grounded cannot continue flight. A creature that takes damage from an Attack or AoE effect while flying receives Clumsy 1 until they land, up to 6 stacks. Starting to fly is a Swift Action that Provokes as if leaving a Threatened space.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Movement/Fly.md

entries.title: Hover
entries.content: Hover Speeds allow Movement above solid and liquid surfaces while ignoring Difficult Terrain. They may remain in the air as long as they have a Fly Speed - Flying targets get +4 AC against Ranged Attacks while flying. A creature that is Entangled or Grounded cannot continue flight. A creature that takes damage from an Attack or AoE effect while flying receives Clumsy 1 until they land, up to 6 stacks.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Movement/Hover.md

entries.title: Movement
entries.content: You can move up to your Speed on your turn. Some abilities or effects may require spending a certain amount of your movement for the turn. Abilities that move you do not cost or consume any of your movement unless otherwise stated.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Movement/Movement.md

entries.title: Speed
entries.content: Default ground movement speed is 30. Race, Class, Equipment, and Status can change this. Some actions grant extra speed. You may have other forms of movement that manifest in terms of different Speeds - you may use multiple forms of movement on the same turn, but only up to the maximum amount for the given speed. Any slower speeds used overlap - That is, if you have a Fly 40 and a ground speed of 30, you may walk 30 feet and then fly another 10.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Movement/Speed.md

entries.title: Action System
entries.content: This game is played turn-based, with turn order determined at the start of the battle with an Initiative roll. The actions you can take on your turn are as follows. - Standard Action: This action occupies most of your turn, and you can perform one per turn. - Example: The Attack Action is the most common, allowing a series of smaller attacks up to your Attack Speed, executed in any order. Refer to the "Attack" section for more details. - Swift Action: This action can be executed during any other action, with a limit of one per turn. - Free Action: These actions are effortless or part of other actions, allowing you to perform as many as you wish per turn - within reason. - Full-Round Action: This action requires the use of your standard action and all of your free Movement. You may still move if you have an ability that allows extra movement as a different action. When it's not your turn, you can take the following actions: - Immediate Action: A Swift Action that can occur off-turn. Limited to one per round, shared with Swift Action — you cannot use both in the same round. - Instant Action: A Free Action that can occur off-turn. Referred to as "Instantly" in abilities. - Attack of Opportunity: A response triggered by certain actions of others. Limited to one per round. When a creature "Provokes," they are engaging in an action that allows others to AoO them. - Movement: You can move up to your Speed on your turn. Some abilities or effects may require spending a certain amount of your movement for the turn. You may have other forms of movement that manifest in terms of different Speeds - you may use multiple forms of movement on the same turn, but only up to the maximum amount for the given speed. Any slower speeds used overlap - That is, if you have a Fly 40 and a ground speed of 30, you may walk 30 feet and then fly another 10.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Action System.md

entries.title: AoO
entries.content: Attack of Opportunity (AoO): An Instant Action Attack triggered in response to certain actions of others. All creatures can do this once per round by default. When a creature "Provokes," they are engaging in an action that allows others to AoO them. Movement can only provoke once from a given creature per turn.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/AoO.md

entries.title: Free Action
entries.content: - Free Action: These actions are effortless or part of other actions, allowing you to perform as many as you wish per turn - within reason. See: Delay Swap Item Monster Lore
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Free Action.md

entries.title: Full-Round Action
entries.content: - Full-Round Action: This action requires the use of your standard action and all of your free movement. You may still move if you have an ability that allows extra movement as a different action.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Full-Round Action.md

entries.title: Immediate Action
entries.content: - Immediate Action: A Swift Action that can occur off-turn. Limited to one per round, shared with Swift Action — you cannot use both in the same round.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Immediate Action.md

entries.title: Instant Action
entries.content: Instant Action: A Free Action that can occur off-turn. Referred to as "Instantly" in abilities.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Instant Action.md

entries.title: Standard Action
entries.content: - Standard Action: This action occupies most of your turn, and you can perform one per turn. - Example: The Attack Action is the most common, allowing a series of smaller attacks up to your Attack Speed, executed in any order. Refer to the "Attack" section for more details. See: Administer Potion Aid Attack Action Carry Charge Dash Disengage Prepare Total Defense
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Standard Action.md

entries.title: Swift Action
entries.content: - Swift Action: This action can be executed during any other action, with a limit of one per turn. See: Hide Jump Use Potion Recharge Abilities
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Action System/Swift Action.md

entries.title: Delay
entries.content: You can wait for a later spot in Initiative. If you're already at the bottom, you can wait until a later round. When you decide to re-enter Initiative, your Initiative changes to the spot you enter.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Free Actions/Delay.md

entries.title: Swap Item
entries.content: At the start of your turn, you can decide what's in your hands from your inventory. You can draw and put away any weapons without penalty. This is a Free Action as long as it's done at the start of your turn. If you decide to change what you're wielding at another point in your turn, it becomes a Swift Action - and you can't do both.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Free Actions/Swap Item.md

entries.title: Fall Prone
entries.content: You can willingly inflict Knocked Down on yourself as an Instant Action.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Instant Actions/Fall Prone.md

entries.title: Administer Potion
entries.content: Give a potion to an unconscious ally as a Standard Action. You can use potions from either of your inventories. A conscious ally must spend an Immediate Action to drink an administered potion.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Standard Actions/Administer Potion.md

entries.title: Aid
entries.content: Provide one of the following bonuses to an ally within your reach for 1 round as a Standard Action: +2 to ACC against foes you both threaten +2 to Saves +2 to AC Alternatively, remove one stack of the following conditions: Clumsy, Shaken, Sickened, or Knocked Down. Note: Many Entangled effects can be removed using Athletics. Use the Aid action to assist an ally in overcoming these conditions.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Standard Actions/Aid.md

entries.title: Attack Action
entries.content: When you take the Attack Action as a Standard Action, you dedicate your turn to all-out offense. This allows you to make a number of attacks up to your highest Attack Speed, in any non-conflicting combination. Attack Speed is a product of which weapon you have on hand, but not all attacks must be with a weapon. Action-Attacks are a special type of Standard Action, which by default can also be used as an Attack with an Attack Speed of 1. Most combat Spells, Combat Maneuvers, and Techniques are Action-Attacks.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Standard Actions/Attack Action.md

entries.title: Carry
entries.content: Carrying an ally allows you to move them with your movement. You must be able to lift the ally, or drag them treating all terrain as difficult terrain. You must use this action every turn you carry an ally. The creature you carry becomes clumsy 2 unless they are defeated or you aren't in combat.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Standard Actions/Carry.md

entries.title: Charge
entries.content: Move up to your speed in a straight line, and then make an attack.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Standard Actions/Charge.md

entries.title: Dash
entries.content: Double your speed this round.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Standard Actions/Dash.md

entries.title: Disengage
entries.content: Your movement is Elusive this turn.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Standard Actions/Disengage.md

entries.title: Prepare
entries.content: You can prepare swift actions, movement, free actions and standard actions to react to a specific triggering event (Ex: “a goblin opens this door, I walk up to him and shove him off the cliff”). If the triggering action never happens, you don't get your actions back. When you prepare a standard action to attack, you can only prepare a single attack. You cannot prepare actions outside of Initiative.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Standard Actions/Prepare.md

entries.title: Total Defense
entries.content: Get +4 to AC and Saves until the start of your next turn. Remove all Clumsy stacks. You can't make an AoO while using Total Defense.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Standard Actions/Total Defense.md

entries.title: Jump
entries.content: Jump in a straight line. This can only be used in combination with other forms of movement such as walking or charging. Jump is also a statistic. By default, your Jump is 5. This is a measure of distance, specifically for horizontal jumps, while vertical jumps are half. This does not give you additional movement, and the thus it is limited by your Speed, unless your Jump is higher than your Speed (in which case it functions as your total movement limit when jumping). It can be used to avoid Difficult Terrain, but not if you're already in the Difficult Terrain. You can only jump once with this action. If you Dash, you can jump twice. These jumps do not need to be consecutive. Jump distance increases by 5 ft per point of DEX (and STR with Athletics).
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Swift Actions/Jump.md

entries.title: Recharge Abilities
entries.content: Regain all uses of your Recharge abilities. When you use this action, you cannot use it again for one minute.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Swift Actions/Recharge Abilities.md

entries.title: Use Potion
entries.content: Retrieve and drink a potion.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Actions/Common Actions/Swift Actions/Use Potion.md

entries.title: Alternative Win Conditions
entries.content: For when killing everything that moves isn't what you want, alternative win conditions seek to answer the question of "How do I end combat without reducing the enemy hp to 0?" See: Restraint Surrender and Morale Truce
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Alternative Win Conditions/Alternative Win Conditions.md

entries.title: Restraint
entries.content: When creatures don't surrender, but you don’t want to risk killing them, restraints can be used to end the fight. Some situations can naturally be neutralized by dropping a cage in the right place, but such conveniences are rare. More often than not, restraining your foe is going to involves rope and cuffs. #Cuffs Grabbing and already-grabbed creature allows you to put cuffs on them. One grab is needed per appendage cuffed. You cannot cuff a creature on your own unless you can grab multiple times per turn, in which case you need another free hand. This provokes AoO. This completely prevents the use of their arms outside of simple item interactions. Cuffs can also be placed on the legs to reduce a creatures speed to 15. Combat maneuvers made against a cuffed creature gain a +10 bonus. Cuffs are difficult to escape, and even harder to break. They typically require outside assistance in order to be removed. Because cuffs are typically made from iron and steel, they can take a significant beating. DC to break (Athletics) or lockpick (Hands) is dependent on the type of material and the lock. A typical forged cuff is DC 40 to break, or 20 to pick. Creatures that are bound can try to free themselves, but take a -5 penalty. #Rope Grabbing and already-grabbed creature allows you to tie them with rope. One grab is needed per appendage tied. You cannot tie up a creature on your own unless you can grab multiple times per turn, in which case you need another free hand. This provokes AoO. Rope is easier to destroy than cuffs, but it is also easier to make the restraint more intense. By grabbing one more time, you can prevent the creature from acting completely. Rope tends to be a good way to bind singular creatures, since anybody with a sharp implement can handily free a bound creature. Rope can be destroyed with an attack from any slashing weapon. Using Athletics or Acrobatics, you can pull the ropes apart, but the DC is determined by the athletics bonus of the creature who bound you (30+their athletics bonus). Creatures that are bound can try to free themselves, but take a -5 penalty. This penalty can be ignored with a natural attack suitable for freeing yourself, or a slashing concealed weapon. #Container Grabbing and already-grabbed creature allows you to forcefully shove them into an object within reach such as a bag, barrel, or box, so long as they can handily fit in the object. Whether or not they can escape generally depends on the object and the tools the captured creature has on hand. Wooden crates don’t do to well when trying to hold barbarians or crafty characters with crowbars. DC to break (Athletics) is dependent on the type of material. Some objects can be handily dealt with, not requiring a skill check. A knife makes quick work of a bag, and given enough space, hammers break boxes. Creatures that are bound can try to free themselves, but take a -5 penalty.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Alternative Win Conditions/Restraint.md

entries.title: Surrender and Morale
entries.content: During combat there come times when you do not wish to fight, usually when one side is close to victory, but can also happen when creatures are clearly outnumbered or outmatched. How well a surrender feels in a situation usually comes down to a gut feeling, affected by a lot of variables. In order to even consider a surrender to be viable, one or more of the following (or other applicable) conditions should be met… >Numbers advantage >Some other clear advantage, such as terrain, positioning, equipment or a powerful noteworthy ally >Heavily damaged or unconscious allies >Consequences for not surrendering (often death or further prosecution) >Hostages >Whether or not creatures are minions or named characters A surrender requires clear communication, which may not always be possible given the hectic and spread out nature of battle. Some creatures, particularly mindless ones, will not surrender unless specific circumstances are met. Creatures of animal intelligence can be convinced to surrender if you can speak to animals or have wild empathy etc. Surrender can mean forfeiting weapons, fleeing in fear, begging for mercy or something similar. If not all individuals accept the surrender, then the fight continues until they do.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Alternative Win Conditions/Surrender and Morale.md

entries.title: Truce
entries.content: In situations where there are two opposing sides that are generally neutral towards each other or even allies with each other, you can call for a truce. This generally requires important information (we were sent by the merchants guild), certification from an important or recognizable organization (legal documentation) or a special item (an artifact or flag). It could also be appropriate to call for a truce if you are delving into a dungeon and encounter another party, so long as you aren't after the same thing. You might not cooperate, but at least you won't be killing each other. If more information is revealed by talking throughout a battle (wait you're also hunting for the garbooni?), you can also reasonably call for a truce.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Alternative Win Conditions/Truce.md

entries.title: Action-Attack
entries.content: Action-Attacks are actions that can either be used as a Standard Action or as an attack with an AS of 1.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Action-Attack.md

entries.title: Combat Maneuver
entries.content: Combat Maneuvers are Action-Attack that target AC. AC should have separate notes for bonuses towards specific maneuvers. You add both STR and DEX to these attacks, rather than just DEX. When making a Combat Maneuver, you must decide which specific form it takes, such as a Fell, Dirty Trick, or Shove. A successful Combat Maneuver will inflict a condition based on the form you chose. Combat Maneuvers can sometimes benefit from rolling a Critical Hit, by augmenting its power instead of its damage. See: Dirty Trick Disarm Drag Feint Fell Grab Shove Steal
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Combat Maneuver.md

entries.title: Dirty Trick
entries.content: Apply clumsy 2, sickened 2 or blurred vision to a creature. They must spend a standard action to get rid of the condition.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Dirty Trick.md

entries.title: Disarm
entries.content: Knock a held item out of a creature’s hand, landing at their feet. It takes 30 ft of Movement or a Standard Action to pick up an item off the ground, which Provokes.
