entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Disarm.md

entries.title: Drag
entries.content: Requires a free hand or prehensile appendage. Target creature stays adjacent to you for the remainder of your turn. If the creature is not adjacent to you when you successfully drag, they are automatically pulled adjacent to you. You can choose any space within your natural reach to place the creature in at the end of your drag.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Drag.md

entries.title: Feint
entries.content: Feint is the use of Deception vs the target's Insight. Feint is NOT considered an Attack, but you can still use your ACC in place of Deception. It is still classified as a Combat Maneuver, and can benefit from any bonuses or defenses relevant to them.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Feint.md

entries.title: Fell
entries.content: Inflict Knocked Down.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Fell.md

entries.title: Grab
entries.content: Requires a free hand or prehensile appendage. As long as the Grab persists, you and your foe gain the Entangled condition, the grabber is considered Grabbing, and the target is considered Grabbed. Each round you can spend another Action-Attack to maintain the Grab and deal damage as per a melee Attack, requiring no Roll. If you are moved out of reach from the target, your opponent succeeds at a Grab on you, or you are otherwise unable to maintain your grip, the target is freed and the conditions end. Opponents that Grab you in return can continue the Grab as if they are Grabbing. Special: Multiple creatures can Grab one creature. The Entangled conditions stack. Special: Creatures ignore the attack penalty from partial and total concealment against creatures they are engaged in a Grab with. See alternate win condition>restraint/capture for more options on locking someone down for good.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Grab.md

entries.title: Shove
entries.content: Push the target 10ft away from you. On Crit, add an additional 10ft.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Shove.md

entries.title: Steal
entries.content: You take an item that is not in the target's hands, but is otherwise accessible on their person. Steal can use Hands in place of ACC. Worn Equipment is assumed to be ineligible targets unless it is an Accessory.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Combat Maneuvers/Steal.md

entries.title: AS
entries.content: Attack Speed (AS): In order to decide how many attacks to make, you must use the AS of anything available to you when you take your Attack Action. Most weapons have an AS greater than 1, allowing you to make multiple attacks. If you have multiple ways to attack, you can combine them together. However, you cannot "overlap" your AS. To visualize this - Here we have a character that has a dagger in hand with an AS of 5, a mace in the other with an AS of 3, and multiple Action-Attacks with an AS of 1. He can take one action from every column, meaning if you use a Spell (AS-1) you can no longer do any attacks that use the same column. He could do - 5 dagger attacks - 4 dagger attacks and a Spell - a Special Attack and 2 mace attacks and 2 dagger attacks, etc... However, he cannot do a Spell and a Special Attack on the same turn, as they only have an AS of 1 individually.

entries.title: Attack
entries.content: Attack rolls are any type of harmful effect targeting a creature that does not require a saving throw. This can be spells, swords, or trying to push your foe off of a cliff (see Combat Maneuvers). Default: Roll+ACC+/-(circumstantial bonuses or penalties) When you roll an attack, you compare it to the target's AC. If you roll under it, you miss, and you usually deal no damage. If you meet it, you hit, and roll the damage associated with the attack. If you roll 20 or more points over their Avoid, you Critically Strike (Crit), adding your Critical Damage to the attack.

entries.title: Crit
entries.content: Critical Hit: an Attack that adds Critical Damage. Normally, this is a result of rolling an attack and beating their AC by 20 or more. Other abilities may change the conditions needed to score a Critical Hit.

entries.title: Critical Damage
entries.content: Critical Damage: Damage added to a Crit. By default, this amount is d10+LUK damage. This is in addition to your attack's normal damage. This only applies to HP damage, and does not add to any other effect. Items and abilities may change your Critical Damage.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Critical Damage.md

entries.title: Damage
entries.content: Damage is a value that subtracts from a target's HP when the effect takes place. "Losing HP" is synonymous with taking Damage. Damage is always assigned a type. The physical damage types are Crush, Slash, and Pierce, and the elemental types are Magic, Lightning, Fire, Cold, Holy, Necrotic, and Psychic. These are also Tags. If something deals multiple damage types, it usually adds both tags to the effect. For example, a flaming sword will deal Fire and Slash damage with its total damage, rather than separate d6 slash and d4 fire. Fire and Cold effects are mutually exclusive. For Weapons, damage is determined by the weapon used and adds your STR. A Technique may add to this as well. For Spell, this value is determined by your LV and SP. Any given effect will describe how to determine the damage it deals.

entries.title: Dual Wielding
entries.content: When using something in each hand, you gain the full benefits of both. You may benefit from two staves granting casting bonuses, use both of their AS, a sword and shield - whatever you like. If you use two weapons of the same AS, they gain +1 AS. Both weapons must be used at least once. You cannot engage in Dual-Wielding if you have a Two-Handed item. For example, you cannot swing a greatsword and then use Unarmed Strikes or throw shuriken with their higher AS.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Dual Wielding.md

entries.title: Line of Effect
entries.content: A straight line between two places with no Total Cover or impassable obstacles for a given effect grants Line of Effect. This is different from sight, as you may be able to see someone and not Target them (such as through a window).
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Line of Effect.md

entries.title: Offense Calculator
entries.content: | Accuracy | Weapon Damage | Attack Speed | | --------------------------------- | ------------------------- | -------------------- | | | | | | Critical Rate (decimal) | Critical Damage | | | | | | | STR | STR Multiplier (1h or 2h) | | | | | | | Target's HP | Target's Avoid | | | | | | Hit Chance = % Attack Power = Target's Defense Power = Time to Kill = Rounds This Time to Kill formula is not accurate for Hit Chances above 100%.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Offense Calculator.md

entries.title: Ranged Attack
entries.content: A Ranged Attack is an Attack made with ranged targeting. This means you can make the attack up to the listed range, not limited by the space you Threaten. These attacks can also be penalized due to Cover. Physical Ranged Attacks have two listed ranges - the first is Close Range and the second is Wide Range. Making a Ranged Attack Provokes. Abilities that function from a distance but do not use an Attack Roll are not Ranged Attacks.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Ranged Attack.md

entries.title: Switching Weapons
entries.content: At the start of your turn, you can decide what's in your hands from your inventory. You can draw and put away any weapons without penalty. This is a Free Action as long as it's done at the start of your turn. If you decide to change what you're wielding at another point in your turn, it becomes a Swift Action - and you can't do both. Handedness is an important concept here. When you use your hand for something other than a free action, you usually cannot use it for something else on the same turn. The main exception to this is Two-Handed items, which allow you to let go with one hand to perform an action. Any other exceptions should be handled with discretion.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Attacking/Switching Weapons.md

entries.title: Targeted
entries.content: A Targeted ability refers to one where you must select targets to apply the effect, which is not an Attack Roll. Some abilities are particular about what they work on, and will fail if used outside of their scope. You must have Line of Effect and be able to see your target to target them. If you cannot see them, you must target their space with the intention of targeting them.

entries.title: Ashen One
entries.content: In dark souls, certain types of creatures, namely the player character, hold a special place in the world's lore. When you die you don't reload the game, you canonically respawn at the location you last rested, leaving behind all your money where you died. You could choose to adopt a similar system where certain types of conditions need to be met for these unique creatures to die for real. Having the characters lose all their money might not be the best approach for a TTRPG: players like their money. But, in souls games you can go back to the place you died and collect the money again, so maybe. This kind of natural respawn mechanic is a good fit for campaigns where you expect your players to encounter dangerous creatures on the regular and your players don't get too discouraged from losing. Meat grinder without the consequences of losing your character for good.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Death and Resurrection/Ashen One.md

entries.title: Cloning Device
entries.content: You start off your adventures waking up in some alchemist's lab, surrounded in copies of yourself. Whenever you die, there is a fresh body waiting for you back at the lab that your soul gets sucked into. This plays more into having a secret base type thing, and it feels a little less metagame-y than "chosen by god." it also has an interesting mystery component to it. Why were you guys chosen as clones? Whose lab is this? How's that for storytelling with resurrection?
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Death and Resurrection/Cloning Device.md

entries.title: Death and Resurrection
entries.content: The purpose of resurrection in TTRPGs is primarily for the benefit of the players. If a DM makes frequent use of the resurrection spells for entities that the players went to great lengths to kill, it heavily undermines their effort and feels terrible, even if plausible. The powers that be should instead be very particular about the who gets a second chance. If the players are the main character of the story, then the game's resurrection mechanics should treat them as such. As a replacement for most resurrection effects, use these rules instead. Or don't use resurrection at all. It's your game. Whatever. IMPORTANT NOTE: Please make sure your players are on board with whatever you decide. Nobody likes surprise mechanics. See: Ashen One Cloning Device Limited Resurrection Tombstone Withers
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Death and Resurrection/Death and Resurrection.md

entries.title: Limited Resurrection
entries.content: Pose a caveat to resurrection magic that imposes a severely limiting factor, such as only being able to revive a creature shortly after it died with some kind of resource attached to it. Maybe even make it a limited resource by tying it to physical items, like scrolls with this effect attached to it. EFFECT | | | |---|---| |Range|Reach| |Target|One dead creature| |Duration|instantaneous| DESCRIPTION You breathe new life into a recently deceased creature. If the creature has died within the last minute, they are brought back to life at 1 hp and drained 1.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Death and Resurrection/Limited Resurrection.md

entries.title: Tombstone
entries.content: In the event of your characters untimely demise, worry not, for the gods smile upon you. When killed, your body becomes a tombstone with your name and face on it. It weighs as much as you did, including all of your equipment. This tombstone can be carried back somewhere to perform a ritual and bring the character back to life. This can be a place of significance to this god, something generic like a church or something with more story relevance. It can be wherever home base is, or you can require the players to reach certain points in the campaign in order to get their characters resurrected (Ex: Your friend died by the lich's hand, and now, to get them back, you have to destroy his phylactery. Make a temp character!). The basic idea is there: satisfy this entity's conditions and life will be restored.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Death and Resurrection/Tombstone.md

entries.title: Withers
entries.content: In Baldur's Gate 3, there is an NPC that shows up in your camp that has a vested interest in your success. He has powers that aren't like normal characters, chief among them the ability to resurrect fallen allies. You could easily introduce a similar character into your campaign, maybe even the introduction to the campaign is this NPC resurrecting the players. This particular method has the benefit of being less nebulous than divine forces. It gives someone the players can interact with and someone that can give them direction. Whatever the reason they have for resurrecting your players, it's because they need their help.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Death and Resurrection/Withers.md

entries.title: Defeat
entries.content: When a creature falls to 0 HP, they gain the Defeated condition. They cannot do anything more than a mild whisper while at or below 0 HP. If they are healed to positive hit points, they do not lose the Defeated condition, but they may Crawl at a rate of 10 feet per turn, or move at full speed when assisted by another creature. This mostly only applies to important characters. A character is important when the players or DM say so (often the player characters themselves, an NPC relevant to the story, or a major villain). When an important character defeats an unimportant character, it is assumed they are killed outright unless otherwise stated by the characters attacking. If a creature reaches an amount of negative HP equal to its maximum HP, it dies outright regardless of its importance. See Recovering from Defeat.

entries.title: Healing
entries.content: Healing is an effect that restores current HP up to your maximum HP, grants Temp HP, or removes debilitating status conditions.

entries.title: HP
entries.content: Hitpoints (HP) are a representation of how much offense you can weather. If you run out of HP, you are Defeated. Your total HP is determined primarily by Class, but can also be augmented by abilities, Feats, and even Race. When you take Damage, you reduce your current HP out of your normal maximum HP. Your current HP value can be negative. Every character with a class starts with 30 HP, with an additional bonus from their class every level (Usually around +10).

entries.title: Immunity
entries.content: Having an Immunity represents that a particular Damage type or classification of ability has no effect on you.

entries.title: Long Rest
entries.content: Taking a Long Rest requires being in a place with no immediate threats or hazards for at least 8 hours, during which you sleep to benefit from Natural Healing. Proper rest requires being in a safe environment with the minimum necessary accommodations to not ache in one's sleep. Lacking any of these requirements results in only restoring half of one's missing HP, or less if the situation is worse, at the DM's discretion. If you are interrupted but spent at least 15 minutes resting, it counts as a Short Rest.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Hitpoints/Long Rest.md

entries.title: Natural Healing
entries.content: Naturally Healing requires eating Food. Food restores varying amounts of HP based on the food eaten. You must take a Short Rest or Long Rest to eat food. The amount recovered is based on the food. With a Long Rest, a character restores all of their HP and all of their Limited abilities and spent Mana. You can only Long Rest once each day. You must have eaten at least once since the last time you Long Rested (or eat during the Long Rest), or else you will not recover HP. A proper Long Rest requires being in a safe environment with the minimum necessary accommodations to not ache in one's sleep. Lacking any of these requirements results in only restoring half of one's missing HP, or less if the situation is worse, at the DM's discretion. If you are interrupted but spent at least 15 minutes resting, it counts as a Short Rest.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Hitpoints/Natural Healing.md

entries.title: Recovering from Defeat
entries.content: After being Defeated for an hour after the last time it took damage, a creature may attempt to shake off the condition with a STR Roll. On a 10 or higher, they lose the Defeated condition, but as long as their HP remains negative, they are Staggered. On a fail, they lose 5 HP. After successfully recovering, the creature is Drained by d4-LUK. This drain cannot kill the creature.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Hitpoints/Recovering from Defeat.md

entries.title: Resistance
entries.content: Having Resistance to a Damage type makes you take half damage from it.

entries.title: Rest
entries.content: Take a Short Rest or Long Rest.

entries.title: Short Rest
entries.content: Taking a Short Rest requires being in a place with no immediate threats or hazards for at least 15 minutes, where you can eat and stretch and wipe your brow to benefit from Natural Healing. During a Short Rest, you can Prepare Techniques.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Hitpoints/Short Rest.md

entries.title: Temp HP
entries.content: Temporary Hitpoints (Temp HP) are gained separately from your HP. They are lost before your HP, and multiple sources do not stack - only the highest applies. Unless otherwise stated, Temp HP only lasts 1 minute.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Hitpoints/Temp HP.md

entries.title: Weakness
entries.content: Having a Weakness means you take 50% more damage from Damage of that type, or have a -4 penalty to Saves against effects of a certain type if they are not damage.

entries.title: Fall Damage
entries.content: Fall damage increases by 3 Crush for every 10 feet you fall, capped at 60 damage. Every 50 feet you are also Drained 1, capped at 4. When determining fall distance, subtract your Jump. If you take more damage than your AC (Fell), you are Knocked Down.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/More Rules/Fall Damage.md

entries.title: Light Level
entries.content: Light comes in 3 forms. ==Bright Light== A sunny day or a torch lit room. Bright light let's creatures see things clearly. Most creatures can see in bright light without any penalty. ==Dim Light== Moonlight or at the edge of your torch light. Many humanoids cannot see well in dim light. Features in dim light appear only as a silhouette with dull, if any, color. Without special senses, creatures have Partial Concealment in dim light. ==Darkness== The depths of a cave or deep underwater. Few creatures can see clearly in a complete darkness. Some, such as humans, can't see at all. Those that can (such as with night vision or Darkvision) still only see in grayscale. Without special senses, creatures have Total Concealment in darkness.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/More Rules/Light Level.md

entries.title: Rounding Numbers
entries.content: Always round decimals down, minimum 1.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/More Rules/Rounding Numbers.md

entries.title: Size and Reach
entries.content: This game is meant to be played on a grid of hexes or squares. Personally, I prefer hexes. Creatures must be represented in such a space. That's why creatures are broken up into size categories. | | | | | |---|---|---|---| |Size|Space|Reach|Description| |Tiny|1 space|0 ft|Typical for fairies and pets like cats. Tiny creatures are usually around 1 ft tall and weight <10 lbs.| |Small|1 space|5 ft|Typical for goblins and common animals like dogs. Small creatures are usually around 3ft tall and weigh around 30 lbs.| |Medium|1 space|5 ft|Most common size for creatures in general. Medium creatures are usually around 6 ft tall and weigh around 150 lbs.| |Large|~3 spaces|10 ft|Common size for monsters like giants. Large creatures are usually around 10 ft tall and weight around 600 lbs.| |Huge|~7 spaces|15 ft|Enormous monsters like dragons fit here. Huge creatures are usually around 15 ft tall and weigh around 3k lbs.| |Massive|10+ spaces|20 ft+|Massive creatures are terrifying monstrosities like kaiju and dinosaurs. Massive creatures are over 20 ft tall and weigh tons.| Creatures threaten all spaces they occupy by default. You can enter the space of a creature that is a size category larger or smaller than you. If you leave a space occupied by a creature, it provokes an AoO as though you were leaving a threatened area. If you get attacked this way, the same creature can't also AoO you for leaving their threatened square in the same turn.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/More Rules/Size and Reach.md

entries.title: Specific Defenses Rule
entries.content: Sometimes, a player or creature will have bonuses to their defenses against specific effects. For example, they may have +4 AC against Fell attempts. If not otherwise stated (such as "Fell attempts from Attack Rolls"), apply these bonuses to any instance of an ability that performs a similar function, especially when it is a secondary effect. For example, Fire Blast and Low Sweep will cause Knocked Down. The defender should receive their bonus against these effects, even though these are Reflex Saves. In the case of Fire Blast, the bonus would only apply to the Knocked Down portion, allowing them to fail the save against the blast and take full damage, but not be Knocked Down.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/More Rules/Specific Defenses Rule.md

entries.title: Stacking Damage and Defense
entries.content: When you stack a source of flat damage reduction and multiplicative reduction, add them together in the way that reduces the damage the most. When you have multiple sources of increasing damage by a percentage, add the percentages together, do not multiply.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/More Rules/Stacking Damage and Defense.md

entries.title: At-Will
entries.content: An At-Will ability can be used as many times as desired, as long as you spend the appropriate actions (if any).
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Recharging Abilities/At-Will.md

entries.title: Limited
entries.content: A Limited ability can only be used once, after which you must Long Rest to restore it. If it is a Mana ability, such as a Technique or Spell, you can prepare a different slot with the ability to use it again.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Recharging Abilities/Limited.md

entries.title: Mana Burn
entries.content: Mana Burn is the loss of a daily Mana slot such that it cannot be recovered until you take a Long Rest, and needing to re-prepare the ability to another slot to use it again. This is usually voluntary, but can also be the result of an offensive effect.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Recharging Abilities/Mana Burn.md

entries.title: Mana
entries.content: Mana Slots (Mana): All creatures have 2+LV Mana unless otherwise stated. When selecting Techniques or Spell, each one takes up one Mana Slot, unless otherwise stated. How you use a given slot is determined by whether the ability is At-Will, Recharge, or Limited. - At-Will abilities can be used as you like, without affecting the Mana Slot. - Recharge abilities will temporarily consume the slot until you use the Recharge Abilities action. You do not need to re-prepare the ability, it returns to the slot as if it was not spent once you use the recharge action. - Limited abilities will make you lose the slot until you Long Rest. This is sometimes referred to as Mana Burn. You can re-prepare the ability to assign it to a different slot and continue to use it. When you learn abilities that must be assigned to a slot, you must Rest to assign them to those slots. A given ability can only be assigned once in your loadout. You can rest again to reassign your abilities. Abilities gained through class features or items usually do not take up Mana Slots, and thus you cannot re-prepare your ability to a different slot if it's Limited.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Recharging Abilities/Mana.md

entries.title: Recharge
entries.content: A Recharge ability can only be used once, after which you can use the Recharge Abilities action to restore it.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Recharging Abilities/Recharge.md

entries.title: Fortitude
entries.content: Fortitude Saves are one of the three primary Saves Rolled to avoid a negative effect. Your Fortitude represents your resistance to physical hardship, such as Poison, Disease, and concussive attacks. You add STR and LV to your Fortitude, as well as any bonuses from your Class.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Saving Throws/Fortitude.md

entries.title: Reflex
entries.content: Reflex Saves are one of the three primary Saves Rolled to avoid a negative effect. Your Reflex represents your reactions and ability to evade or mitigate sudden attacks such as Area Effects and Traps. You add DEX and LV to your Reflex, as well as any bonuses from your Class.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Saving Throws/Reflex.md

entries.title: Saving Throw
entries.content: Saving Throws (Saves) are Rolls decide the effectiveness of abilities or effects that do not require an Attack. It is typically the affected creature that rolls the save. In order to consider a saving throw a pass, the affected creature must roll higher than the DC of the effect. The DC of a Saving Throw is usually 10 plus the Level of the effect, or the attacking creature's Potency. Saves come in 3 forms: Fortitude saves (based on STR), Reflex saves (based on DEX), and Will saves (based on WIS).
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Saving Throws/Saving Throw.md

entries.title: Will
entries.content: Will Saves are one of the three primary Saves Rolled to avoid a negative effect. Your Will represents your mental resilience and ability to resist mental attacks such as Illusions, mind control, and Fear. You add WIS and LV to your Will, as well as any bonuses from your Class.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Saving Throws/Will.md

entries.title: Affliction - Hamstringed
entries.content: Tier 1 Affliction Description - Your leg muscles have been grabbed, torn, tenderized, and shredded, bringing great pain and hindering your mobility. Effect - Your speeds that rely on your legs are halved. Cure - Healing and resting for day.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Afflictions/Tier 1 Afflictions/Affliction - Hamstringed.md

entries.title: Affliction
entries.content: A type of permanent negative effect that can usually only be removed by taking some time off to rest, recuperate and relax. Afflictions come in tiers from 1-3. Higher tier afflictions usually require more extreme forms of care to remove. They are similar to Curses, but are often not magical in nature. Tier 1 Afflictions usually only take a day of rest, Tier 2 tend to take a week, and Tier 3 tend to only be cured when meeting special conditions.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Afflictions/Affliction.md

entries.title: Ablaze
entries.content: When a creature is set Ablaze, it takes 2d8 Fire Damage at the end of each turn and suffers -2 AC. Before taking damage, it gets a Reflex save to end the effect. A creature can choose to inflict Knockdown on itself at the end of its turn for a +4 bonus to this save.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Ablaze.md

entries.title: Anchored
entries.content: Creature cannot use Teleportation effects. If it attempts to, the action (and ability) is wasted.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Anchored.md

entries.title: Asleep
entries.content: Asleep: This creature is Knocked Down, can take no actions, and cannot be awakened unless it takes damage or an ally uses the Aid action to awaken them. The creature is also Surprised and suffers -20 Perception. If the creature is asleep through natural means, it can use perception to wake up by noticing something amiss.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Asleep.md

entries.title: Bleed
entries.content: Bleeding creatures lose the specified amount of HP at the start of each of their turns for a specified duration. If no duration is specified, it lasts indefinitely. The DC to stop the bleeding (with the Medicine skill, or magic healing with a CL check) is the attacker's Potency. Unlike most sources of Damage, Bleed effects do not deal a specific type of damage. They act as their own type in the sense that creatures can resist or be immune to it, but Bleed is a condition and not a real Damage type.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Bleed.md

entries.title: Blinded
entries.content: Sighted creature takes a -10 penalty to Perception and treats all creatures as though they had Total Concealment. Creatures' vision range decreases to 10 ft. Creature is also Surprised.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Blinded.md

entries.title: Blurred Vision
entries.content: Sighted creature takes a -4 penalty to Perception and treats all creatures as though they had Partial Concealment.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Blurred Vision.md

entries.title: Charmed
entries.content: Creature cannot attack the entity that inflicted this condition. The entity that inflicted this condition has a +4 bonus on Charisma Skills against this creature. This ends if the creature that inflicted the condition harms the charmed creature.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Charmed.md

entries.title: Chilled
entries.content: Creature is covered in ice. Creature has -2 AC, Resistance to Fire Damage and -15 Speed. This status ends when they take physical or fire damage.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Chilled.md

entries.title: Clumsy
entries.content: Creature takes a stacking penalty to Reflex and AC equal to the Clumsy value. This otherwise functions like Shaken. A Clumsy creature cannot ascend using Flight, or things that function similarly to flight, such as a Hover Speed.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Clumsy.md

entries.title: Confused
entries.content: Creature considers all others enemies. Every turn, they roll d10+LUK to determine how they act. For confusion effects that last more than 1 round, each subsequent d10 roll gets 2 added to the result. | Roll | Effect | | ---- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------ | | 1-2 | Attack nearest non-Companion creature once. | | 3-4 | Harm yourself for 2d8+STR Crush Damage as a Standard Action. | | 5-6 | Consume all movement to wander 15 feet in a random direction. | | 7-8 | Babble incoherently as a Standard Action. | | 9-10 | Confusion ends. |
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Confused.md

entries.title: Cursed
entries.content: A Cursed creature is suffering from a permanent debilitating condition. Curses cannot be dispelled, but they all have some way to get rid of them. This usually requires some convoluted action most people wouldn't do unless prompted. Can be identified using the "identify curse or affliction" feature in the Medicine skill.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Cursed.md

entries.title: Dazed
entries.content: A more severe version of Staggered. Creature cannot take a Standard Action and cannot make AoOs. -15 Speed.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Dazed.md

entries.title: Defeated
entries.content: A Defeated creature cannot do anything more than a mild whisper while at or below 0 HP. If they are at or are healed to positive hit points, they do not lose the Defeated condition, but they may crawl at a rate of 10 feet per turn, or move at full speed when another creature uses Aid. See Defeat.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Defeated.md

entries.title: Dominated
entries.content: A creature that is dominated is hit with a powerful charm effect, possessed, or controlled by some other means. They are unable to control their own actions and are subject to the will of another creature.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Dominated.md

entries.title: Drained
entries.content: A stacking condition that decreases all Rolls and Potency by 1. Lowers your current and maximum HP by 5 each stack. One stack is removed when Resting for a week straight.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Drained.md

entries.title: Entangled
entries.content: Creature gets -2 AC, and their Speed is reduced to zero. This condition usually comes with a means to escape manually with Athletics. Creatures without the entangled condition receive a +5 bonus on checks to untangle a creature.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Entangled.md

entries.title: Entombed
entries.content: The creature is encased in ice, stone etc. They have Total Cover and are Untargetable. Entombed creatures can only perform mental actions or try to escape (usually requiring an athletics check).
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Entombed.md

entries.title: Fascinated
entries.content: Creature cannot take actions other than watch the source of its fascination. Creature loses this condition after it is attacked, has a Saving Throw inflicted on it, or succeeds on a Perception check to notice a creature in its pockets or otherwise taking an offensive action. If the source of its fascination is no longer visible (or able to be sensed for other types of fascination), the condition also ends. After this happens, the creature temporarily becomes immune to fascination for 1 minute.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Fascinated.md

entries.title: Fatigued
entries.content: Cannot Charge or Dash. Jump is halved. -10 Athletics and Acrobatics. Removed on a Short Rest.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Fatigued.md

entries.title: Frightened
entries.content: Creature cannot move closer to the source of its fear. It has -6 ACC and opposed skill checks against the source of its fear.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Frightened.md

entries.title: Glowing
entries.content: Creature emits Bright Light with a 5 Ft Radius, causing it to suffer -20 Stealth and -2 AC. The AC penalty does not stack with Ablaze.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Glowing.md

entries.title: Grounded
entries.content: Through bent wings, malfunctioning magic, or disorientation, the creature is unable to stay airborne. Creatures currently flying immediately plummet and provoke AoOs, but retain enough flight to avoid Fall Damage. This also affects Hover speeds.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Grounded.md

entries.title: Held Down
entries.content: Creature cannot stand from Prone.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Held Down.md

entries.title: Invincible
entries.content: Creature's HP cannot be reduced.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Invincible.md

entries.title: Invisible
entries.content: You cannot be detected by sight. This grants you Total Concealment against any creature that primarily uses sight. You must still use Stealth to hide your presence and specific location, or else creatures will still be able to attack your space to try and hit you.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Invisible.md

entries.title: Knocked Down
entries.content: Creature is knocked Prone until the start of the inflicting creature or effect's next turn, at which point the condition ends without Provoking or spending Movement, unless the creature is Held Down. Swimming creatures can be prone, but airborne creatures become Grounded instead.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Knocked Down.md

entries.title: Mindless
entries.content: Creature does not have any capacity for reasoning. It performs basic motions regardless of external stimuli. This status grants immunity to many Mind-Affecting effects.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Mindless.md

entries.title: Necrosed
entries.content: Healing effects that restore HP or grant Temp HP are half as effective (minimum 1 healing).
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Necrosed.md

entries.title: Pacified
entries.content: The creature cannot take aggressive actions against enemies with intent to inflict damage or assist its allies in inflicting damage.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Pacified.md

entries.title: Prone
entries.content: Creature is lying down or otherwise on the ground, has -4 AC and ACC, and can't move unless they spend 30 movement to end the condition, which Provokes. Prone creatures gain +4 AC against Ranged Attacks instead. This condition ends automatically after one round unless otherwise stated.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Prone.md

entries.title: Shaken
entries.content: Creature takes a penalty to Will and Potency equal to the Shaken value. Adding new stacks of Shaken gives all stacks the longest duration of all the effects. Usually, Shaken wears off after 1 minute out of combat.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Shaken.md

entries.title: Sickened
entries.content: Creature takes a penalty to Fortitude and ACC equal to the Sickened value. Otherwise functions like Shaken. Sickened usually wears off after 1 minute out of combat.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Sickened.md

entries.title: Silenced
entries.content: Creature cannot speak, including to cast Spell. Spells that state an absence of speech can still be cast.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Silenced.md

entries.title: Siphoned
entries.content: The creature is severed from its magic. It is not capable of casting Spells, Concentration, or using its activated Supernatural abilities. Constant effects, effects from items, or effects that were already cast remain in effect.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Siphoned.md

entries.title: Staggered
entries.content: Creature can only take a Standard Action or Swift Action each turn, not both. -15 Speed.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Staggered.md

entries.title: Stasis
entries.content: Creature is frozen in time, or some other particularly powerful effect. They are Untargetable, Unassailable, Unstoppable and Invincible. They cannot take any actions unless otherwise stated.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Stasis.md

entries.title: Status
entries.content: A Status Effect is a condition that is placed on a creature to apply CC, change their rolls, and otherwise modify how they interact with the world... For better or for worse. See: Ablaze Affliction Anchored Asleep Bleed Blinded Blurred Vision Charmed Chilled Clumsy Confused Cursed Dazed Defeated Dominated Drained Entangled Entombed Fascinated Fatigued Frightened Glowing Grounded Held Down Invincible Invisible Knocked Down Mindless Necrosed Pacified Prone Shaken Sickened Silenced Siphoned Staggered Stasis Stunned Submerged Surprised Taunted Time Out Unassailable Unstoppable Untargetable Wet
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Status.md

entries.title: Stunned
entries.content: A more extreme form of being Dazed. Creature cannot take any actions or movement. Creature is Surprised.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Stunned.md

entries.title: Submerged
entries.content: Target is completely surrounded in liquid. This triggers Aquatic Combat and Improved Cover.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Submerged.md

entries.title: Surprised
entries.content: Creature is unable to respond effectively to attacks due to Stealth, Feinting, or some other status or Circumstance. Attacks made against a Surprised creature get a +10 bonus. This status effect is also a Circumstance that can be determined on a per-creature or per-attack basis, but can also be a condition that applies to all incoming attacks. Creatures Surprised by the start of a combat also place below non-Surprised creatures regardless of Initiative result.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Surprised.md

entries.title: Taunted
entries.content: A Taunted creature must use all their attacks on the target of the taunt, and must include the target in all of their special attacks (Spells, Supernatural, etc.). A taunted creature can only move if the movement puts them closer to the creature that taunted it. A creature taunted by 2 or more creatures may decide which they'd like to attack (assuming they attack at all). More extreme forms of taunt may restrict the types of actions the creature can take while taunted.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Taunted.md

entries.title: Time Out
entries.content: A creature in Time Out has lost the will to fight, and has surrendered to you. They cannot inflict harmful effects on anybody or anything. They also cannot cast spells without your permission. They meekly follow your commands (ex. follow me), but won’t do anything against their ethos (kick that puppy) or that is dangerous (jump off that cliff) without extreme circumstances. If you or your allies attack the creature or cast a harmful spell on it, the condition ends. Treat it like a slightly more convenient form of unconsciousness if you want to interact with the creature after the combat. Many minion type creatures will acquire this status effect when their leader is defeated.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Time Out.md

entries.title: Unassailable
entries.content: Creature ignores penalties that result from Circumstance or Status.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Unassailable.md

entries.title: Unstoppable
entries.content: Creature cannot be moved by force, and can move and take actions normally regardless of any status.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Unstoppable.md

entries.title: Untargetable
entries.content: Creature cannot be targeted.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Untargetable.md

entries.title: Wet
entries.content: Gain weakness to Electric and Cold Damage. When a wet creature takes Electric or Cold damage, the condition ends. Being wet is something that can come up often in the environment. Only by being drenched in heavy rain, submerged in water or something similar can one be considered wet to the point where this has a mechanical effect.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Status Effects/Wet.md

entries.title: Cold
entries.content: Cold is a Damage type Tag, representing the disruption of movement and natural processes through cold and freezing.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/Damage Types/Cold.md

entries.title: Crush
entries.content: Crush is a Damage type Tag, which represents bludgeoning attacks, shockwaves, and blunt force trauma.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/Damage Types/Crush.md

entries.title: Fire
entries.content: Fire is a Damage type Tag, representing destruction through heat melting metal or cooking flesh.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/Damage Types/Fire.md

entries.title: Holy
entries.content: Holy is a Damage type Tag, representing attacks against the soul or convictions, or divinely-sourced retribution. Usually particularly effective against Undead and Fiends.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/Damage Types/Holy.md

entries.title: Lightning
entries.content: Lightning is a Damage type Tag, which represents ionization and burning through the use of electricity.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/Damage Types/Lightning.md

entries.title: Magic
entries.content: Magic is a Damage type Tag, which represents damage that is supernatural in origin, forces rending and unmaking through means that cannot be described by physical processes.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/Damage Types/Magic.md

entries.title: Necrotic
entries.content: Necrotic is a Damage type Tag, representing the decay of flesh, poisons, and the organic disruption of life processes. May bolster Undead.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/Damage Types/Necrotic.md

entries.title: Pierce
entries.content: Pierce is a Damage type Tag, and represents force applied across a small surface area, usually by pointed objects.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/Damage Types/Pierce.md

entries.title: Psychic
entries.content: Psychic is a Damage type Tag, representing an assault on a creature's mind. Usually ineffective against Mindless creatures.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/Damage Types/Psychic.md

entries.title: Slash
entries.content: Slash is a Damage type Tag, and represents damage dealt by cuts, chops, and slices with a sharp or thin weapon.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/Damage Types/Slash.md

entries.title: Abnegation
entries.content: These spells focus on disabling magic and protection.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/School Tags/Abnegation.md

entries.title: Conjuration
entries.content: These spells focus on summoning, displacement, and temporary creation.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/School Tags/Conjuration.md

entries.title: Divination
entries.content: These spells focus on gaining knowledge through spying and querying the universe.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/School Tags/Divination.md

entries.title: Evocation
entries.content: These spells focus on the manipulating elements and focusing power to destructive effect.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/School Tags/Evocation.md

entries.title: Illusion
entries.content: These spells focus on warping perception to impose one's will over others. Enchantment spells are Illusion spells that are also Mind-Affecting.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/School Tags/Illusion.md

entries.title: Transmutation
entries.content: These spells focus on changing things into other things.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Tags/School Tags/Transmutation.md

entries.title: Air
entries.content: Effect manipulates air to produce its effect. This is a non-Damage elemental tag.

entries.title: Bond
entries.content: An effect with the Buff or Bond tag grants a boon to a creature, or a shared effect. If an unwilling creature has a buff or bond used on it, it can choose to deny it.

entries.title: Buff
entries.content: An effect with the Buff or Bond tag grants a boon to a creature, or a shared effect. If an unwilling creature has a buff or bond used on it, it can choose to deny it.

entries.title: Caloric
entries.content: Effect either creates Food, or has special interactions when using it.

entries.title: Charm
entries.content: Charm effects allow the creature inflicting it to exert some degree of control over others. All charm effects are also Mind-Affecting.

entries.title: Companion
entries.content: In media it's very common for creatures to have minions, squires and sidekicks. This is what the companion system is for. Like most other content, the companion system is ill-suited for large quantities of creatures, like armies. It's meant to be more compact. Something to take with you on the go for your adventure. This could also reasonably extend to temporary allies that join your party. Companions are generally tied to your class, abilities and items. Any such ability is marked with this tag. If an ability has the companion tag, it summons an ally, or otherwise serves some kind of interpersonal function. >You can have 1+CHA Companions. >Companions always act on your turn if you are present. There is no separation between your turns, you all act in the same Initiative (rolled by you). >Companions gain bonuses or penalties based off of your CHA.

entries.title: Concentration
entries.content: An effect with the Concentration tag requires some degree of upkeep from the caster and typically has a duration. Concentration effects end if the caster is Defeated, Stunned, put Asleep, or otherwise completely prevented from taking any actions. You can also cease concentration Instantly. If you cast a spell with concentration, you must hold the staff in order to maintain your concentration. Being disarmed of a staff you are using to concentrate ends the effect. While you are concentrating on a spell, you cannot use that staff to cast other spells. However, you can use another staff to cast spells, or concentrate on another.

entries.title: Contingent
entries.content: The effect can be cast ahead of time with a specific trigger for when it activates. A creature can only have a single contingent effect active on them at once. The effect manifests as a clearly visible wisp of energy that floats around the creature. The DC to identify the effect increases by 5, but the fact that there is a contingent effect is clear.

entries.title: Curse
entries.content: Curse effects inflict permanent debilitating conditions on creatures. Curses cannot be dispelled, but they all have some way to get rid of them. This usually requires some convoluted action most people wouldn't do unless prompted. Can be identified using the "identify curse or affliction" feature in the Medicine skill.

entries.title: Darkness
entries.content: Effect either creates darkness, or has special interactions when in it.

entries.title: Dismissible
entries.content: Dismissible (D) effects can be ended prematurely by the caster as a Standard Action. Note that voluntary effects (such as buffs) can be dismissed Instantly without this tag.

entries.title: Earth
entries.content: Spell manipulates earth to produce its effect. This is a non-Damage elemental tag.

entries.title: Elusive
entries.content: Elusive: This action doesn't provoke an AoO.

entries.title: Emotion
entries.content: An Emotion effect is a Mind-Affecting effect that relies on manipulating the target's emotions.

entries.title: Fear
entries.content: Usually inflicts Shaken or Frightened. All fear effects are also Mind-Affecting.

entries.title: Figment
entries.content: Figments create creatures, objects, and terrain that don’t truly exist. As long as the creature does not directly interact with a figment, it believes it to be real. If a creature figures out that it's fake and tells its allies, or demonstrates by moving through it, they no longer believe it to be real. Directly interacting requires doing things like walking into a wall or attacking a creature, upon which the creature rolls a Will save. A failure indicates the creature will try to run around an obstacle or that they missed a creature. If used to satisfy the conditions of a surrender (such as making a spooky monster), the creatures affected get a will save to negate it. They have +6 on this save if they saw you cast the spell.

entries.title: Glamer
entries.content: A Glamer changes a subject’s sensory qualities, making it look, feel, taste, smell, or sound like something else, or nothing at all.

entries.title: Language-Dependent
entries.content: Language-Dependent effects require the target to understand your spoken words, or requires some form of clear communication that mimics language (like Telepathy).

entries.title: Light
entries.content: Effect either creates light, or has special interactions when in it. If unspecified, it creates Bright Light in its area of effect for one round, or on the spaces where something was targeted.

entries.title: Martial
entries.content: Martial effects allow the user to deliver the effect using the ACC and Damage and On-Hit Effects of a wielded Weapon, even if it mentions using another form of attack. Martial techniques and Special Attacks by default ALWAYS have the martial tag. It is not listed to save time/space.

entries.title: Mind-Affecting
entries.content: Mind-Affecting effects are a more general group that include things like Fear effects, Charms, and more. Creatures that are Mindless cannot be affected by mind-affecting effects.

entries.title: Multi-Strike
entries.content: This effect, when used with an Action-Attack, is improved by attacking multiple times. It may apply its effect to every attack on your turn.

entries.title: Pattern
entries.content: Like a Figment, a Pattern creates an image that others can see, but a pattern also affects the minds of those who see it or are caught in it. Common effects include Fascination or Blurred Vision. Pattern effects are also Mind-Affecting.

entries.title: Persistent
entries.content: Persistent Effects have an initial effect and an effect that persists over time. This type of effect cannot deal its persistent effect on the same round as its initial effect. Persistent effects end preemptively if the user is Defeated.

entries.title: Polymorph
entries.content: Polymorph effects transform creatures into other creatures. Many of the features granted from polymorph effects are based off the Shapeshifter's class features. You retain the ability to speak while polymorphed. When transforming using a polymorph effect, it can fall under one of the following to determine the nature of your transformation (some can be multiple). Chimeric Polymorph - Your form stays roughly the same, but acquires some features of the new creature that you're transforming into, such as claws, fur, a long tongue etc. When you chimeric polymorph, you do not lose access to any of your gear. True Polymorph - Your form completely changes to the form mentioned in the ability. You completely lose access to all of your equipment. There are only a handful of features recognizable from your previous self, such as eye color. Baleful Polymorph - This form of polymorph is inflicted upon you rather than willingly used. It functions very similarly to true polymorph, but provides fewer tangible benefits and often include debilitating Status. You lose access to your equipment and cannot speak.

entries.title: Scrying
entries.content: Scrying effects create a specific type of magic sensor, often from remote locations, usually for the purpose of spying on people. The sensor allows you to see and hear anything with any of your senses, so long as it is in the specified range the effect mentions. Scrying sensors are clearly visible to the naked eye. They usually take the form of an eye. Sensors that can move can use the caster's stealth bonus to hide as they move.

entries.title: Sigil
entries.content: The effect puts magical text on a surface with some kind of delayed effect, usually triggering when a creature walks within a certain radius of the sigil. A sigil must be clearly visible in order to function. If it is obscured, then it is deactivated until it is unobscured. Most sigils have the ability to apply a passphrase that, when spoken aloud, allows a user to move through the area without triggering the sigil.

entries.title: Subtle
entries.content: The effect has a chance for nobody to notice it. If the target creature fails its save, then the effect goes unnoticed. The DC to Identify Spell with the subtle tag increases by 5. If someone is watching you and suspects you are using a subtle spell in their presence, they can use Detect to get a Perception check at -10 against the Identify Spell DC of the effect.

entries.title: Summoning
entries.content: The Summoning Tag is placed on abilities that conjure a creature. Many summoned creatures are specific individuals that you must form a Summoning Contract with. However, Summoning Techniques do not usually call for a specific individual, instead conjuring a temporary disposable Minion with no prior setup. Summoned creatures instantly disappear when Defeated.

entries.title: Tag
entries.content: Tags are descriptors that let you apply general rules to similar effects. Tags are not just limited to spells, but spells do commonly use tags. Certain tags may only effect specific parts of an ability. Use discretion when needed. See: School tags Abnegation Conjuration Divination Evocation Illusion Transmutation Regular tags Air Bond Buff Caloric Charm Companion Concentration Contingent Curse Dismissible Damage Darkness Earth Elusive Fear Figment Glamer Language-Dependent Light Martial Mind-Affecting Multi-Strike Pattern Persistent Polymorph Scrying Sigil Subtle Teleportation Water

entries.title: Teleportation
entries.content: Teleportation effects allow the user, and sometimes their allies, to instantly travel between two locations. Teleportation tends to be very limited in scope, bringing you to very specific predetermined places or being wildly off-course if not. If unspecified, you must have line of sight to the location you are teleporting to.

entries.title: Water
entries.content: Effect manipulates water to produce its effect. This is a non-Damage elemental tag.

entries.title: Rolling Dice and Statistics
entries.content: This game relies on a special roll, detailed below. It will be referred to as dX in the content. Action resolution is done by using random chance to represent a range of success in an attempt to reach a target number, combined with a bonus based on your character's build, such as from their ability scores, skills, class features, active buffs, and feats. Content is currently being made with a roll equivalent to counting successes on a d15 die, exploding on any number above 1, success being any roll (including the first). This can be written into rolling simulator websites such as Roll20 to speed things up. The benefit of this method is that anyone can roll any number, unlike other systems where a large enough target number will make the roll impossible. The Short Version: Every point added for or against these rolls is about a 7% difference in power. This means Attack Rolls, Skill checks, Saving Throws, DCs, Avoid, all of it. A 6 point difference is roughly a 50% boost in odds. A 10 point difference is about double. As an example, if you gain 10 Accuracy or 10 Stealth, your odds of success are about twice as high. This is the case regardless of the opponent's statistics.
entries.path: Core Rules, How to Play/Rolling Dice and Statistics.md

entries.title: Armor
entries.content: Armors of varying weights have STR requirements, granting more AC at higher values. You lose 10 Speed and Jump for every point of STR you lack (minimum 5). Armor takes the Armor Equipment Slot. The following are the three most simple and common forms of armor. Light armor consists of hard leathers and gambesons, medium armor includes chain and scales with breastplates, and heavy armor covers every part of the body with a combination of plate, chain, and gambesons. | Armor Class | AC | Weight | STR Required | | | ------------ | ------ | ------ | ------------ | -------------- | | Light Armor | 1 | 10 | +0 | | | Medium Armor | 3 | 25 | +1 | | | Heavy Armor | 5 | 50 | +2 | -4 Stealth |

entries.title: Shield
entries.content: Shields are a subtype Weapon Group. Not all shields can be used as weapons, however. Shields are primarily used to gain defensive abilities to use as Actions, and most also passively increase your defenses (Mainly AC). Many shields have minimum STR requirements just like Armor, which penalize you in the same manner. Unless otherwise stated, shields are 1-handed. The following are the basic shields. | Type | AC | Weight | Str | Abilities | | ------------ | --- | ------ | --- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Shield | 2 | 10 | +0 | Shove +2Technique: BlockImmediate Action, At-Will: Reduce an incoming Attack's Damage by 8. Can be used for adjacent allies. | | Tower Shield | 2 | 30 | +1 | Technique: Cover Swift Action, At-Will: Create Total Cover for yourself on one edge of your space until the start of your next turn. Adjacent allies gain cover if they stand to the side or behind you. You cannot make attacks of opportunity during this effect.You can reduce the effect to Cover if you want to attack through that edge. | | Buckler | 0 | 5 | - | Technique: Buckler Parry Immediate Action, At-Will: Make an opposed Attack Roll against an incoming melee attack. If you beat their result, the attack is negated. |

entries.title: Background
entries.content: Background helps to determine what your character was doing before they got sucked up into an adventure. Other than acquiring the skills necessary to go out into the dangerous world, of course. Backgrounds give starting bonuses or equipment.

entries.title: Family Man
entries.content: You are the primary owner of a house somewhere in the world, usually at least on the tangent of civilization. You lived with either your immediate family, like parents and siblings, or you made a family of your own with a spouse and children. You own a meager house in a specific place, and a handful of family members to come home to after an adventure. Your house is always considered a suitable place to rest in order to cure general afflictions. See Backgrounds

entries.title: Noble
entries.content: You come from an upper ring of society. Your name might not carry the same weight everywhere you go, but your gold pouch certainly does. You get a bonus 1,000 starting gold that you can spend as you wish. Your family also gives you an allowance every month of 500g. For campaigns with a faster or slower pace, such as if there are frequent time skips, consider changing how often the allowance comes in. If you are far from home, it can take up to a week for your allowance to arrive. They can only ever be picked up from settlements. See Backgrounds

entries.title: Tradesman
entries.content: You worked in a job that required a specialized form of training, such as an alchemist, a doctor or a blacksmith. Over the years of your work you have accumulated a few tools of the trade. Select one of the following presets, or make one that's similar. Regardless of the selected trade, you have a place of work that you can return to that views you favorably, has masterwork equipment available for use, and that you can get +10% Wealth from with related sales and deals. Doctor - You start off with a medicine kit, a dose of troll oil, and 3 doses of Bloodblock. Alchemist - Start off with an alchemist kit, a love potion, and 2 alchemist fires. Craftsman (weapons/armor) - Start off with a set of combat ready equipment. You can start off with - Heavy armor and a weapon - Medium armor, 3 melee weapons, a ranged weapon, and a shield - Light armor, 6 light melee weapons, 2 ranged weapons, and a shield See Backgrounds

entries.title: Wanderer
entries.content: You go wherever the road takes you. You might have had a home once, but for one reason or another you had to or wanted to leave. You start play with a standard rock. More information can be found in the bestiary. Very basically, rocks are autonomous mass transportation and shipping vehicles. Most significant places in civilization will have service stations and parking available. See Backgrounds

entries.title: Crafting
entries.content: Crafting is the use of specific Profession skills to create items. In terms of gameplay, Crafting rewards players that use Resources gained in their adventures with a more efficient use of those resources. As an example, a flaming dragon hide that is normally worth 10000g might normally only sell for 5000g (as items only sell for half of their value by default), but is worth its full 10000g when used to Craft an appropriate item with it. It is also useful for acquiring items when there is no civilization from which to purchase them. Most crafting is done with 3 components: Resources, Mana Crystal, and Labor. When deciding to Craft an item, first determine how much of the item's value will be provided in Resources, how much will be Mana, and how much will be Labor. We will be using the Cleaving Axe as an example. Typically, half of an item's value is Resources, such as metals or special Loot. Non-magical items can have up to 75% of their value in Resources, while magic items can have as little as 25%. Unless specified on the item, players are free to choose how much value they want to assign to Resources within these bounds. A Cleaving Axe is worth 2000g, so let's assume in this case we want to minimize the time to craft, and assign 75% of its value in Resources. A Cleaving Axe only requires metal to be crafted. That means we need to have or buy 1500g of metal, and reduces the remaining value to 500g. A Cleaving Axe requires 1 Mana to craft. Any player can easily afford to sacrifice 1 Mana at some point during the crafting process to satisfy this requirement. This reduces the remaining value to 495g. The player then needs to provide labor to complete the process. The Labor provided must be done using a Profession skill that is related to the item being crafted, such as Cooking for Food, or Weaponsmith for a Weapon. Let's assume the player has a +10 bonus in their Profession: Weaponsmith skill. By Economics rules, they can complete 140g of value per day. This means it would take them 495/140 = 3.5 days of work to craft this item. If they had a friend with a related profession, they could assist too, and speed up the Labor process.

entries.title: Labor
entries.content: Labor is the work required to Craft an item. It determines the time it takes to complete an item, and is calculated by subtracting the cost of Resources and Mana Crystals from the item's total value. Labor is provided by all creatures participating in the crafting process. Each creature's Profession bonus is used as per Economics to determine how much they contribute to the craft. For example, if creating a special Armor requires 2000g of Labor, it would take a creature with a +5 bonus (65g per day) about 31 days to craft alone.

entries.title: Mana Crystal
entries.content: Mana Crystals are a physical manifestation of Mana used for Crafting and Rituals. They represent the power of populations, and are usually not readily available for direct purchase. One Mana is worth 5g when Crafting. When Crafting, whoever is providing the Labor can Mana Burn to add an equal amount to their product to meet its Mana Crystal requirement. Most Mundane items have almost no Mana requirements, but Magic Items tend to have substantial amounts, and powerful Magic Items and Rituals tend to require exorbitant amounts of Mana. The purpose of Mana Crystal requirements is to give innate value to populations and followership. Churches and kingdoms will establish donation sites to accumulate the power of their people, and will be unwilling to share those resources with just anyone. Those that have access to Mana have access to power in the world. Nobody can easily create powerful artifacts alone. See Mana Donation. Players that cannot reasonably meet Mana Crystal requirements should ally themselves with such organizations to gain access to their supplies, or establish a followership or church of their own.

entries.title: Resources
entries.content: Resources are items that can be used for Crafting that are sensibly related to the item being crafted. For example, flaming dragon hide may be useful for crafting flame-resistant armor, but not for crafting ice staves or crossbows. They are most often acquired through using Butcher to acquire parts from creatures, or as Loot.

entries.title: Common Prices
entries.content: LV 1 Characters start off with 3000g to spend. Higher level characters should get more gold, determined by the DM and as appropriate for the sort of campaign being run. The following are prices of basic equipment. Recall that basic equipment is the lowest quality available. This is budget equipment suitable for militias, thugs, and beginner adventurers. | Equipment Type | Cost | | ------------------------------------------------------------------ | ---- | | Light Armor | 50g | | Medium Armor | 200g | | Heavy Armor | 800g | | Buckler | 25g | | Shield | 50g | | Tower Shield | 100g | | Close, Dagger, Axe, Bludgeon, and Thrust weapons | 50g | | Ammunition, Caster, and Bow weapons | 100g | | Blade and Polearm weapons | 200g | | Trigger weapons | 400g |

entries.title: Economics
entries.content: Daily income, typically through the use of a skill, like profession, perform or alchemy. All income is based around a formula which calculates a yearly salary (y) based on your skill bonus (x). y=10000+x^2 * 250 Salary assumes you work for 5 days a week, 50 weeks a year. Divide this value by 250 to figure our your daily income. The chart below does this formula for you for most expected values. Anything lower than a +0 bonus to the task at hand makes a 5k salary, or 20g daily. This formula assumes a prosperous nation with a lot of economic opportunity and a population with many thousands of people per city. In poorer and less populous regions, consider using the following multiplier for all goods and services. Developing - Multiply all values by .75 Poor - Multiply all values by .5 | Skill Bonus | Daily Salary | Weekly Salary | Yearly Salary | | ----------- | ------------ | ------------- | ------------- | | 0 | 40 | 200 | 10000 | | 1 | 41 | 205 | 10250 | | 2 | 44 | 220 | 11000 | | 3 | 49 | 245 | 12250 | | 4 | 56 | 280 | 14000 | | 5 | 65 | 325 | 16250 | | 6 | 76 | 380 | 19000 | | 7 | 89 | 445 | 22250 | | 8 | 104 | 520 | 26000 | | 9 | 121 | 605 | 30250 | | 10 | 140 | 700 | 35000 | | 11 | 161 | 805 | 40250 | | 12 | 184 | 920 | 46000 | | 13 | 209 | 1045 | 52250 | | 14 | 236 | 1180 | 59000 | | 15 | 265 | 1325 | 66250 | | 16 | 296 | 1480 | 74000 | | 17 | 329 | 1645 | 82250 | | 18 | 364 | 1820 | 91000 | | 19 | 401 | 2005 | 100250 | | 20 | 440 | 2200 | 110000 | | 21 | 481 | 2405 | 120250 | | 22 | 524 | 2620 | 131000 | | 23 | 569 | 2845 | 142250 | | 24 | 616 | 3080 | 154000 | | 25 | 665 | 3325 | 166250 | | 26 | 716 | 3580 | 179000 | | 27 | 769 | 3845 | 192250 | | 28 | 824 | 4120 | 206000 | | 29 | 881 | 4405 | 220250 | | 30 | 940 | 4700 | 235000 |

entries.title: Mana Donation
entries.content: By going to specialized facilities, or by going to churches with gilded altars, an untrained creature can donate Mana via Mana Burn. A creature can safely donate up to one less than their maximum. There are usually safeguards against donating your max mana, but less savory individuals don't mind. Spending your max mana gives you the Tier 3 Affliction Mana Starvation. This means that most common people are only able to donate 1 Mana each day. Children typically do not possess enough Mana to safely donate. Specialized facilities and gilded altars are incredibly expensive, typically costing hundreds of thousands of gold to craft. This makes it so facilities for mana donation tend to be rather sparse, only located in sizable settlements with magical and religious influence. When mana is extracted, it is turned into a Mana Crystal. Mana Crystals are versatile and can change between states of matter, becoming either liquid or solid for ease of storage. Each point of mana can earn 5g in a mana extraction facility. In a church, it earns food and lodging for the day. Accumulation of Mana Most religious services happen in the evening after work, so that way people may spend their mana as they wish during the day, and donate it at night if they wish. With large generous populations this can mean that you can amass large quantities of mana rather quickly. Because most people can only donate 1 mana, you can almost 1:1 translate a population of donors to daily mana generation. Not everybody who donates has commoner tier mana, but at the same time, not everybody can always donate! So the 1:1 ratio is generally the go-to method of determining mana generation over time. Again, not all places have the correct facilities, so this is often available in villages.

entries.title: Populations
entries.content: Settlements receive classifications based on population. More populous settlements tend to condense more wealth, have more facilities and are more cosmopolitan. Expensive or luxurious services can be expected in larger settlements, but are unheard of in smaller ones. Hamlet - <1,000 people Village - 1,000+ people City - 10,000+ people Metropolis - 100k+ people Some general assumptions about a given population: - About 10% of the population is assumed to be over level 0, with a skew towards early levels. - Most regions have a dominant religion, with at around half the population favoring them. Metropolises tend to have more variety, while hamlets tend to be entirely dominated by a single religion.

entries.title: The Cost of Living
entries.content: Staying alive requires resources and food. The easiest way to obtain and represent these is to spend money. Only accounting for minimum food and necessities, the basic cost to remaining alive is 10g per day. In a town, where sleeping on the streets isn't advised, the cost increases to 30g. The savings from living in the wilderness are made up by the time spent setting up camps and creating one's own resources, as per Forage. Characters that do not spend this money must spend additional time collecting enough food to survive. Players should lose this much gold every day to represent the use of supplies. If they are on a particularly long journey where they will not encounter others to sell them supplies, they must spend this money ahead of time to avoid running out of supplies.

entries.title: The Value of Gold
entries.content: Estimating the true value of a single unit of currency is difficult to do when considering the possibilities of every setting. However, in order to establish some reference for pricing adventuring gear and items, we have to settle on one - so, for the purposes of the default pricing and earnings, we're going forward with the assumption that the differences between the peasants, tradesmen, and aristocrats is large, but not in such a way that compromises the ability of the peasantry to afford basic items. As a fantasy setting with swords and monsters, there are comparisons to be made to the value of labor in the medieval era. However, in order to avoid mixing the complexities of medieval economics with magic and superheroes to an audience that may not have studied such, the gap between the peasants and aristocrats is reduced, and social mobility is substantially increased. If a more extreme economy is desired, adjust the earnings from Economics and The Cost of Living. Average laborers like farmers can be expected to make ~10-20k gold every year, with the amount increasing with more sophisticated trades such as smiths or merchants. Gold pieces are small coins and are virtually weightless due to the minting process performed by the financial wizards. Another benefit of this minting is that it causes gold pieces to naturally stack into specific values (5, 10, 20, 100, 1000). Someone can easily hold 100g in their pockets, or 1000g in a dedicated pouch. Anything more and they are bursting at the seams and would be better off with a bank, or to switch to alternative methods of payment. Carrying around a bag of 100,000g would be like the real-world equivalent of carrying around a several briefcases full of paper currency. While this may happen for large transactions or when hauling away a dragon's horde, it's usually difficult to avoid drawing attention if you were to do it on the regular. When imagining gold costs, use the following: | Item Rarity | Cost Range | Description | | ----------- | ---------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Cheap | 1-100g | Items used for regular, day-to-day activities fall in this category. Food, clothing, a stay at an inn, or common alchemy or building materials fall in this range. The lower end is comprised of items like bread, candy, and clothing, while the high end may be specialized items like light weaponry, trade tools, and padlocks. | | Common | 101-1k | Common items are generally purchased less often than cheap ones by most. On the low end you get something like a furnace installation for a house, a med kit, minor potions, or a fancy outfit, and on the high end you get heavy armors, wagons, and masterwork weaponry. | | Expensive | 1k-25k | Expensive items must be saved up for by most common folk. These include long-distance travel vehicles, the average magic item and goods made with rare metals. On the low end you get good deals on failed magic items, high quality potions, and upgrade scrolls. On the high end you get something like a cannon, a sailing ship, or a meager home. | | Rare | 25k-250k | Rare items are usually reserved for the rich, or require loans, savings, or groups to pool funds to purchase. This includes houses, battleships, and masterfully crafted items that have been upgraded substantially. | | Unique | 250k+ | Large construction projects, ancient tomes of secrets, coveted legendary equipment, and expenses that are usually only sustainable by an entire town's contributions lie here. |

entries.title: Food
entries.content: Food is one of the most common and necessary consumable resources to survive difficult journeys and dangerous dungeons. It is the slower, more efficient alternative to Potions, which may grant their benefits briefly or in smaller amounts at a moment's notice. It is assumed all food items are portioned properly as a meal, and cooked to preserve. They never spoil as long as they are handled properly and are not damaged directly, such as by fire. Perishable Ingredients will spoil unless cooked. Food is consumed during a Short Rest over 15 minutes, unless otherwise stated. Food primarily restores HP, but may grant bonus effects until you eat again or Long Rest. The value of a particular food increases with how much it heals, what it grants, and how little it weighs. Because of how varied food can be, its value will often lead to haggling - however, at the very least, any such item will be worth more than its components. The creation of food requires two or more Ingredients, time, and skill. See Cooking and Crafting for more details. The following are some basic examples of food: | Name | Effect | Cost | Weight | Ingredients | Description | | --------------- | ------------------------- | ---- | ------ | --------------------------------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Scraps | Heal 1, Sickened 2 | 0 | 5 | Scavenged Materials | The bare minimum to stay alive.
