entries.title: Basic Weapon
entries.content: Basic Weapons are the default Weapons of a Weapon Group. They represent the effectiveness of common or makeshift weaponry. They have no Upgrade Slots, and come with the fewest amount of Weapon Qualities. Basic Weapons are the bare minimum afforded to arm common foot soldiers, or an adventurer in a pinch. Most people of note will quickly move on to better equipment. When in doubt, assume the following as the standard: | Weapon Description | Damage | Attack Speed | | | --------------------------------------------------- | ------ | ------------ | ---------------------------- | | Light, small weapons, such as daggers and claws | d6 | 4 | | | One-handed weapons, such as clubs, axes, and swords | d10 | 3 | | | Two-handed weapons melee weapons | 2d8 | 2 | May be 2d6 damage with Reach | | Ranged weapon (two-handed) | 2d6 | 2 | Long Range | | Trigger ranged weapon | 2d8+ | 1 | Long Range | | Thrown ammunition | d6 | 2 | |

entries.title: Close Range
entries.content: Close Range is the shorter of the two Range increments for Ranged Attacks with Ranged Weapons, where there is no ACC penalty.

entries.title: Exotic Weapon
entries.content: Exotic Weapons do not neatly fit into any Weapon Groups, and will list how they differ. They often break the norms of conventional weaponry.

entries.title: Range
entries.content: Weapons with ranged capabilities (thrown or otherwise) will also have a listed range. Ranges come in an X/Y format, with the X range increment being the accurate range (Close Range), and the Y being second range increment (Wide Range), taking a -4 penalty. | Range Category | Value | | -------------- | ------ | | Thrown | 20/40 | | Short | 40/60 | | Long | 60/120 |

entries.title: Special Attack
entries.content: Special Attacks are qualities that a Weapon can have that temporarily grant you a Technique-like ability as long as you wield them. See Class and Weapon Abilities. You must use the weapon when performing the Special Attack. As per the Mana rules, you cannot sacrifice your own Mana to get another use of a Limited Innate Technique unless otherwise stated. Special Attacks uses are also tied to the weapon - If you use the Special Attack, you cannot pass the weapon off to another creature to use it again, and the weapon has its own Recharge timer. This means you can't take the Recharge action and then pass it off to another creature to use their own Recharge.

entries.title: Unarmed
entries.content: Punches, kicks, headbutts, and any other strikes with one's own body. Natural Weapon Freehanded AS 4, 1 Crush Damage By default, if you use Unarmed strikes for Dual Wielding and you do not have a free hand, the AS is reduced to 2.

entries.title: Weapon Group
entries.content: A Weapon Group is a categorization of Weapons that describes the way it is used in combat, and is used to identify what Special Attacks, Abilities, and Techniques they're compatible with. The categories describe how they are used to attack, rather than how they look. If a weapon has more than one main category, then that means its category changes based on the way it is used, such as throwing a dagger instead of swinging it. There are 10 main groups: Axe, Blade, Bludgeon, Bow, Close, Dagger, Polearm, Thrown/Caster, Thrust, and Trigger, and 4 sub-groups: Ammunition, Natural, Shield, and Staff.

entries.title: Weapon Qualities
entries.content: Weapon Qualities describe what a Weapon does beyond its classification, Damage, and AS. | Quality | Description | | -------------------------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Bonus (+X) | This will be written as a specific Combat Maneuver, Skill check, or Attack type, and X will be the bonus to it. You add this bonus when performing the associated Roll with the weapon. Dual Wielding allows the application and stacking of this passive bonus within reason - A trip weapon can be used in conjunction with another, but a Hands weapon will not let you conceal your second weapon any better. | | Reach | Weapon can be used 5 ft farther. This doesn't change your natural Reach; all uses of this bonus reach must be through the weapon. | | Attached | Weapon is physically attached to the body in some way, specified in its description. +20 Disarm AC. Takes a Standard Action to draw. | | Freehanded | Doesn't require a hand to equip/use it, and counts as 1-handed. | | 2H | Item is two-handed. You cannot dual-wield while using two-handed weapons. Two-handed melee weapons add double STR to damage. | | TechniqueAbilitySpecial Attack | The weapon grants the listed Technique, Ability, or Special Attack as an Innate Technique when wielded. |

entries.title: Weapon
entries.content: Weapons are the most basic method of increasing one's offensive power. Just having a weapon and attacking an enemy is often enough to make you a substantial threat, regardless of your expertise or abilities. Weapons fall into Weapon Groups for the purpose of identifying what Special Attacks, Abilities, and Techniques they're compatible with. The categories describe how they are used to attack, rather than how they look. If a weapon has more than one main category, then that means its category changes based on the way it is used, such as throwing a dagger instead of swinging it. There are ten main categories: | Type | Description | | ----------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Axe | Can be 1-handed or 2-handed. Weapons made to cut or pierce using chopping motions. | | Blade | Can be 1-handed or 2-handed. Blades meant for slicing and stabbing, relying on the blade to do the cutting with a mere touch rather than chopping or committed thrusts. | | Bludgeon | Can be 1-handed or 2-handed. Bludgeons to beat the snot out of enemies in the most primitive way possible. | | Bow | Always 2-handed. Curved weapons held at the ends by taut or resistant elastic strings used for firing ammunition with a drawing motion. | | Close | Always "1-handed." Punches, kicks, claws, and headbutts that can be used in the closest of combat, even when pinned. These attacks can be with one's own natural weapons, or with weapons augmenting limbs. | | Dagger | Always 1-handed. Short, sharp weapons for getting close to enemies and striking weak spots or overwhelming them with angles of attack. | | Polearm | Always 2-handed. Long skirmish weapons for battlefield versatility. They combine the spacing of spears with the swings of axes. Often used to hook enemies in addition to being general weapons. | | Thrown/Caster | Almost always 1-handed. Weapons designed to be thrown using a swing from the hand or sling. Casters are armored gauntlets with thrown ammunition stored inside, used to draw and throw faster and harder. | | Thrust | Can be 1-handed or 2-handed. Blades and spears meant for dedicated thrusts to put enormous pressure at a single point. Often used to outrange and lunge at opponents. | | Trigger | Can be 1-handed or 2-handed. Weapons with handles that are loaded beforehand and then fire their ammunition with a trigger. Trigger weapons require an Action-Attack to reload. Trigger weapons do not add STR to damage. | And 4 subtypes: | Type | Description | | ------------------ | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Ammunition | Arrows, bolts, rocks, bullets, darts, or any other weapon that is either part of another weapon's use, or that is meant to be launched by itself in quick succession. This can also be a main group.Ammunition can be drawn as an Instant Action. Ammunition and its price and weight represent an unlimited source. You cannot easily "share" or otherwise split Ammunition between allies. You either have the ammunition or you don't - Exceptions can be made in the heat of combat, such as firing back an arrow that just hit a tree next to you. | | Natural Weapon | Weapons that are part of a creature's being. Examples include claws, fists, tails, horns, stingers, and tentacles. Most natural weapons are not universal, meaning they are different for each creature that has them and will be noted as such in their stat block. However, they do follow common trends. | | Shield | These weapons are also shields. | | Staff | These weapons qualify for completing the Staff component of spells, and may have additional statistics as a result. | Exotic Weapons do not neatly fit into these categories, and will list how they differ. Weapons come with damage values, attack speed values, and damage types as their core stats, in addition to the categories listed above. All standard weapons deal a physical Damage type. If a weapon has more than one damage type, you can decide which to use before you make a given attack with it. Damage values and Attack Speed correlate such that the damage tends to be very similar without any additional abilities or STR. The typical offense-oriented damage values and AS are as follows: | Speed | Damage | Use | | ----- | ------ | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | 5 | d4 | Best used with higher stats, On-Hit Effects, or in conjunction with other actions. | | 4 | d6 | Most versatile. | | 3 | d10 | Middle-ground option for one-handed uses and Dual Wielding. | | 2 | 2d8 | Best value with bonus attacks and Techniques. | Weapons with ranged capabilities (thrown or otherwise) will also have a listed range. Ranges come in an X/Y format, with the X range being the accurate range, and the Y taking a -4 penalty, referred to as the Range. | Range Category | Value | | -------------- | ------ | | Thrown | 20/40 | | Short | 40/60 | | Long | 60/120 | Some weapons come with Techniques and Special Attacks. These temporarily grant you a technique as long as you wield them. As per the Mana rules, you cannot sacrifice your own Mana to get another use of a Limited Technique unless otherwise stated. Special Attacks specifically are also tied to the weapon - If you use the Special Attack, you cannot pass the weapon off to another creature to use it again, and the weapon has its own Recharge timer. Many weapons come with Weapon Qualities. These describe what a weapon does beyond its classification, Damage, and AS. Unless otherwise stated, Weapons weights default to the following: | Group | Weight | | --------------------------------------------------------------- | ------ | | Close, Dagger, 1h Blade, Sword-Like 1h Thrust weapons | 2 | | 1h Axe/Crush/Thrust, Bow | 5 | | 2h Axe/Blade/Crush/Thrust, Ammunition, Caster, Polearm, Trigger | 10 |

entries.title: Wide Range
entries.content: Wide Range is the longer of the two Range increments for Ranged Weapons, in which you take a -4 ACC penalty.

entries.title: Equipment Slot
entries.content: There is a limit to how much wearable equipment you can use at once. This is represented by Equipment Slots, each of which can hold one piece of equipment of that type. By default, humanoid characters start off with the following Equipment Slots: | Slot | Description | | ---------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Armor | Usually covers the upper legs, full torso, shoulders, neck, and arms. Typically gives bonus AC for armors that require more STR, and other defensive bonuses for lighter armors or robes. | | Gloves | Covers the hands and wrist specifically. Typically grant offense-oriented bonuses or skill bonuses. | | Boots | For your feet. Usually related to mobility effects. | | Headgear | For your noggin. Headgear focuses on mental abilities or survival, such as with masks for poison or tinfoil hats for keeping out mental influence. | | Accessory(Two) | Humanoid creatures have two Accessory slots. Accessories are typically belts, bangles, jewelry, piercings, and rings. Accessories are often utility items, but are extremely diverse in the effects they provide. |

entries.title: Cerberus Style
entries.content: Fighting Style Feat When you are being Flanked, you gain the attack bonus against the creatures Flanking you. When you make Unarmed Attacks against a creature that is Flanking you, you can use a Swift Action to have them apply to another creature Flanking you this turn.

entries.title: Demon Style
entries.content: Fighting Style Feat You get a +2 bonus to attack and damage with Unarmed Attacks for 1 round when you take the Charge action. You can turn once during your charge. When you strike a creature with a Charge Attack, you can then Drag or Shove them as a Swift Action. Successful Drag or Shove attempts deal your Unarmed Damage to the creature.

entries.title: Dragon Style
entries.content: Fighting Style Feat Your unarmed strikes double their STR bonus to Damage. When you Critically Strike, you can unleash a 15 Ft cone behind the target as a Swift Action that deals the same damage as Magic Damage, Reflex halves.

entries.title: Fighting Style
entries.content: A Fighting Style Feat is a Feat that grants a Passive and active ability when using Unarmed attacks.

entries.title: Grabbing Style
entries.content: Fighting Style Feat Gain +2 to Grab attempts. When you Grab a creature, you are not Entangled, instead only suffering -15 Speed. When you Grab or maintain a Grab on a creature, you can attempt to Grab another creature as a Swift Action. Maintaining a Grab works on all Grabbed creatures.

entries.title: Monkey Style
entries.content: You can crawl and climb at full Speed. You can stand up early from Knockdown without spending Movement. When you strike a creature at least your size with an Unarmed Attack, you can begin to ride them as a Swift Action. This causes you to enter their space and follow their movement without spending any of your own. You gain Cover while riding, and if this bonus AC would cause an Attack to miss you, it hits the creature you're riding.

entries.title: Snake Style
entries.content: Fighting Style Feat When a creature misses you with an attack, you can move 10 Elusive Ft closer to it. If this movement puts you within reach of the attacker, it provokes an AoO. This AoO must be an Unarmed Attack. When you would be hit with an attack, you can spend an Immediate Action to make an opposed Attack Roll. If you match or exceed their roll, you instead negate the attack, which activates the passive effect.

entries.title: Antagonize
entries.content: Combat Feat Use Intimidation or Deception to Demoralize a creature. Instead of being Shaken, they are Taunted for one round. You can extend the duration by using your Swift Action on consecutive turns.

entries.title: Back to the Wall
entries.content: Combat Feat You cannot be flanked as long as you are adjacent to a wall. You are considered flanking a creature that is adjacent to a wall.

entries.title: Blind Fight
entries.content: Combat Feat You are not Surprised while Blinded. You ignore Concealment AC bonuses.

entries.title: Bodyguard
entries.content: Combat Feat When an ally is moved out of your natural reach (via its own volition or not), you can move as an Instant Action so that it is again in your natural reach. Any movement you take using this feat counts against your movement for this round. If you cannot reach your ally, you can move as close as you can get. You can position yourself in the most advantageous way around your ally, assuming you have the movement.

entries.title: Bonded Weapons
entries.content: Combat Feat Gain the ability to perform a 10 minute ritual that allows you to bond with 2 specific weapons. You cannot be Disarmed of these weapons. When you throw these weapons, they automatically Teleport to your hand after the attack is resolved, if desired. If these weapons somehow manage to leave your possession otherwise, you can spend a swift action to have them Teleport to your hand.

entries.title: Clustered Blows
entries.content: Combat Feat When you attack the same creature multiple times on your turn, apply DR only once.

entries.title: Combat Reflexes
entries.content: Combat Feat You can draw a weapon as part of an AoO if you have a free hand. Gain two additional AoOs. Opponents can tell you continue to threaten past the first AoO.

entries.title: Dimensional Reflexes
entries.content: Combat Feat When a creature Teleports, it Provokes from you. You get +20 Crit Range with these AoOs.

entries.title: Elemental Adept
entries.content: Combat Feat Choose an element from the magical Damage types. You ignore Resistance against this element. Immunity becomes Resistance. Whenever you wield this element, there is something visually distinct about it versus the norm, such as your flames turning black.

entries.title: Endurance
entries.content: Combat Feat Requirement: +1 STR The first time you would be Defeated or outright killed in a day, you are instead not Defeated. If it was a result of taking damage, your HP is set to 1. Whenever you are Defeated, you can make a single attack immediately before you are Defeated. You automatically pass the STR Roll when Recovering from Defeat.

entries.title: Fan Club
entries.content: Combat Feat Requirement: +1 CHA, LV 3 You use your influence and charm to gain a group of people that appreciate you. They are often willing to perform minor tasks for you, stick their neck out for you, but not risk their life for you. They are located in one specific place at first, but they may branch as you gain more levels and influence. The size of your fan club is CHA((LV)^2). One member of your fan club is your biggest fan. Your biggest fan is always a Minion. Other than that, there are no restrictions for what your biggest fan can be. When you gain this feat, you decide their class, race, stats etc. They count as a companion if they travel with you. Your biggest fan doesn't necessarily need to be a playable race, but those that aren't should be acquired through story related encounters rather than chosen.

entries.title: Fearsome Finisher
entries.content: Combat Feat Requirement: Intimidation Proficiency Whenever you Defeat a creature, you can use Demoralize as an Instant Action, and you get +4 Intimidation for the rest of the combat. When using Demoralize in this way, you Frighten the target for one round in addition to the normal effects.

entries.title: Fleet Footwork
entries.content: Combat Feat Requirement: +1 DEX Increase your base speed by 5ft. Your movement is Elusive against any target you have hit with a melee Attack this turn.

entries.title: Ghost Buster
entries.content: Combat Feat Requirement: Religion Proficiency You treat Incorporeal creatures as though they were corporeal.

entries.title: Longshot
entries.content: Combat Feat At the start of your turn, you can reduce your speed to 0 to remove the penalty from making a Ranged Attack with the second Range increment for this round.

entries.title: Maneuver Adept
entries.content: Combat Feat You get +4 ACC with Combat Maneuvers, and they can be used as a regular Attack instead of an Action-Attack. This means you can replace an AoO or other simple attack with a Combat Maneuver.

entries.title: Quickstep
entries.content: Combat Feat Requirements: +2 DEX You can reduce your speeds to 10 to make your movement elusive.

entries.title: Spellbreaker
entries.content: Combat Feat Requirement: Arcana Proficiency When striking a creature that is currently holding Concentration on a spell with a melee Attack, they must make a Fortitude save or stop concentrating. A Ranged Attack can be used as well, but the target gets a +4 bonus to their save.

entries.title: Escape Route
entries.content: Teamwork Feat Movement out of threatened squares also threatened by your allies is elusive.

entries.title: Move As One
entries.content: Teamwork Feat During an ally's turn, if they move, you can spend an Immediate Action to use your movement to move along with them. You must either end this movement within their natural reach, or threatening the same enemy as them. You subtract this movement from your movement next turn. Turn based games make movement awkward, but the idea is you are moving together, so other positional effects, such as Escape Route or Shield Brothers, can treat moving allies as within reach for the duration of the movement in circumstances where allies converge on a location or start in positions that are close to each other.

entries.title: Pack Tactics
entries.content: Teamwork Feat Flanking only requires threatening the same enemy, regardless of position.

entries.title: Shield Brothers
entries.content: Teamwork Feat Gain +2 AC when you are within the natural reach of an ally that wields a shield. The shield must have an AC bonus. You can use any shield benefit on an ally instead of yourself, as long as they remain within your reach.

entries.title: Tandem Charge
entries.content: Teamwork Feat Requirement - Move As One During an ally's turn, if they make a Charge Attack, you can spend an Immediate Action to charge along with them and make a simple attack. You must charge attack the same creature they do. Your Speed is zero on your next turn. Turn based games make movement awkward, but the idea is you are moving together, so other positional effects, such as Escape Route or Shield Brothers, can treat moving allies as within reach for the duration of the movement in circumstances where allies converge on a location or start in positions that are close to each other.

entries.title: Feat
entries.content: Feats are class features in progression that are gained every odd level. They allow your character to get bonuses to specific actions, abilities from other classes, and occasionally get general stat increases. Some feats have prerequisites, such as stat requirements, Skill Proficiency, or other feats. You must meet all of the requirements of a feat to take it.

entries.title: Stat Feat
entries.content: A Stat Feat grants numerical bonuses, such as to Skills or ACC, usually unconditionally, and not much else. These are for rounding out weaknesses and giving an indecisive PC or DM an easy pick-me.

entries.title: Teamwork Feat
entries.content: A Teamwork Feat is a Feat that provides a benefit only if used with other creatures that have the same feat.

entries.title: Difficulty and Integrity
entries.content: The Equivocation of Optional Mechanics as Difficulty Management in Video Games Preamble In the ongoing conversation about difficulty in games, it is crucial to recognize the different ways designers shape challenge—whether through numeric adjustments, increased enemy complexity, or opt-in mechanics like summoning or assistive features. Unfortunately, many argue that all optional mechanics are neutral tools for difficulty management that do not impact the core gameplay experience. As players and developers, we should focus on creating environments that allow individuals to experience the game in the way they prefer—including doing so without imposing significant changes that undermine the integrity of the core challenge. The goal should be to empower players while respecting both the game’s design and their personal approach to difficulty. How We Make Things Accessible In the gaming landscape, the design of difficulty and balance is a necessary part of accessibility for users with handicaps - especially in harder titles. Players that are too old or too new, that have responsibilities that pull them from the game, limited time, or that simply lack the necessary abilities to enjoy a game should have the necessary means to level the playing field. The design of difficulty in games can be broadly categorized into three distinct approaches: numeric, complexity-based, and opt-in mechanics. - Numeric difficulty involves straightforward adjustments such as increasing enemy health, damage output, or resource scarcity, making encounters more difficult through quantifiable means. This is the most simple approach, and is used as part of the other approaches - but alone is often only appropriate for games with minimalist mechanics and low skill expression. - Complexity-based difficulty, on the other hand, will change enemies to act with more intelligence, have more varied abilities and attack patterns, and require players to master the mechanics already present in the game to keep up. This is often the preferred method for any game with strategy or skill expression, but is the most taxing to implement. - Finally, opt-in mechanics—such as summoning allies, flying, or activating other assistive features—allow players to choose whether to bypass or mitigate certain challenges altogether. While these mechanics are often presented as optional tools for difficulty management, their adoption and integration can fundamentally alter the player’s experience. There's a clear outlier here. There are no limits to what developers can put into their games as "optional" mechanics. The flexibility is a double-edged sword, as the implementation can just as easily ruin the experience if there is not an appropriate alternative or less invasive means. For the purposes of this discussion, I will mainly refer to Skyrim, Mario, and Elden Ring. Attention to Detail All three methods of designing difficulty can easily interrupt the core gameplay experience when implemented thoughtlessly. In Skyrim, there is very little strategy and skill expression. At best, the player can move out of the range of some enemy attacks and strike back between them, or properly aim an arrow. Beyond that, the game is no different to MMOs such as RuneScape, where the player either engages in a slap fight whose winner is determined entirely by opposing statistics and how much healing is in their inventories, or the player stands out of reach of a melee opponent and attacks them with ranged weapons until they die helplessly. Skyrim uses numeric difficulty. Despite being the easiest approach, there are major oversights in its implementation that force players to use specific playstyles or exploits to keep up. For example, a player that wants to use primarily destruction magic will be greatly disappointed on higher difficulties as their entire Magicka bar is depleted defeating a single lesser bandit, and the abysmal regeneration rate and lack of potions will force them to resort to sword fighting or the use of AI exploits and loading zones. As the game progresses, the only way to have enough Magicka to defeat enemies without hours of grinding is through Alchemy-Enchanting exploits that bring the cost of spells to 0, or their damage to arbitrarily high numbers—the latter of which completely defeats the purpose of the numeric difficulty increase. Complexity-based difficulty is the hardest to implement. With the exception of complexity through AI improvements, it requires making more content on top of what should already be an adequate amount of content for lower difficulties. The more mechanics an enemy has, the higher the odds that they will invalidate a certain method of playing the game and require players to do something they are not interested in. For example, if the difficulty is in higher enemy aggression, then any playstyle that relies on large openings is going to suffer disproportionately. If the difficulty is in close-range incapacitation, then melee players will suffer more than ranged ones. Sacrificing some part of the original experience is often inevitable. There are exceptions where the numeric and complexity approaches meet. The speed of a game and the precision of its timings are a good example—Most of the game remains untouched, and a small adjustment in the reaction time necessary to beat the game can be the difficulty a player wants. At the crux of the issue lies difficulty through optional mechanics. These are the most likely to change the experience of a player. In Elden Ring, the variety of abilities in the game ranges from completely impractical to game-trivializing superpowers. Some are very similar to each other, such as two weapons of the same class with similar movesets that have wildly different performance. Most are not at all similar, making the experience when switching from one to the next completely different. Despite this, one could make an argument that the difficulty in the game rises from which strategies the player chooses. The most polarizing optional mechanic is Summoning. This changes the game from single player to Co-Op vs AI, or Co-Op and AI vs AI. Using this, a player can use NPC assistants to make enemies ignore the player, or simply ask a friend to beat the game for them while they watch. The extreme nature of this mechanic has caused heated debate in online communities as to what extent an optional mechanic can be used to manage difficulty before it simply becomes thinly veiled cheating. What is Cheating? Cheating in most games is simply breaking the rules to your benefit. In the context of early video games, cheating was specifically programmed into games using "cheat codes" that would allow players to break the rules. Later, specialized pieces of hardware such as Action Replay were introduced that are akin to modern hex editors, allowing players to cheat by changing any variable they could find, far beyond what developers willingly included in their games. All of these were widely agreed to be forms of cheating. And yet, the definition of cheating became more flexible as time passed, even though little changed in what players were capable of. In Super Mario games, there exist powerups that grant the player complete invincibility combined with another powerup that only appear when a player has died in a level multiple times. These are essentially easily accessible god modes that can be used to skip content that is too difficult or boring to play normally, or for any other reason the players see fit. There is no code that needs to be input. There is no need to go out of one's way to obtain these powerups. They aren't even labeled as cheats. They are even included with explicit intent to be used by a portion of the player base—while many cheats in the past were added just for the sake of having cheats (such as with Big Head Mode) or as rewards for completing the game. And yet, despite the lack of labeling, there is a subtle acknowledgement that using these is different than beating the game "normally." Achievements and collectibles will look different, scores may be altered, and the game otherwise records your use of these items to give your completion of the game an asterisk. The difference between invincibility powerups and other cheats is that invincibility powerups are deliberate additions intended to help players of lower skill or patience complete the game. They are easy, low-effort inclusions that sacrifice a portion of the gameplay for an easier experience, which would sour the experience for players that do not need them. They are still, however, cheats. They break the rules to your benefit. In Skyrim (PC), the player can, at any time, open the console to manipulate the game via console commands. This is more akin to classic cheat codes, where no player would be able to guess what they need to type into the console to cause a specific effect without looking up the codes, but is closer to the power of hex editors in terms of possibilities. Skyrim's console blurs the concept of cheating far more than a handicap feature would. Unlike other cheat codes, the use of the console is far more common even among players that do not like cheats for one reason: Skyrim does not function as a game. Did the player get stuck in random map geometry? The console allows them to teleport out. Did a quest break? The console can skip to the next step. Did the game crash? The console can be used to restore progress without needing to replay content. By definition, these are all instances of cheating, yet many would decline to call it such. Cheating has a harsh connotation that someone is cheapening an experience by breaking the rules, and yet this time the cheats are used specifically to improve the experience of a broken game—and arguably play closer to the rules as intended. Developer Intentions How do you know what a developer's intentions are? Intuition is a helpful tool, but it is also often wrong. Unless someone spoke their intentions, there cannot be certainty... But we can still make reasonably educated guesses. In Elden Ring, a common argument in favor of using anything the game offers is that, if it's in the game, it's intended to be used. The developers wouldn't have added it if they didn't intend for players to use it. This is obviously a baseless assertion, and there are plenty of examples where this intuitive reasoning falls short. Soon after the game's release, there were debates as to whether or not weapons such as Rivers of Blood and summons such as Mimic Tear were so powerful as to be unintended, or even be considered cheating. Players that defended these inclusions used the above argument, only to later find that both of these (and some underlying systems that improved them) were patched to reduce their effectiveness. Which one was truly the intended way of playing the game? Was it before or after the developers changed it? What else will the developers change? Can developers change their intentions? Some players that use this argument will make exceptions. For example, some enemies can be coerced into falling off of the map to their deaths, or get stuck such that they are easy targets. These will be exception cases, because their intuition tells them that the developers did not intend for enemies to simply fall off of the map and die on their own. And yet, despite the developers being able to modify the game however they wish, patches keep going by where these supposedly unintended inclusions remain untouched. When observing the design of the game, it is reasonable to try and guess developer intentions based on conflicting design principles and a charitable interpretation of the intelligence of whoever made it, even without the say of the developers. If in the vast majority of cases a condition is true, except for one specific case where there does not seem to be any reason for the deviation, an argument can be made that the aberration is not intended. For example, in Elden Ring, there are almost always methods to avoid an instance of damage as a player of reasonable reaction time and positioning. Enemy attack patterns will place the attacks in such a way that that is always the case for their target. However, if there are multiple enemies, an attack may be placed in such a way that it is avoidable for the primary target, but not for any others nearby. This can be considered an unintentional side effect of the optional mechanic of multiplayer. In Minecraft (Java Edition), players frequently modify the game using third party programs to drastically alter the gaming experience in ways far outside of the scope of the original game. It would be reasonable to assume that the intentions of the developer do not take into account anything a player may find in the landscape of unofficial changes to the game. Some of these modifications may be considered cheating, while most are considered changing the game entirely such that it is no longer "truly" Minecraft. However, there are modifications to the game whose only purpose is to improve the performance of the game, allowing more players the ability to play the game at all. Some modifications fix behaviors and perceived oversights to make the game more consistent. Are these third party changes bringing the experience closer to what was intended? The Minecraft speed-running community certainly thinks that some do. Performance-boosting modifications that do not change the basic rules of the game are allowed and encouraged. It's intuitive that the game running better rather than worse is the intention of the developers. Being able to reset the game more quickly or load faster are generally accepted to not be considered in the realm of cheating due to not affecting the integrity of the performance of the player during their speed-run. There it is—Integrity. Integrity There is a sort of principled superiority that cheating is playing the game "wrong," and that accomplishments that were only acquired via cheating are illegitimate. This intuitive understanding is highly attractive, as speaking with someone who claims the same accomplishments as yourself while having a different experience reaching that goal will inevitably cause a disconnect. It can invoke feelings of mockery, as if your efforts are being undermined and cheapened by someone with a GameShark. Cheaters that are perceived to lack integrity are seen as dishonest and insincere. It is no surprise that people will be on the lookout for any examples of something that can be seen as cheating. Whenever there are perceived rules and the perceived breaking of said rules, there will be conflict among players. Developers should keep this aspect of human nature in mind when designing their game, especially if they do not put any effort into explaining their intentions to the players. Players are less inclined to fuss about cheating and accomplishments when difficulty and handicaps are properly communicated to them. When numeric and complexity difficulties are clearly labeled "Easy," "Medium," and "Hard" with descriptions of their effects, and opt-in mechanics are properly balanced or labeled as handicaps, players are more likely to be able to have civil discussions about the game's design. At the end of the day, the purpose of games is to have fun. Players will act in accordance with what they find most enjoyable (and accessible), and they will associate with other players that have similar values to their own. Players are also not expected to have the emotional intelligence or logic capacity to put together well-reasoned and compassionate arguments to connect with others that do not think like them. They are expected to complain, pick sides, and attack anyone with opposing views, needlessly causing divides that the developers could have easily avoided. Analyzing Examples of Poor Difficulty Implementation and Arguments Elden Ring is a gold mine of thoughtless arguments and assumptions from players due to the vague and often half-baked implementation of its core difficulty management mechanics. For this, we will be focusing on the debate around the users of summons against solo/difficulty purists, as both sides suffer from astounding levels of shortsightedness on the subject. Let's start with solo purists that claim that anyone that used summons did not truly "beat the game" and that they "played the game wrong." There are legitimate arguments to be made about the poor implementation and incredible variance in effectiveness from the use of summons. Truly, they can be akin to using a Super Leaf in Mario games to skip entire areas and bosses from the sheer power that having another player or ally in a fight can bring. The way enemies do not take into account the presence of additional enemies for their choice of actions reveals a lack of polish or worse. In some cases, enemy AI will simply cease to function when a creature is defeated, or their movements and bodies will become unnatural as they change targets mid-attack, resulting in deceptive and jarring visuals that do not appear as intended behavior. However, there is no reason to attack others for choices made for the purposes of entertainment in what may as well be a single-player game. Without the developers defining what it means to beat the game, like in Mario, the player's assertions are baseless. As the player progresses further into the game, many of the enemies have identical gameplay with only minor cosmetic differences—and enormously increased statistics. It is not uncommon for a player to fight a generic soldier with a sword and trade hits to defeat them in one blow, only to find the exact same enemy wearing a different color shirt that can kill the player in a single blow. It is entirely possible for a player to simply not have enough ammunition to defeat even a single enemy from differences in numeric difficulty, resulting in certain playstyles being invalidated via arithmetic impossibility. What would normally be a method of difficulty control instead becomes a burden for the player to level up their character to unreasonable strength, skewing the experience unnecessarily because of arbitrary restrictions from the developers. Furthermore, the action of increasing one's level has no relation to the core gameplay experience or player skill. If a player wishes to improve their numerical abilities until winning is possible, they will most likely resort to repeatedly resting at a save point and attacking defenseless enemies for an arbitrary amount of time until they have enough points to do so. There is no option to use skill to increase one's ability to deal damage when the resources used to do so are limited - if you have ten shots, and the enemy can survive eleven, no amount of skill will help you win. The increase in "difficulty" using numbers serves no purpose except to waste hours of a player's time when players opt for weaker strategies. Strategies and weapons that are stronger or weaker are often touted as the game's main way of adjusting difficulty. In many cases, these are legitimate, non-invasive methods that do not significantly alter the core gameplay experience. If a player likes a specific kind of weapon or spell, chances are there are alternatives that function similarly enough while being substantially more or less effective. It's always easier to reduce effectiveness, as a player can choose not to upgrade a weapon, but it is not always possible to increase the strength of a playstyle past a certain point. That is the point at which this method of difficulty implementation fails. It is a common argument among users of summons that anyone that complains about numeric difficulty while refusing to use opt-in playstyles is trapped in a cage of their own making. This view isn't just false, it's patronizing and misses the valid portion of the purist argument. Summoning, for example, changes the core experience of the game to such a degree that it can and will lead to questions of integrity and legitimacy in a run. Even inexperienced players identify that someone or something else defeating enemies for them "feels" like it made their own contributions irrelevant (because it did). That all tools the game offers are equally valid means of managing difficulty is an equivocation. To insist others use them in the same way they would an "enemy health and damage multiplier" lacks nuance and borders on dishonesty. To the purists, telling them to "just summon" is no different than telling them to "just play Tetris instead," "just use the Super Leaf," or "have you considered handing the controller to your big brother?" since, to them, it is either an alternative game experience that doesn't interest them, or actively cheapens the experience of the game akin to cheating, even if the developers did not say such. To them, the game simply lacks the means to make their chosen way of playing the right difficulty, and their way of playing the game for entertainment is just as valid as the summoners. This problem also exists in reverse. For example, what if someone wants to play with their friends, but does not want to make the game too easy? There are numeric ways to make yourself weaker, but the core experience is warped. No amount of self-restriction will make up for the fact that enemies in the game are not designed to act differently in the presence of multiple opponents. There is one last drawback of opt-in mechanics as difficulty, especially in Elden Ring: Not all mechanics are even available from the start. If you want to play the game from start to finish with Godfrey's Axe, you are required to either arrange for another player to drop the item for you, or you need to cheat. That's right: there are playstyles that are not even accessible. The game does not have a reasonable method to enjoy items granted only after beating the game. This is not even for balance reasons either, as items like Fire Giant's braid and Godfrey's Axe are incredibly weak weapons compared to similar ones obtainable earlier in the game. Limited items exist that never respawn or force players to waste time collecting rare resources, which needlessly punishes inexperienced or challenge run players that are more likely to fail when using them. Given everything discussed, using cheats for the purposes of enabling the game to be played in a specific way that does not affect the integrity of the core gameplay is something that should be reasonable to most. The issue is not cheating, it's integrity. There should always be methods of controlling difficulty within a given set of rules while respecting those rules, self-imposed or otherwise. If the developers fail to do so, it is perfectly within reason for players to point it out.

entries.title: Math and Worldbuilding
entries.content: The Neglect of Mathematics and Game Balance in Tabletop Roleplaying Games Preamble In all forms of interactive storytelling where numbers are involved, the narratives and imaginations of those involved are grounded in and informed by the underlying mathematics and mechanics. Just like in the real world, math is the basis on which everything exists - change one variable, and the world and the cultures within will look much different. Despite this foundational importance, the math in TTRPGs is often neglected or not taken into consideration during its creation, causing the stories built on it to lack plausibility or the players to engage in degenerate gameplay loops that are better incentivized by the math. We must elevate the standards of game balance and mathematical principles within to ensure a stable play environment with maximal freedom of storytelling. For the purpose of this discussion, I'll mostly be referring to the design of Dungeons and Dragons, but these principles extend to all games, TTRPG or otherwise. The Value of Balance and Mathematics 1. The Foundation of the Universe Here in the real world, our actions are most often decided by their expected outcomes. People grow the food that produces the most in the local terrain, they wear protection to avoid death, they take the path of least resistance, they outlaw actions that harm others. If the outcomes or goals were different, the actions taken would be different - if stabbing someone was a pleasant experience that extended their lifespan, then the laws around stabbing people would be very different. If we only ate for pleasure, we would grow what tasted the best regardless of climate. This is true down to the very foundations of the universe, where the actions that the atoms and forces of the universe take are decided by simple rules. Light takes the path of least time, mass and energy act towards increased entropy, and other such rules determine how everything else acts. Just like in real life, expected outcomes are what guide us in TTRPGs. If the goal of the player is to live the longest and kill the most things, then the actions they take will be guided by what best gets them to that goal. Because this is based on probability, it becomes a question of simple math to determine the best course of action at a given moment. All else the same, the weapon that does the most damage should be what everybody in the world defaults to. All else the same, the strategy that prevents the most damage taken is the best. Math IS worldbuilding. 2. The Foundation of Game Design In real life, we can't fight against monsters and men-at-arms with shuriken and our bare fists. Reality dictates that those actions would likely result in our demise. However, in a game, we often find ourselves roleplaying something that isn't exactly realistic - such as a magician slinging fireballs at ogres. If we want to allow the full range of themes to be represented in a game, we need all of them to be on a fair playing field. There is no purpose to allowing "Unarmed Strike" as an action that accomplishes nothing and gets you killed, after all - but we decide the rules of this universe. We can make "Unarmed Strike" deal substantial damage, or have additional benefits that make their use reasonable. By setting the rules properly, what is feasible changes to match our desires. Whether what you desire is a good thing is a discussion for another day - let's focus on the hows. What players do is a combination of what they desire, and what the game rewards. Developers should set the rules to reward what they want to happen, and not reward what they don't. Ideally, the incentives should match what the players want to do. 3. The Foundations of Fairness and Creativity The incentive structure of a game like DnD usually comes in the form of power. More money and experience means bigger and more magical swords and fireballs, or more hirelings, etcetera. When you want a fair game for players to enjoy various themes and strategies, you must balance the power such that there is not a single overwhelmingly dominant strategy that is easily recognized by players. This is only fair; if you have multiple players, and one is given obviously inferior power, they may experience frustration or disengagement when they notice their impact on the game is insubstantial as a result. Fairness in a system of mathematics is fundamentally a question of mathematics. When the underlying math is neglected, and the rest of the game is built despite it, you will quickly find oddities. If you make "Unarmed Strike" deal 1 damage, and "Longsword" deal between 1 and 8, you should not be surprised when nobody will opt for "Unarmed Strike" under any circumstances. If there is a dominant strategy, and yet you still declare that most of the people in this world fight with fists instead of swords (all else equal), your world becomes less believable. From the math, the rest of the world-building should come naturally and without significant leaps of logic - If you declare something exists in this world, there should be a basis for it, and this basis almost always comes from the math. Balanced systems inherently foster deeper engagement. Players are more likely to invest their time into the mechanics of a game when they believe they will not be held back by deviating from superior strategies. By employing mathematical approaches to skill scaling, damage output, resource allocation, and character progression, players are free to choose options based on thematics, creativity, and their own desires without worrying about doing the math on behalf of the developers to make sure they are being dealt a fair hand. Everything I've stated so far may seem obvious, and even patronizing, but the reality is that most developers do not take this into consideration as much as they should. 4. The Willy Wonka World of DnD I'll spare you the fine details and skip to the important math to keep in mind. In DnD, there are listed weapons that are assumed to be available from character creation. If we consider the world in which this takes place, it would be fair to assume that the people in the world would also want to survive encounters when selecting their weaponry, and those weapons are boiled down to sets of numbers and tags to describe them. The most important number to a commoner with no bonuses to anything is the damage number - in a fight, the odds to succeed are highest by simply using the weapon with the highest damage. And yet, a dagger deals 2.5 damage, while a stick deals 3.5. If they use a very big stick, they can even reach 4.5, if they don't mind using both hands. If they spend some more money and actions, they can use two axes for a whopping 7 damage, and this is only with "simple" weapons they may be proficient in. The simple conclusion here is that, all else equal, a commoner's preferred weapon should be a stick, or two axes if they have money to spare. The stick is the most versatile, cheap, and powerful weapon available to them. Even if you take into account the bonuses from stats, a commoner would need maximum dexterity to consider a dagger, even compared to weapons they are not proficient in. In this world, using a dagger is mathematically inferior to every other option for any regular, non-player character. This results in a silly world that only suits the players, without taking into account the rest of the creatures. Why would a knife be a substantially worse weapon than a stick? A goat that attacks a human is likely to kill them in a single attack. How long would a farmer last in such a world? Some classes and builds can easily survive far longer and deal multiple times as much damage as others, often while being better at non-combat activities as well. Why would anyone willingly choose to be the inferior class if the objective is to survive? The expected earnings of a player far outpace the earnings of commoners, as untrained labor is only enough to pay for a gallon of ale or a stay at a poor inn while a single piece of basic equipment can be worth a hundred times as much. Is it really acceptable to put the price on a day of deadly work (such as a mercenary) equal to the price of a dagger, one of the worst items in the game, such that a player could hire dozens of them for every adventure? How long can you ride on a player's goodwill and desire for thematics and roleplay before these poor worldbuilding decisions start to interfere with their fantasy? The Defense of Flawed Mathematics One of the most insidious phenomena in the world of TTRPGs is the tendency of players to defend poor mathematics and imbalanced mechanics, often born out of a fundamental misunderstanding or intentional ignorance of underlying principles. This defense frequently stems from a place of trust in the developers and an emotional attachment to the game itself, leading players to uphold the perceived authority of the creators. 1. Trust in Authority "If they wanted it that way, they would have made it that way!" "You think they didn't think of that? They clearly left it like that for a reason." "Why don't you do better, then?" When players encounter a system that is hailed as "official," there is a natural inclination to assume that the developers have meticulously crafted every detail, and thus, their choices are unquestionable. Players may erroneously believe that since the developers designed the game, they must have considered every possible variable and outcome, rendering any criticism unwarranted. Players may also propagate the myth of developer infallibility, asserting that they are privy to unique insights that justify design decisions. Such attitudes not only inhibit constructive discourse, but they also diminish the validity of collective player experiences and insights, as an entire community’s lived experiences may be rendered irrelevant in the face of perceived expertise. The belief that there "can’t be a better way" is a common claim that started among video game developers, such as at Riot Games and Nexon, as they frequently cite data they claim exists to justify their actions while refusing to release said data to prove it. The truth is that no such data exists, and modern gaming communities can easily get access to or create superior data from which to make decisions. When confronted with suggestions for rebalance, players often leap to the defense of their cherished mechanics, positing that the developers "must have had a reason" for their choices. This blind and aggressive defense of the systems further perpetuates the cycle of flawed designs, as those advocating for improvement or merely offering their observations are dismissed as "Powergamers," or told that they're just not focusing on what matters, and that roleplay trumps game design. Because the foundation of these defenses is inherently fallacious, they almost always lead to a statement that reveals their lack of engagement with the topic. The most common ones include that the game is made to be changed from table to table, that the suggestions are merely opinions and do not represent the needs of the community, that the opinions of those that are not part of successful gaming companies are inherently worthless, and basic attacks on the character of those criticizing the game (rather than focusing on the criticisms themselves). 2. Ignorance of Mathematical Foundations Most players lack the mathematical literacy necessary to fully grasp the implications of game mechanics at a detailed level. Consequently, when flaws in balance emerge—be they overpowered abilities, inefficient resource distribution, or underwhelming options—players may misinterpret these issues as subjective preferences rather than objective mathematical failings. The most common misinterpretation of the math is that of percentage reductions: Most players do not know that reducing an effect by 100% is far more than twice as good as reducing it by 50%. A common way this ignorance appears is in video games such as League of Legends, Minecraft, and Skyrim, where players will honestly believe that combining a reduction of 50% with another 50% and getting a result of 75% is somehow a "diminished" effect because the total did not reach 100%, when in reality the result is a multiplicative, mathematically accurate, and fair way to represent the effect. Combined with the aforementioned bias towards that which is "official," a majority of the population will convince themselves that their intuitive (incorrect) understanding of the underlying mathematics is also aligned with what the developers think - and, unfortunately, they may be correct. 3. Ignorance of the Developers The methods used by the developers of DnD to create the game and the underlying math is transparently dubious. By their own (unwitting) admission, the top-down approaches used by them with a lack of emphasis on mechanics and math, insufficient player testing, and dismissal of community feedback has led to books full of wondrous descriptions of a game that does not accurately match their vision in practice. The examples of such are too numerous to list, but to bring up simultaneous examples that perfectly encapsulate the sheer nescience of the lead developers of DnD, we can look at the playtests of DnD 5.5. During the playtests, the developers made a particularly bizarre public video about the results, falsely claiming that a mechanic that players did not interact with was "mathematically one of the most powerful" when it was the worst on average, dismissing feedback because player scores on individual features were higher than the overall score, and even incorrectly referencing their own changes to their own content. What truly happened behind the scenes to cause such a public statement to be made without any proofreading is unclear. It's up to a given individual to review these actions to decide whether it's negligence, ignorance, or deliberate equivocation. I try taking the most charitable approach by assigning ignorance to what could have just as easily been malice. From Math, All Is Born Game developers must adopt a mathematical mindset in their approach. This includes rigorous playtesting with statistical analyses, iterative balancing, and a commitment to utilizing clear metrics for evaluating the effectiveness and fairness of mechanics while maintaining consistency and logic. Checking published content for faults should not be the burden of the players, especially when the product is advertised as being beginner-friendly. Disparities that can be encountered within a new player's first turn should not be tolerated, let alone upheld as intended design. Players should be involved in the balancing process, and even perceived faults in criticism should be thoroughly investigated to identify the underlying reasons for the criticisms being put forth. When a community is particularly large, there's a high likelihood that there will be individuals that practically design the game in its entirety in their criticisms. To dismiss them is the peak of hubris. When a game's fundamentals and mathematical foundations are made airtight, the content built on them will likewise be untouchable. Under ideal circumstances, even inexperienced players should be able to expand on the content in the game with little worry of diminishing the balance. I hope to one day live in a world where criticisms of game balance and mathematics are truly in the realm of the nitpicking and biased, and that all game discussion becomes that of themes and abstractions.

entries.title: Random YouTube Comment
entries.content: "As someone who comes from D&D, another very customiseable game, the "just fix it yourself" mentality is so pervasive even though the whole reason we use a tabletop RPG SYSTEM is that it should minimise how much actual game design non-game designers (i.e. players) should be doing. The best example of people being forced into the "game designer" position (who really shouldn't have been) is this well known issue that it wasn't worth casting healing spells in combat because they healed so little compared to incoming damage. Healers, who also have potent offensive magic, would just let people get to zero HP, then resuscitate them right before their turn with the weakest, lowest commitment healing spell so they both at least get to do some damage before the injured person goes down from the next thing that breathes on them. This was called "yo-yo healing" because combat would become a whack-a-mole game of people going down, then up and down again. For some reason, it became really popular to punish going unconscious with debuffs. This is like seeing smoke and trying to fan it away while making the fire underneath worse. Great, now the situation you don't really have the tools to avoid now punishes you further. With such a terrible "fix" being so popular, clearly being a game designer isn't an easy, "anyone can do it" job. It takes years of experience to get good at it. Most people were unable to identify the root cause of "yo-yo healing", which was eventually correctly addressed as low healing output 10 years later by the actual game designers when they buffed healing magic. That being said, the average player, and even modder, likely isn't that great at even identifying WHY something is a problem or why something is causing them to have less fun. After I started playing with KeepInventory, I started feeling dissatisfied after a while of using death as a way to just get back to my spawn. I couldn't just eject the "forbidden knowledge" from my head. What I eventually realised is that I DID want death to have some kind of punishment, I just didn't want it to cause "oh my god, I'm going to lose hours of progress!" kind of panic. The real solution ended up being installing a gravestone mod so I still had to collect my death loot." @floofzykitty5072 May 2025

| ------------------------------------------------ | | Elven Sight | Gain Eagle Eye as an Innate Technique. | | Elven Accuracy | +1 ACC Ranged weapons gain +10/20 range. | | Ageless Patience | You can Take 15 instead of Take 10. | | Alternate Minor Features | | | ------------------------ | ----------------- | | Nice Ears | +2 Perception | | Lore | | | ----------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | | Size and Age | Elves are typically around 5' tall and 100 Lbs. They age about the same rate as humans do, but once they grow to size, they do not die of old age, nor do they get any health complications from old age. | | Appearance and Biology | Elves are lithe androgynous humanoids with long pointed ears as their most telling feature. In their youth, elves possess an eerie beauty, appearing as idealized and flawless beings in the eyes of humans. Most are light-skinned with green eyes, but they come in a variety of shades and hues that reflect the environments in which they were born.They become adults at about the same speed as humans, but when they grow older, they physically change based on things like their environment or their magical affinity instead of becoming wrinkled and feeble. Forest hermits might start growing leaves and branches, stag horns or feathers. A wizard that specializes in Cryomancy might turn a light shade of blue and grow cold to the touch. Changing in physical properties like these typically happen over the course of many years.Elves do not reproduce often due to a combination of low fertility, low libido, and cultural pressures due to their lifespan. Most elves can only conceive in the presence of natural magic, such as during celestial events or in blessed springs. Because of this, they are quite a rare sight outside of their settlements. | | Ageless | Elves are unique among humanoids due to their endless youth. They develop a very different perception of time and the world at large. While a generation of humans might pass every 20 years or so, a generation of elves often lasts over a century. As such, they have a unique perspective on the rise and fall of empires, world level crises, and the passage of time in general. Elves possess a unique form of wisdom that can either be used to aid other races, or cause them to become jaded as they see the same pattern of self destruction emerge multiple times amongst the humanoid societies they observe.Long life isn't all sunshine and rainbows. Elves can often develop a superiority complex, considering they are usually the smartest or wisest person in any given room. Yearly celebrations such as birthdays are largely ignored. Elves making friends with non elves is a rarity, since they won't stick around long enough to matter anyway. Elves can often seem apathetic towards the plights of other humanoids, but their reactions have merely been tempered by experience. Many will hide for the rest of eternity, minimizing the risks to their health until they feel there is something important enough to emerge for.Because elven society moves much more slowly than other humanoids, many of their practices can seem archaic, time-consuming and inconvenient. They are often purposefully designed to be so in order to make them take more time and be more inconvenient to replicate for other races. "See you again soon" takes on an entirely different meaning as the elf's perception of time is likely wildly different than what most non-elven creatures think. They tend to be much more conservative than others, adhering to ancient traditions and worshiping less popular or older deities. Everybody is a kid at some point, so they understand what it was like to some degree: What it is like to feel wonder in a world filled with the unknown. At some point people grow and the wonder and discovery of childhood is filled with responsibility and routine of adulthood. Elves eventually come to exist on some 3rd plateau of existence where they have eaten every food, vacationed in every country, saved the world, started a family, lost people they loved, turned to the dark side and were eventually redeemed and all the rest. Once you experience so much of what the world has to offer, once you have given so much of yourself to the world only to be forgotten, what is the meaning of your continued existence? | | Obsession | The aforementioned appearance changes are merely an outward representation of decades, maybe even centuries of obsession, and their effects on the individual's soul. When traditional methods of acquiring meaning in one's life fail, elves have all the time in the world to dedicate to their projects. Spiteful elves may eventually have their conscious eroded to the point where the short-lived races are viewed as mice in their experiments, and are transformed into monsters. They might develop an entirely selfless desire to protect the natural world and view most any inhabitants that exploit it as a virus to be cured by any means necessary. Maybe at a young age they are exposed to a great evil and tirelessly work to exterminate it, and snuff out any reemergence for as long as they live.Turning people into monsters is abhorrent, and hunting demons is noble. Protecting nature is a lofty ideal, but usually most humanoids are only willing to go as far is needed to maintain their way of life: Appeasing the spirits for safety, enriching the soil for crops etc. So a single-minded dedication to nature could easily cause conflict once one too many trees are cut. These exceptionally long-lived elves that develop obsessions don't necessarily cause conflict, but depending on their obsession, they very easily could. Entire elven societies form around these obsessions, for better or worse. | | The Princess Adventurer | Age causes the perception of elves to warp as they gain life experience, but elves in their youth have no such experience. Young elves are rebellious towards elven traditions in the same way children of other races are to their parents, as the reality of their immortality takes decades to set in. Young elves (usually between ages 20 and 100) are often hard to distinguish from humans in terms of personality archetypes. They are usually more reserved, but are otherwise capable of taking risks that older elves learn to avoid. They are the most likely to travel the world and engage in dangerous adventures. This is where the visage of the stereotypical elf comes from: stories of fair elven princesses leaving their homes to see the world, still retaining that eerie beauty of their youth while being the oldest among their peers.As they age, and the reality of their immortality sets in, young elves often regret the decisions they took in their rebellious years. Other races enjoy their lives while they have it, taking risks and making dumb decisions to make the best of it. Elves, on the other hand, will live long enough to regret their tattoos, their scars, and the enemies they made. "Permanent" means something very different to someone that will have to deal with the consequences of their actions for the next thousand years. |

This allows for a unique approach to life, where offspring are kept in the presence of the Usa and treated as a single person until the parent dies. They often have additional luxurious fur on their necks and extremities, and dense voluminous hair. Usa look almost identical to their parents without fail, making lineage easy to identify.Almost all Usa are female or hermaphrodites with extreme fertility. Their ability to multiply is their main method of survival, and doing so comes as easily as breathing to them. This is paired with an innate aloof disposition and lack of self preservation. They often have so many offspring that they don't care to keep track of them, and the fear of death has less value to their survival than the desire to breed. | | Pest Control | Ancient Usa ancestors survived by minimizing their impact on their environments, hiding, and ensuring their children would live to see another day when the Links were being hunted to extinction.The most successful among them were the smallest, fastest, and most efficient kin. Hiding turned into predator satiation, and protecting children turned into sacrifice for the good of the group. After enough time, the Usa simply accepted that they were hunted for sport, and stopped worrying about minimizing their footprints. They unapologetically swarmed resources, knowing full well it made them easy to find.In modern times, Usa Half-Links are often still mercilessly hunted, as their overwhelming numbers can cause serious problems when their leadership figures don't have conservation on the mind. At the same time, this continued aggression from other races radicalizes the larger Usa clans, and retaliatory Usa uprisings have been known to tear countries apart in short-term conflicts. This cycle of lifestyle and violence is an inevitable fact for most Usa. |
