If they fail, they hesitate and cannot complete their turn. Undead and Fiends gain a +10 bonus to this. | | Lore | | | --------------------------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Size and Age | Half-Links are incredibly diverse. However, most lineages have a maximum size of around 4', and weigh around 70 lbs. The most short-lived lineages grow incredibly rapidly until they reach maturity at 1, and then live until 20, or 35 with good health. The longer lifespans tend to reach maturity at 15, and then live until 100. | | Appearance and Biology | Many Half-Links have a gradient of form, ranging from mostly-animal or even completely feral to humanoids with minor aesthetics (such as ears and tail) or indistinguishable from other humanoids. However, many others have no control over their appearance, and are stuck in a middle ground between a particular humanoid race (usually human or elf) and their animal ancestry. Half-Links tend to be druids, barbarians, and other wild peoples as a consequence of their pasts, so most that are not integrated into civilization will wear pelts and plant matter, if anything at all. Half-Links that are integrated into society will tend to wear whatever culture they are closest to within that society to fit in. Half-Links tend to appear small, almost childlike in their youthful appearances, and tend towards being incredibly athletic and muscular in build. As they age, their humanoid parts still tend to remain young, but their animal aspects will wither and grey. | | Origins | The Half-Links originated from animals in the distant past. They were subject to an obscure, primordial phenomenon known as Primal Sentience. This rare occurrence grants random animals a spark of consciousness, later culminating in a high degree of intelligence and understanding of the world equal to a human, as well as physical abilities far beyond any other of their species.These creatures were initially viewed as malevolent entities, tricksters and puppet-things of spellcasters and demons through which harm was inflicted on crops and societies. These beliefs were founded on real events, as many of them appeared from the wilderness and preyed on livestock and children, or mimicked common speech to scare away or, rarely, converse with strangers that wandered into their territory.As time passed and understanding of these beings grew, powerful druidic circles took it upon themselves to cultivate their integration into society. They were able to seek and collect the rare animals and give them an opportunity to learn common speech, culture, and knowledge, and with that they were able to reach a level of proficiency in ability and magic similar to humanoid races. This was an incredible undertaking, requiring the hands of some of the most powerful individuals in the world, with the guidance of the gods above and below. The final step in their integration was a study of druidic magic. The same magic that allowed druids to shape change into animals was used by those magic animals to change into humanoids, giving them a nearly seamless transition into personhood as it was recognized by those around them. For a long time, their unique talents and perspectives put them at the forefront of magical research, entering civilization as part of the middle and upper class. They were then known as The Links. | | The Great Hunt and Devolution | While the Links changed culturally and physically as their descendants acclimated to living with the other races, the culture and tradition of the other races were far too slow to change. A backlash from those who still perceived the Links as abominations from deeply entrenched superstitions ultimately led to their widespread persecution. Entire crusades were established in opposition to their sudden rise to power, fueled by conspiracies built on folklore and disgust at the intermingling of Links and humanoids in an equal setting. In a blink of history, the Links and the druidic circles that helped them went from a well-established collection of powerful enclaves, to nothing. The relentless pursuit and slaughter of these individuals, generations of separation from their primal origins, enslavement, and the suppression of their innate magical abilities caused the total degeneration and extinction of the Links, resulting in the fragmented, diminished forms that exist today. Those who managed to evade this cataclysm were forced to isolate themselves, adopt human guise, or interbreed for survival, completing the final severing of ties with their ancestral heritage. Eventually, all that remained were the Half-Links; smaller, weaker, more mundane, and otherwise pathetic when compared to what they once were.The majority of modern Half-Links inherited but a fraction of their forebears' magical capacities, leading to the present-day diversity of tribes and the varied, often unstable, expression of their abilities. | | Tribal Lineages and Regional Variations | Fast-forward through now-ancient history, and specific Half-Link tribes have emerged, each with their own distinct characteristics, traditions, and magical inclinations. These tribes, often defined by their animalistic ancestry, reflect the divergent paths taken by various Half-Link ancestors. While some remain largely isolated, others have adapted to their environments and forged uneasy alliances with humanoid societies. To most, specific tribes of Half-Links are their own separate, unrelated race. Over time, many groups have carved out niches for themselves with the abilities they inherited, evolving into something completely unlike what their ancestors were. They created their own cultures and abilities in these offshoots, resulting in modern groups such as the Kitsune and Lamia. | | Never Again | Primal Sentience still exists. There are still occurrences of spontaneous intelligence in animals. However, the druidic magic, common ancestors, individuals, and even the gods that made the Links were lost to the extinction and time. While it's not impossible to recreate what was lost, nobody has attempted (or even had the means) to bring them back. |

entries.title: Dwarf
entries.content: The most relatable Race. | Traits | | | ---------- | -------- | | Language | Dwarven | | Size | Medium | | Type | Humanoid | | Major Features | | | -------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Stoneblooded | Gain Resistance to Necrotic. | | Wall | -5 Speed, +10 HP, Bonus Feats: Endurance and Toughness | | Minor Features | | | ---------------- | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Night Vision | You treat dim light as Bright Light. You treat darkness as Dim Light. | | Skepticism | +2 Insight | | Alternate Major Features | | | ------------------------ | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Racism | Choose a race of humanoids. You gain +2 to Accuracy, Avoidability, Potency, Skills, and Saves against them in combat. | | Stable | Reduce forced movement by 1 space. As an Immediate Action, reduce forced movement to 1 space. | | Stonecunning | Gain Blindsense 10 (Tremorsense) while standing on stone. At a glance, you can identify whether or not a stone is natural, modified, or worked. | | Alternate Minor Features | | | ------------------------ | -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Beard of Holding | You can store 1 item that you can hold in a single hand that weighs no more than 20 Lbs inside of your beard. | | Cavern Crawler | Climb at full speed. | | Flame Belch | As an Action-Attack, you can light and raise a flame to your mouth, then belch on an adjacent creature. They are set Ablaze (reflex negates). It takes another standard action of drinking an alcoholic beverage to recharge this ability. | | Salt Beard | As a Swift Action, coat a held weapon in your beard salt. Your next hit with it inflicts Taunted for one round (Fortitude negates). This ability recharges when you eat. | | Value Scent | You possess Blindsense (Scent, 5ft). It is only usable on detecting the value of objects. You are automatically able to discern the value of something with a quick sniff. Particularly valuable things such as rare magic items may have extremely powerful and wide scents as strongly scented creatures and objects normally would. | | Book of Grudges | You meticulously record all events that you perceive as negative in a government approved book. Slights against your character, betrayals, enemies, lies and the like are all written down in the book. By presenting this book in a suitable situation, such as incriminating someone, you get a +2 bonus to skill checks. | | Not Impressed | +2 to saves against Charm effects. | | Craftsman | +2 to skill checks while Crafting. | | Lore | | | ---------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | | Size and Age | Dwarves tend to be around 4' tall and weigh 150 . Dwarves reach adulthood by 20 and live to be around 150. | | Appearance and Biology | Dwarves are universally "male" (genderless, but typically masculine). Rather than reproducing through traditional means, they go mining to find more Dwarves. Dwarves are a naturally occurring resource just like iron, and can be harvested as such. They usually appear inside of stony egg-like structures with the texture of hair. These eggs naturally form as a result of Dwarvic Energy, which is created through the act of mining. Dwarf eggs can only form in unworked stone, making it necessary to go far out from home to find them. More Dwarvic Energy is generated when dwarves mine, and Dwarves have a more keen sense when it comes to finding Dwarf eggs, making it uncommon for other humanoids to discover them. There are a handful of ways to hatch a Dwarf egg. Some use specific solvents like a shampoo to soften the protective outer beard shell while others warm it up and comb at it. When hatched, Dwarflings start off a bit more developed then birthed humanoids. With roughly a year head start, they can already move around on their own, eat most foods and understand basic physics. Dwarves are easily identifiable from their wide frames, short statures and incredible beards. They typically have a higher density of muscles and hair than most other humanoids. They take exceptional care of their facial hair, prioritizing it over the hair on the top of their head. Dwarves hatch with beards, so it is very rare to see one without a beard. Average Dwarves tend to be wary of beardless Dwarves. | | Vibe Check | Because Dwarves have completely different biology when it comes to reproducing, their family structure doesn't follow that of creatures that give birth to their own young. Instead, Dwarflings stick with whoever mined them during their early years. By the time they are teenagers, they can get a feel for their immediate family and decide whether or not they are a good fit for them. As such, Dwarves form families (called Brotherhoods) similar to how most people find friend groups. Dwarves who don’t click with the family they were hatched into will readily leave to go find people that share their ideals and lifestyle more closely. Dwarves that are part of a brotherhood share the same name, but are willing to drop it when they change or they think the brotherhood 'aint what it used to be. Dwarves who don't vibe with the local brotherhoods have a tendency to wander around the overworld until they find a nice craftsman or adventuring party to latch onto. Dwarves innately have a strong ability to read people, making this somewhat naïve approach to finding family more viable. However, just because a Dwarf is traveling doesn't automatically mean they aren't part of a brotherhood. Sometimes it is necessary to do business with surface dwellers. | | Round Up the Lads | Because Dwarves do not have genders, they are a lot less sensitive to the kinds of dynamics having sexual dimorphism causes in humanoids. It can take a bit of getting used to not bathing or taking a leak in the presence of ladies. Dwarves tend to treat women of other races just like the men. This comes with a whole host of problems, but it also comes with a few positives. Men and women having a Dwarven friend are likely to be at ease with any talk of romance or its implications, knowing their companion has no personal interest in the subject.Dwarves tend to express masculine ideals much more frequently. They enjoy one-upping each other when it comes to tests of strength, and especially tests of endurance. A favorite is the drinking contest, which most Dwarves will handily win. Unfortunately for suitors, they are also aromantic, making such advances made against them bounce harmlessly off of them. | | Secrets of the Dwarves | Larger brotherhoods or groups willing to cooperate can sometimes get up to some…Interesting shenanigans when it comes to experimentation on Dwarflings. Nearly everything related to the topic is a closely guarded secret, known only by a handful of elders in the brotherhood. Rumor has it that the Dwarves will use some arcane mining methods in order to increase the chances of Dwarflings appearing inside of rare metals like gold. These oddities are usually substantially different from the standard Dwarf, taking on some of the properties of the metal they form from. Golden Dwarves, a favorite amongst the Dwarven elite, tend to be softer, thinner, and more magically talented. There are even some rumors of Dwarfling eggs being used as part of the forging process in order to create metallic Dwarves. If such things do exist and are not just fantasy stories told by bards looking to capture the interest of the common folk, then they have never seen the light of day. |

Despite their mundane hairless forms, their demeanors span across every extreme of the humanoid experience, their tales of conquest and glory reaching every corner of the world. The overwhelming strength of Human ambition causes them to be among the greatest heroes and most dastardly villains, the most talented craftsmen, the most passionate lovers, the richest, the most prideful, and every other extreme. |

entries.title: Race
entries.content: Races are a classification similar to creature type, mainly tailored towards players. They are the various sapient species and beings that inhabit the setting. When creating a character, players typically choose a race to determine their character's physical appearance, unique abilities, cultural background, and narrative possibilities. Most races have a racial language, but also know common. All creatures are assumed to have a base speed of 30ft, know Common, and be Medium in Size unless otherwise stated. The lore used to describe races is to differentiate a given race from the others. It also gives people a starting point if they don't know how to roleplay or world build with a specific race. The descriptions you find here (or in any source really) are tailored to a specific setting, or are the brain child of some other fantasy obsessed weirdo. They do not need to match how a specific race exists in your world if you have something else in mind. Race page format: | Component | Description | | ------------------ | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Traits | These usually cover some of the race basics, such as creature type and starting languages. Some races come with a specific feature baked in that can't be exchanged. You will know if a race has this when they only have 1 major or minor feature. | | Major Features | Default 2 per race. These are the heavy hitting features that generally aren't shared between races and have a major impact on gameplay. | | Minor Features | Default 2 per race. These are the heavy hitting features that generally aren't shared between races and have a major impact on gameplay. | | Alternate Features | Any features that pop up in major/minor alternate features can be exchanged with anything listed in their respective feature type (major replaces major, minor replaces minor). | | Lore | The shapes, sizes, ages, cultures, behavior, biology and origin of various races. Take what you like, scrap what you don't. The features of races are tailored to their themes, so deviating too far may be difficult. Do your best. |

entries.title: Acrobatics
entries.content: DEX-based Skill. Used for Balance, Tumble, and Wall Kick.

entries.title: Balance
entries.content: Acrobatics can be used to cross slippery surfaces, such as ice or oil slicks, at full speed. Failing the check gives you the Knocked Down condition. It can also be used to traverse or stand on incredibly small and unstable spaces, such as a cliff side or a fallen tree branch.

entries.title: Tumble
entries.content: If Trained in Acrobatics, you can avoid AoOs from moving through Threatened spaces. Acrobatics is rolled against all threatening creatures’ Reflex saves. The DC of their reflex save is equal to your Acrobatics Roll. If they succeed, your movement Provokes as normal.

entries.title: Wall Kick
entries.content: If Trained in Acrobatics, As long as there are 2 walls within 5 feet of each other, or a similar arrangement with some horizontal layout, you can continually hop between them to ascend or travel. Only the vertical OR horizontal distance you cover counts against your Movement, not both. This still takes a Jump action.

entries.title: Aquatic Combat
entries.content: Fighting underwater gives a -4 Circumstance penalty to AC, Reflex, and ACC. Being Trained in Athletics or possessing a Swim Speed removes the penalty.

entries.title: Athletics
entries.content: STR-based Skill, or DEX when appropriate. If you are Proficient in Athletics, you add STR to Jump in addition to DEX. Used for Climb, Swim, Brute Force, Catch Fall, and Aquatic Combat.

entries.title: Brute Force
entries.content: Using Athletics, you can use Brute Force when there are no lockpicks or beasts of burden to handle your problems. The DC to break apart an object is modified by its quality, materials, and size. Substantial failure may cause back problems. You can also use Athletics to represent bursts of strength that allow you to surpass your normal Carry Weight to shift large objects.

entries.title: Catch Fall
entries.content: When Proficient in Athletics, as an Immediate Action, you can attempt to grab onto something to stop your fall, or to prevent an ally within reach from falling. The DC to do this is 20+the height fallen before the catch. You do not take Fall Damage when successful.

entries.title: Climb
entries.content: Using Athletics, you can climb surfaces. Spaces you climb through are considered difficult terrain. With Athletics Proficiency, you climb at full Speed. If you have a Climb Speed, you get a +8 bonus and use that speed instead.

entries.title: Swim
entries.content: Using Athletics, you can swim through liquids. Spaces you swim through are considered difficult terrain. With Athletics Proficiency, you swim at full Speed. If you have a Swim Speed, you get a +8 bonus and use that speed instead.

entries.title: Create a Distraction
entries.content: Using Deception as a Standard Action, you can shout something at your enemies to briefly get them to look the other way so you can give them the slip. All creatures get a roll to try and beat yours. If you succeed, you are able to roll Stealth, and they won't know where you went. This does not prevent people from finding you again using Perception.

entries.title: Deception
entries.content: CHA-based Skill, normally rolled against Insight. Used to Lie, Disguise, Feint, Create a Distraction, Subtle Message, and Skills/Deception/Sucker Punch.

entries.title: Disguise
entries.content: Using Trained Deception, spend 10 minutes perfecting your makeup, outfit, and wig to appear as a person or playable race you're not. Disguise checks are usually unnecessary unless you fall under scrutiny, the person knows you/what you're pretending to be, or you're trying to enter an exclusive club, in which case they get a Perception check. Creatures get bonuses to their Perception if they know you or what you're disguised as particularly well. You take a -2 penalty to Disguise when you try to change your race and when you change your apparent gender. When you initiate a Disguise, you tell your DM your bonus, they apply any appropriate Circumstance modifiers and roll it in secret. Crafting a disguise without a disguise kit or magic imposes a -5 penalty.

entries.title: Lie
entries.content: Use Deception against a target's Insight to speak falsehoods, or to soften the truth. See Detect Dishonesty. It may be more entertaining if the DM rolls this in secret to preserve tension. Common modifiers to increase the DC include: - The target has firsthand experience with the events - Claims that are fantastical or impossible, such as equating angels with demons or asserting a green sky - The target is knowledgeable of the subject matter Common modifiers to make the task less difficult can include: - The target is inattentive, such as from being tired or drunk - The target trusts you

entries.title: Subtle Message
entries.content: By speaking in roundabout terms and making subtle gestures, you can use Trained Deception to communicate a simple idea (such as "we need to leave", or "time to strike") while not talking about it directly, to avoid alerting others of your intentions. The DC to convey this message is 20. The intended recipient automatically understands the message. Anyone that may be suspicious gets an Insight check to beat your Deception.

entries.title: Sucker Punch
entries.content: If you are in some kind of standoff where you aren't quite fighting your enemy yet, you can use Trained Deception or Trained Hands as a replacement for Stealth to Surprise your enemy with a melee Attack. The enemy must be aware of you in order to Sucker Punch, otherwise it is Stealth, and you must already be adjacent to use Hands for it. If you don't use an Unarmed Strike, then you have disadvantage on this check, unless you use Hands. Certain situations where you are not able to get close to your aggressors, such as having bows pointed at you from a garrison above you, make Sucker Punching impossible.

entries.title: Conceal Item
entries.content: Use Hands to conceal an item on your person. Should someone search you or otherwise have access to you to find such an item (such as if your clothes was lifted), you must roll Hands against their Perception to prevent them from discovering the item. Concealed items cannot be procured as a Free Action or Instant Action. You can use Trained Hands as a Swift Action to draw a concealed weapon. If you win the opposed check, the target is Surprised against your next attack. You can use this as an alternative to Stealth to Surprise an enemy when you are otherwise in a neutral position, and the opposing party is aware of you.

entries.title: Disable Device
entries.content: Use Hands to disable a trap or similar mechanism, magical or mundane, as long as it is armed and you have detected its presence. Failure triggers the trap. If you are Proficient in Hands, you can disable it temporarily or otherwise slightly modify the trap to better suit your needs.

entries.title: Hands
entries.content: DEX-based Skill. Used for Pickpocket, Conceal Item, Pick Lock, and Disable Device.

entries.title: Pick Lock
entries.content: Use Hands to open a lock without a key. This takes 1 or 5 rounds, depending on the DC of the lock - DC 30 and up is 5 rounds. Attempting this without a Thief Tools gives a -5 penalty.

entries.title: Pickpocket
entries.content: As a Standard Action, use Trained Hands on a distracted or Surprised creature to pilfer an object off of their person. This is opposed to the Perception of the target and any nearby creatures that can witness you. Failure indicates that the target noticed an unwanted intrusion on their person, and the theft fails. Items that are closely bound to the target cause a -5 penalty to Pickpocket. Items that are worn or held in the hands cannot be pickpocketed.

entries.title: Detect Compulsion
entries.content: Use Trained Insight to determine when a creature is under duress from a spell or some other kind of effect that has a lasting impact on their mind, such as when Dominated or Possessed. You must actively search for this by speaking with the creature for 1 minute. Roll Insight vs the DC of the effect. If the effect has no DC, assume a basic DC based on the Potency of the source.

entries.title: Detect Dishonesty
entries.content: Whenever a creature makes a statement, you can roll Insight (opposed by Deception) to see if what they say aligns with what they think. If you roll lower, or if they aren't being dishonest, you don't detect dishonesty. If you succeed, you determine that something is fishy - or if a statement lacks nuance (such as a yes or no response), you can determine the correct answer. Prying further about the deception may cause the creature to reveal the truth or become hostile depending on context. This can be combined with Deception against their Insight to hide whether or not they know you know they're being dishonest. When this is done, it may be more entertaining to have the DM roll in secret, and distribute results in secret, in order to preserve tension. You can only roll Insight on a particular assertion or topic once.

entries.title: Insight
entries.content: WIS-based Skill, but CHA can be used if it's a social cue. Used for Detect Dishonesty, Detect Compulsion, and Intuition.

entries.title: Intuition
entries.content: By using Trained Insight, you can observe a structure or item whose function is known, an event unfolding, or a behavior pattern to try and glean information about it. The DC is modified by how much knowledge you already possess on the topic, or how closely you're able to investigate it. A success gives you nearly prescient knowledge about the intention behind the structure, item, event, or behavioral pattern that goes beyond a basic understanding of function. For example, when used on a Trap whose function is to shoot an arrow, your character may determine that based on its unusual angle and obvious placement, it may have been used to deter adventures from finding a secret in its line of sight instead of to actually effectively trap them. The knowledge you glean from this success will always be the reality of the situation when you follow your intuition.

entries.title: Coercion
entries.content: With Trained Intimidation, by having a conversation with a creature that lasts at least one minute, or by defeating a creature in combat, you can shape how they respond to you or anybody asking about you in the future. The strength of this creature's conviction is dependent on your Intimidation Roll against it. You can make the creature keep their mouth shut about something you did to them. Any checks to gather information from this creature about you or your party change to your roll if it would be higher than the usual DC. You can greatly exaggerate what you did to further spread fear and grand tales of your strength. Any Knowledge checks that creatures make on you when hearing about information that spreads from this creature changes to your Intimidation roll if it would be higher than the usual DC, or else they learn false information.

entries.title: Demoralize
entries.content: As an Action-Attack, inflict Shaken 1 on an enemy that can see or hear you within 30 feet. Roll Intimidation versus their Will. They are Shaken as long as you are nearby, and for 1 minute after. You can Demoralize a creature repeatedly to increase the penalty. If they pass their save, their shaken value from Demoralize decreases by 1. If you are Trained, you can inflict Frightened instead on creatures you have Defeated before. This lasts one round, and can only be done once per day per creature. This doesn't work if they Defeated you once before as well.

entries.title: Intimidation
entries.content: CHA-based Skill, or optionally STR when using displays of might. Used for Coercion and Demoralize.

entries.title: Invocation
entries.content: INT- or LUK-based Skill. Used for Trigger Magic Device and Ritual.

entries.title: Ritual
entries.content: Rituals are complicated and time-consuming projects that use a large amount of materials and Mana to produce a powerful effect far beyond the strength of an individual spell. It is similar to Crafting.

entries.title: Trigger Magic Device
entries.content: Use Invocation to try and trigger the effects of a magical device without meeting the requirements for its use, such as bypassing a password, activating an item you're not qualified to use, or activating a sigil that only works in the presence of another type of creature. You have no control over the effect once it's active. Failing this check often comes with unforeseen consequences.

entries.title: Alchemy
entries.content: INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill. Allows the use of Monster Lore on Oozes. Used for Identify Potion, Identify Composition, and Craft alchemical items.

entries.title: Identify Composition
entries.content: Use Alchemy on an unknown substance to learn how to create it, if it has or can be created through Alchemy. The DC is the Craft DC+5.

entries.title: Identify Potion
entries.content: Use Alchemy to identify a held Use Potion or Poison with a sniff or taste. The DC is the item's Craft DC.

entries.title: Arcana
entries.content: INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill. Allows the use of Monster Lore on Monsters. Used for Identify Spell and Identify Magic Item.

entries.title: Identify Magic Item
entries.content: Use Arcana to identify all of the magic properties of a Magic Item in reach as a Standard Action. The DC is the item's Potency, +10 if it's cursed. This can be attempted once per day per item.

entries.title: Identify Spell
entries.content: By observing a Spell as it is being cast, you can Instantly use Arcana to identify which Spell it is. The DC is 5 per level of the Technique (not including Upcast.) This is useful for determining whether you want to take action in response, or it has no immediate effect - though many Spells do not need to be identified if you already know the spell. You may use Astronomy to identify Lunar spells, and Nature to identify Gaia spells.

entries.title: Astronomy
entries.content: INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill. Allows the use of Monster Lore on Abominations. Used for Navigation, Identify Spell, and Identify Cosmic Phenomenon.

entries.title: Identify Cosmic Phenomenon
entries.content: Using Astronomy with aid of devices such as telescopes (if necessary), you can determine the cause of cosmic phenomenon, or you can predict them in advance. This can be something like a solar eclipse, a comet, or something more drastic like a meteor or supernova. You can also tell if something unusual is happening, such as someone using illusions to improperly represent the night sky, or cast spells that produce effects similar to cosmic phenomenon.

entries.title: Navigation
entries.content: With a clear view of the night time sky, you can determine where you are and where you need to be. You can use Astronomy as an alternative to Survival for navigation in such circumstances. This skill replaces Survival during space travel.

entries.title: Engineering
entries.content: INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill. Allows the use of Monster Lore on Constructs. Used for Identify Function, Hack, and Identify Structural Quirk.

entries.title: Hack
entries.content: Using Engineering, where there exists technology, there exists a method to disable or gain control of it, even if only temporarily. Hacking always requires a hands-on approach.

entries.title: Identify Function
entries.content: Use Engineering to identify the purpose of particularly complex machinery. Depending on the size and scope of what you're looking at, this could only be a glance, or it could require a few minutes, and usually requires a hands-on approach.

entries.title: Identify Structural Quirk
entries.content: Large scale buildings such as castles, watchtowers, walls, factories, prisons etc. Are all built with specific purposes, facilities and defenses in mind. You can use Engineering to figure out aspects of these buildings, such as where exhaust/waste pipes lead, how far underground you might need to go to go underneath the structure, and even structural weaknesses.

entries.title: Humanities
entries.content: INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill. Allows the use of Monster Lore on Humanoids and Titans. Used for Recall Customs, Recognize Figure, and Recall Locale.

entries.title: Recall Customs
entries.content: Using Humanities, you can recall information about how to conduct yourself with foreign cultures. This can be particularly useful when trying to gain someone's favor, such as royalty. You can also recall information about holidays, festivals and ceremonies.

entries.title: Recall Locale
entries.content: Using Humanities, you can recall the answer to a specific simple question such as "where can I buy potions?" or "where does the royalty live?" or "where can I hire someone to build something?" These questions can be applied to the town you're in or with a higher DC, something much bigger like a country or continent.

entries.title: Recognize Figure
entries.content: Using Humanities, you can attach a name to a face, or vice versa. You generally understand aspects of a creature's reputation, their affiliations, and their general capabilities. Exceptionally high rolls might even land you some secrets or gossip related to this creature.

entries.title: Identify Natural Phenomenon
entries.content: Use Nature to identify natural processes like photosynthesis, the reproduction of creatures, and tectonic activity. You can do things like figuring out if a volcano is about to erupt, what could be causing plants to die, or how long until an egg hatches. You can also identify natural fauna, flora, and minerals, and their potential uses. When used to predict weather, you need to roll well to accurately predict more than a day ahead. You can also tell whether the weather is natural, or if it's being caused by magic.

entries.title: Nature
entries.content: INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill. Allows the use of Monster Lore on Plants, Fey, and Beasts. Used for Identify Natural Phenomenon and Identify Spell.

entries.title: Detect Portal
entries.content: Using Planes, you can detect, identify, and disable portals. Portals are strange phenomenon, but there are signs that they exist miles away from where the portal is actually located. If a portal is naturally occurring, you can use a DC 30 check to find its general area, or where it appears if it is not currently open. If it's manufactured, you can use a DC 20 check, or the caster's opposed Arcana, whichever is higher. In the presence of a portal, you can tell where its destination plane is. Rolling higher can give more specific locations, more details about the portals creation and how often it gets used. This starts at DC 10. Disabling a portal is a task that is very difficult by one's self. Failure could mean getting stuck on the wrong side of the portal, or hyper-charging the portal to attract extraplanar creatures. Using Planes is usually a short-term and rushed method. The DC starts at 30. Using a Ritual with Invocation and Arcana can make the process of disabling a portal more safe.

entries.title: Planes
entries.content: INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill. Allows the use of Monster Lore on Fiends, Celestials, and Elementals. Used for Detect Portal.

entries.title: Divine Lore
entries.content: Using Religion, you can identify a symbol (DC 10) tied to a person, object, or locale to determine its religious affiliation, as well as the tenets (DC 15) of a given religion and its chosen (DC 20) artifacts, people, and events of significance. You can also determine how to gain favor from a particular god (DC 15).

entries.title: Religion
entries.content: INT-based Trained Knowledge Skill. Allows the use of Monster Lore on Undead. Used for Divine Lore.

entries.title: History
entries.content: All Knowledge Skills can be used to glean relevant History for their subject matters. The includes recalling major events, figures, artifacts, and deciphering hieroglyphs. | Difficulty | DC | Example | | ----------------- | --- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Mundane | 0 | Recalling an event/creature that happened/existed in the past 20 years. | | Requires Focus | 10 | Recalling an event/creature that happened/existed in the past 20-99 years. | | Trained | 20 | Identifying how a ritual took place in an ancient ruin, and how you might activate these mechanismsUnderstanding the roundabout significance of murals and other arts | | Difficult | 30 | Recalling an event/creature that happened 100+ years ago | | Very Difficult | 40 | Understanding the roundabout significance of heiroglyphs/ancient language | | Masterwork | 50 | Creating full translations of hieroglyphs.Recalling an event/person that happened/existed 1000+ years ago | | Nearly Impossible | 60 | | | Ascended | 70 | Receiving ancestral memories, or briefly gazing into the past to see an event |

entries.title: Knowledge
entries.content: INT-based Skill. You cannot roll Knowledge if you are not Trained. Knowledge is broken up into many different skills based on subject, and each one has a subsection dedicated to Monster Lore of specific types of creatures. Monster Lore isn’t its own skill, it is instead an action that uses the individual Knowledge skills. If a subject or creature falls into multiple categories, then players can choose whichever they like more, but an individual character can't roll multiple checks with different skills - instead, they receive a +2 bonus for each overlapping Knowledge they possess. If you want to know who an individual creature is and their relevance to the world, rather than their stats and abilities, the DC is usually dependent on how popular they are. This is typically 30-LV with additional reductions to the DC if they are famous or in a position of power, or increases in the DC if they work to keep their identity and exploits hidden. All Knowledge Skills can be used to recall the History of the associated subject as well, such as using Humanities to learn about ancient Elf-Human relations that shaped the current world.

entries.title: Monster Lore
entries.content: Adventurers are assumed to know basic things about monsters, like how a Construct's lack of anatomy grants them resistance to many effects, or the properties of Incorporeal creatures. Monster Lore checks are for figuring out more information about specific monster types, or if a creature is hiding its typing. Monster stat blocks are broken up into sections. Basic stats (Saves, HP and AC), offense traits (breath weapons, dangerous auras, prominent spells), defense traits (healing abilities, elemental Resistances), other traits (extra senses, extra movement options, out of combat abilities) and weaknesses/deep lore (lich's phylactery, vampires not appearing in mirrors). Rolling a Monster Lore check is something you can do as a Free Action once per turn. It is assumed that you also vocalize what you learn to your team. The base DC of a Monster Lore check is (10+creature's LV). By succeeding on a Monster Lore check, you can figure out a creature's basic stats and one other category for your choice. For every 5 over the DC you roll, you figure out another category. If a creature has nothing in a category, you choose another. Creatures with the [unique] tag in their entry increase their Monster Lore DC by 5. Humanoids with class levels by default are assumed to have the [unique] tag, unless their class comes with clearly distinguishable features (such as a Dark Knight's Evil Eye), or they are part of an organization with similar training and abilities (such as a Monk dojo or city guards). | Knowledge Skill | Creature Type Identified | | ---------------- | --------------------------------------- | | Arcana | Monster | | Alchemy | Ooze | | Astronomy | Abomination | | Humanities | Humanoid, Titan | | Engineering | Construct | | Nature | Plant, Fey, Beast | | Planes | Fiend, Celestial, Elemental | | Religion | Undead |

entries.title: Encode or Decode Documents
entries.content: Using Linguistics, you can write things in ways that are difficult to interpret without a cipher, such as disguising your forbidden ritual as a cookbook. The DC to your code is 10+(Linguistics bonus). Creatures that know the code can read encoded text, but creatures that don't will interpret the text as something else. To read encoded text, you must first crack the code, usually requiring at least a week of research. At the end of the week, roll a Linguistics check versus the writer’s DC to crack the code.

entries.title: Interpret Text
entries.content: Using Linguistics, you peruse a book, contract, or other written work to quickly summarize what it says in one minute. The DC for most works is 10, but it changes based on the size and complexity of the work at hand. Failure indicates more time is necessary to understand what the text contains. Finding oddities in a contract requires an opposed Linguistics check.

entries.title: Language
entries.content: Most creatures that can speak will know Common. Some isolated or xenophobic creatures may only speak their native tongue. | Common Languages | | | ---------------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Common | The default tongue - most intelligent creatures can speak this language with some level of proficiency. Conveniently, it's the same language the players speak at the table. | | Fiendish | The language of Fiends. As a language created by creatures that seek only destruction, the language includes guttural sounds and subtle hums as a means of intimidation, and to better convey double meanings and secret messages. | | Celestial | The language of Celestials. Originally used for holy invocations, oaths, and singing - making its native speakers easy to spot from how melodic their speech is. | | Sylvan | The language of Fey. When nature speaks, this is the language it uses. | | Primordial | The language of elementals and ancient common. | | Cultural and RacialLanguages | | | ------------------------------------ | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Dwarvish | | | Elvish | | | Vargish | The language of the brutal and savage, primarily Orcs, Goblins, and wild Half-Links. | | Manganese | | | Giantspeak | Spoken by Giants and Titans, similar to Common, but better suited for their vocals. | | Uncommon Languages | | | ---------------------- | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Sign Language | Common, but in the form of gestures and hand signs. Useful for not making noise, or communicating with the deaf. Other languages can also be learned in Sign Language, and should be noted for the distinction. | | Morse Code | A binary language that can turn any on/off state into characters of a language, whether it be through clicking or a smoke signal. | | Necril | The language of the afterlife, limbo, and the dead. | | Secret Languages | | | -------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Bronze | A unique language that can only be understood by the exceptionally unintelligent. To others, it sounds like nonsense Common. Any Humanoid with -1 INT can understand this language. | | Druidic | An alternative version of Sylvan druidic circles use that can be displayed in otherwise innocuous objects or markings in nature. Used to mark territory, hide secrets in plain sight, and perform rituals subtly. | | Thieve's Cant | A coded version of Common that thieves use to converse about malicious topics without alarming others around them. |

entries.title: Linguistics
entries.content: INT-based Skill. Proficiency in Linguistics grants an additional known Language-Dependent per level. Used for Interpret Text, Write or Forge Documents, and Encode or Decode Documents.

entries.title: Write or Forge Documents
entries.content: Using Linguistics, you can make contracts, forge signatures, and make fake (or real) documents look official. Noticing oddities in such documents requires an opposed Linguistics check.

entries.title: Assess Vitality
entries.content: Using Medicine, you can examine a creature that is wounded to determine how they were injured, how long ago it happened, and whether they are in grave danger of dying. This also functions on corpses for cause of death. The more complex the ailment and the longer the duration since it happened, the higher the DC. Difficulty based on duration may reverse in scaling in the case of diseases, where more time passing makes the symptoms more obvious.

entries.title: Identify Affliction or Curse
entries.content: Use Trained Medicine to examine a creature for one minute. You can identify whether they have an Affliction or Curse, the effects of such, and how to cure them. The DC is 5 times the Affliction level, or the DC of the Curse.

entries.title: Long Term Care
entries.content: Use Trained Medicine to assist yourself or another creature such that they can recover a stack of Drained every 3 days instead of 7. This care is required for some Afflictions.

entries.title: Medicine
entries.content: WIS or INT-based Skill. Used for Assess Vitality, Provide First Aid, Long Term Care, Prevent Recovery, and Identify Affliction or Curse.

entries.title: Prevent Recovery
entries.content: Use Trained Medicine for one minute to prevent a Defeated creature from being able to recover on their own. This lasts 24 hours.

entries.title: Provide First Aid
entries.content: Use Trained Medicine as a Standard Action to cure a creature in reach of Status ailments. You can remove Sickened stacks, Bleed, and Blurred Vision. The DC of removing any of these conditions is the DC of the ability that inflicted them.

entries.title: Detect
entries.content: As a Standard Action, you become more observant of your surroundings, gaining an additional Perception check to detect traps, creatures, or details that are hidden from view. When a creature is not doing anything with its Standard Action and is moving at a normal pace, it is assumed to be using Detect Hidden Presence every round.

entries.title: Perception
entries.content: WIS-based Skill. All creatures are Proficient in Perception, unless they are Mindless or specify otherwise. Used for Detect. Used as a defense against skills like Hands and Stealth.

entries.title: Perform
entries.content: CHA-based Skill. Proficiency in Perform only applies to specific instruments or Performance types. The bonus for having this skill only applies to the chosen types. Examples of Performances include instruments like flutes, pianos, or drums, physical displays such as singing and dancing, and displays of charm such as comedy. Used for Performance and Economics.

entries.title: Performance
entries.content: Attempt to put on a show for other creatures using Perform. Whether it's music, action, or stand-up, benefits will be extended to entertaining individuals. Performances are an important part of every culture. They are a commonly desired luxury, and some Afflictions require Performance as a cure.

entries.title: Coax
entries.content: When an NPC is on the fence or indifferent about a request, and the requester doesn't have anything left to say to sway them, Persuasion can be used to get the target to agree or counter-offer. The DC varies based on how effective the conversation was before rolling. Requests that align with the target's interests, offerings that make them happy, and moral arguments that resonate with their values will lower the DC, while the opposite will increase it. Passing the check results in the NPC requesting something in return, while rolling significantly higher may cause them to waive any additional requests, or even offer additional assistance that wasn't requested. This action can also be used when the NPC already agreed due to good conversation in-character, in order to try to sweeten the deal if the requester rolls exceptionally well.

entries.title: Example DCs
entries.content: | Difficulty | DC | Examples | | ----------------- | --- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | Mundane | 0 | Simple tasks like helping prepare dinner, or gathering information on a topic people are concerned with | | Requires Focus | 10 | Assistance with time-consuming tasks | | Trained | 20 | Gathering information that people don't pay attention to, such as if a mundane person walked by | | Difficult | 30 | Gathering dangerous information that could get snitches in trouble | | Masterwork | 40 | Revealing secrets, such as hideouts, passwords, or scandals | | Nearly Impossible | 50 | Convince people to do something against their ethos, but that could be conceivable in dire circumstances | | Ascended | 60 | Convince people to do the unthinkable against all odds given adequate circumstances, such as killing beloved family members or marching to their death against an unstoppable force to buy time | Common modifiers to make the task more difficult can include racism, your questions/requests being offensive or closely guarded secrets by the target, and not being well-liked by the person/people you are persuading. Common modifiers to make the task less difficult can include being well-liked by the person/people you are persuading, holding a position of authority over them, or it would benefit the person you're speaking to to reveal the information you're looking for.

entries.title: Gather Information
entries.content: When in a settlement, you can use Persuasion to find the answer to a simple question by speaking to people in town. The time it takes and the difficulty scales with the size of the settlement, people's general attitude toward you, and how knowledgeable they are on the subject. Asking about where someone lives in a village could take minutes, but asking in a large city could take hours.

entries.title: Persuasion
entries.content: CHA-based Skill. Used for Coax and Gather Information.

entries.title: Cooking
entries.content: Cooking is a Craft Profession that uses two or more Ingredients to make Food. Having a cook to make use of monster parts during a dungeon dive can be the difference between surviving and thriving. The ingredients used must be of different categories. By default, anyone can cook two or three ingredients together to make Food with a DC 10 check. Each additional ingredient beyond the third adds +10 to the DC. Beating the DC by 10 adds a basic perk, up to 3. Anyone with the skill will automatically add one perk. The basic perks are as follows - Cooking requires Tools, as well as water and a source of heat.

entries.title: Profession
entries.content: WIS or INT-based Skill. Trained individuals can use any ability score for Economy uses if doing so has a justification in-character. Professions can be anything used to provide a service or create a product. When you gain a profession, you choose one such specialization, such as Profession (Cooking). Used for Economics and Quiz.

entries.title: Quiz
entries.content: Use Profession to answer basic questions about a type of craft or service job. Most simple facts are DC 10, but anything higher is Trained-only. Proficient creatures automatically know most simple facts about their Profession.

entries.title: Hide Trail
entries.content: Use Trained Stealth to hide your trail, turning attempts to Track you into an opposed check of their Survival vs your Stealth -5.

entries.title: Hide
entries.content: As a Swift Action, Use Stealth to prevent enemies from knowing your exact location. This lasts until you are spotted. Whenever an enemy has line of sight to you, or you cause some other detectable stimuli, they roll Perception against your Stealth. If you Attack a creature, it gets a +20 bonus on its check. A Ranged Attack grants a +10 bonus. While moving at half speed or slower and not having taken an action, you get an additional Roll to avoid detection. You can only take this action while you have Cover or Concealment.

entries.title: Stealth
entries.content: DEX-based Skill. Used for Hide and Hide Trail.

entries.title: Butcher
entries.content: Spend a minute to use Survival to skin, drain, dress, and otherwise harvest the organic components from a recently killed creature. Obtaining organic loot from creatures is an important part of the game. Creatures that have listed drops when butchered will always give these items without a check if there is not a listed DC. Any organic materials that reasonably spoil will do so if not used in a timely manner (varies based off the part, but no less than 3 days). Using Survival to get additional resources beyond what is listed in a creature's entry grants materials worth an amount equal to the creature's LV^2 times 10. This has a DC of 10+creature's LV. At the DM's discretion, the harvest can be worth more or less or made easier or harder depending on the rarity of the creature and demand for its products.

entries.title: Forage
entries.content: Creatures Proficient in Survival can spend an hour in a wilderness area with suitable sources of food and water to create a Field Ration. Alternatively, this can be used to search for specific Ingredients that are native to the area. In areas that are unsuitable for life, such as deserts, a skill check is needed to succeed at this action. Failure indicates that the time is wasted.

entries.title: Navigate
entries.content: When moving through unfamiliar territory, Survival can be used to get a sense of direction and move towards an intended destination. Higher rolls include avoiding unwanted encounters, while lower rolls represent less progress made towards the destination, or reaching the incorrect destination.

entries.title: Survival
entries.content: WIS-based Skill. Used for Navigate, Butcher, Forage, and Track.

entries.title: Track
entries.content: Use Survival to follow the path another creature took by looking for footprints, disturbed leaves, markings, etc. The older the tracks, the higher the DC to track them. With ideal conditions, you can follow trails made days or weeks ago.

entries.title: Group Checks
entries.content: When working cooperatively, such as to Craft an item or work a machine, use the group's highest bonus, plus 1 per helper, or 2 if they're also Proficient (max +10). When the weakest link can sink a team's effort, such as with Stealth, use the group's lowest bonus, plus the help.

entries.title: Proficiency
entries.content: Proficiency in a Skill marks you as "Trained" rather than "Untrained." Proficiency grants more uses for some skills.

entries.title: Skill
entries.content: Skill Rolls are how players interact with the world without hitting it with their sword. Even if certain actions have a skill associated with them, you don't necessarily need to roll a skill check (no need to roll Deception if they already believe you, no need to roll Athletics in still water, etc.) When one is required, it is prompted by the DM. If the DC to a task is more than 30 points higher than the bonus on the roll, then the DM should deem it impossible in cases where "fishing" for a success with no repercussions is the intent. The special roll allows rolling any number, so if a task is well out of a character's reach such that the DC difference is that high, it may be better to not allow the roll to preserve the narrative. This roll can be very swingy, creating dramatically unexpected results. As such, using a skill roll as a barrier for entry can create all or nothing scenarios. There's nothing wrong with saying "the lock is too complex for you to pick," but you can't be upset when immediately after the martials of the party start smashing into the door. There should be lesser versions of success. If you barely fail the DC to scale a wall, it lowers your speed instead of falling. If you barely fail a Stealth check while trailing someone, they can tell someone is in the bushes, but not who. Many things should not be represented by a skill or ability roll. For example, do not roll to see if someone can lift a portcullis - This is already represented by their Carrying Capacity. You should also carefully consider what a roll represents, and whether rerolls are appropriate. When rolls are made, don't be surprised when the party's expert sometimes gets outdone by the party's pet chicken. A skill check should be summarized with a "you can or you can't" when rolling may cause inconsistencies. Skill bonuses are increased by one relevant Ability Score modifier. You add 2x the bonus to your skill check if you are Proficient. Proficiency in a skill grants you a 2+LV bonus to the skill. Certain aspects of a skill might only be available to characters that are proficient in the skill. Standard skill DCs are what should be used in the absence of a set or opposed DC. Remember that every 10 point difference makes the task twice as hard. They are as follows… | Difficulty | DC | | ----------------- | --- | | Mundane | 0 | | Requires Focus | 10 | | Trained | 20 | | Difficult | 30 | | Masterwork | 40 | | Nearly Impossible | 50 | | Ascended | 60 | Some skills are opposed to other skills, while other skills will include examples comparable this chart.

entries.title: Take 10
entries.content: You can take 10 on non-opposed skill checks. This means instead of rolling, you automatically get a Natural 10. This is suitable for crafting or skipping tasks that aren't too difficult for you.

entries.title: Take 30
entries.content: When not under duress, you can spend ten times the time the task normally takes to achieve your best effort, automatically getting a Natural 30. It is assumed you trigger the failure result ten times, making this unsuitable for crafting or disarming traps.

entries.title: Tie
entries.content: When making an opposed Skill check, ties are rerolled.

entries.title: Bestial
entries.content: Bestial Techniques are collections of abilities that are intended to be used with Natural Weapons. Most are restricted to certain types of attacks, such as claws or tail sweeps. Beasts and Natural Weapon-wielding creatures from the Bestiary will often have access to these as Innate Techniques.

entries.title: Hyper Body
entries.content: Fighter Innate Technique Standard Action, Limited Buff and Passive | Effect | | | ----------- | ------------------------- | | Range | 600 | | Target/Area | Self | | Save | - | | Duration | Until Rest or Your Defeat | You get a +4 bonus to Fortitude. Your HP increases by 6+4/LV. As a Standard Action, grant 3+CHA allies an additional 4/LV HP. This is based on their level. This bonus ends when they Long Rest, or you are Defeated.

As a Standard Action, you can touch a creature to transfer a stack of Drained from them to yourself. A creature can only be affected by this once each week.

On an enemy, this functions as Dispel. For cursed items, this allows the safe removal of the item, but requires a CL check.

This ability cannot restore creatures above 50% HP, but any excess becomes Temp HP. This can be done through a Staff.

You can Mana Burn 1 to hug an ally as a Standard Action, putting them in Stasis for one round, and removing any Fear effects.

entries.title: Mystic Door

As long as you are within 10 miles of the place you slept, you can conjure a Mystic Door that links to the Mystic Doorstep for one minute. It is the same size as the entry you marked. It takes one minute to cast. Any creature can take the portal back simply by walking through it, but it is one-way. Once the Mystic Door disappears, so does your Mystic Doorstep. This effect does not require line of sight.

entries.title: Fury
entries.content: Innate Technique Immediate Action, Recharge | Effect | | | ----------- | --------- | | Range | - | | Target/Area | Self | | Save | - | | Duration | One Round | Move 5ft and Resist physical damage for one round.

entries.title: Dark Sight

Lasts five turns, or until you Attack, cast a Spell, or otherwise take an offensive action. Creatures that are not using Detect do not get additional checks to spot you.

entries.title: Haste
entries.content: Rogue Innate Technique Standard Action, At-Will Passive | Effect | | | ----------- | ------------ | | Range | Reach | | Target/Area | Ally Touched | | Save | - | | Duration | - | Grant a touched ally +10 Speed and Jump for 10 minutes. Up to 3+CHA allies can benefit at the same time. You gain this benefit passively.

entries.title: Cleave
entries.content: Weapon Innate Technique Action-Attack, Recharge Compatible with these Weapon Groups: Axe Blade Bludgeon Polearm Weapon must deal Slash or Crush Damage. | Effect | | | ----------- | ---------------------- | | Range | Reach | | Target/Area | Two Adjacent Creatures | | Save | - | | Duration | - | Make a melee Attack against the target with your weapon, and one additional attack against another target adjacent to it. This extra attack does not need to be in your reach.

entries.title: Great Cleave
entries.content: Weapon Innate Technique Action-Attack, Recharge Compatible with these Weapon Groups: Axe Blade Bludgeon Polearm Weapon must deal Slash or Crush Damage. | Effect | | | ----------- | -------------------- | | Range | Reach | | Target/Area | All Adjacent Enemies | | Save | - | | Duration | - | Make a melee Attack against all adjacent enemies.

entries.title: Skewer
entries.content: Weapon Innate Technique Action-Attack, Recharge Compatible with these Weapon Groups: Blade Bow Thrown Thrust Trigger Weapon must deal Pierce Damage. | Effect | | | ----------- | ----------------------------------- | | Range | Weapon | | Target/Area | One target, and targets behind them | | Save | - | | Duration | - | Make an attack against a target. If you hit, target an additional adjacent target that is on the opposite side of them. Continue making attacks until you miss or deal no damage, or there are no more adjacent targets in a line. If using a melee weapon, the additional targets do not need to be in reach.

entries.title: Class and Weapon Abilities
entries.content: Class and Weapon abilities are not true Techniques, as they lack tiers (and thus do not scale with Upcast), and cannot be learned with Technique Points. They are very similar in function, however. They are almost always Innate Techniques gained through your Class, Feats, Magic Items, and wielding Weapons that have them. Special Attacks also fall into this category. They are written separately for cataloguing and reference purposes. Weapon abilities often list compatibility, but these compatibilities are not immutable. Particularly powerful weapons may have seemingly incompatible abilities, to represent their unique position.
entries.path: Techniques/Class and Weapon Abilities/Class and Weapon Abilities.md

entries.title: Blood Bath
entries.content: Tier 1 Blood Art Technique Standard Action, At-Will Supernatural | Effect | | | ----------- | ---------------------- | | Range | 15 | | Target/Area | Self and All Creatures | | Save | - | | Duration | - | Cut yourself with a Slash Weapon, inflicting d6 Bleed. Whenever you take this damage, nearby creatures begin to Bleed for the same amount. Upcast 2 - +d6 Damage.

entries.title: Blood Rush
entries.content: Tier 1 Blood Art Spell Standard Action, At-Will Healing Transmutation | Effect | | | ----------- | ------------ | | Range | 30 | | Target/Area | One Creature | | Save | Fortitude | | Duration | - | Target must save or suffer SP Bleed. entries.content: Technique Tree. Savagery embodies the raw, untamed essence of primal fury, and visceral instincts. Those who follow this path tap into a wellspring of unrelenting strength and ferocity, transforming their bodies into instruments of destruction. With each blow, they become forceful avatars of chaos, rending flesh and shattering earth beneath their feet. Their rage fuels an indomitable resilience, allowing them to shrug off pain as they rampage through the battlefield, leaving piles of corpses and the ruins of civilization in their wake as they advance with their bodies painted in the blood of their foes.

entries.title: Warfare
entries.content: Technique Tree. In a realm where conflict is an inevitable aspect of existence, Warfare represents the mastery of strategic combat techniques developed throughout a long history of war. This tree is designed for those who understand that warfare is not only about brute strength but also about cunning planning, decisive leadership, and the ability to adapt in the face of adversity. Whether leading a small skirmish or marching through a sea of fire, practitioners of this skill tree will become adept at turning the chaos of the battlefield into a calculated display of tactical prowess.

entries.title: Alarming Sigil
entries.content: Tier 1 Academy Spell Standard Action, Recharge Sigil Divination | Effect | | | ----------- | ---------- | | Range | Reach | | Target/Area | 20 Radius | | Save | - | | Duration | Until Rest | You inscribe a magic rune on the surface of an object. Whenever a creature of at least tiny or larger Size enters this area, the sigil triggers, creating one of two effects you decide upon casting. In either case, you are mentally alerted and awakened if Asleep. Silent Alarm - Only you are mentally alerted. Loud Alarm - A loud sound plays. Creatures within 300 ft can hear it in ideal conditions. This spell only functions while you are inside its radius.

The willing target gently falls 60 ft per round until they land safely on the ground, taking no fall damage. The spell ends when they touch the ground, or after one minute. Upcast 1 - Target an additional creature.

The target cannot use movement while it's benefiting from this spell.

entries.content: Tier 1 Academy Spell Standard Action, Limited Transmutation | Effect | | | ----------- | ---------------------- | | Range | Reach | | Target/Area | One Object or Creature | | Save | - | | Duration | Until Rest | The target object or willing creature's weight is reduced by 100 or by half, whichever is less. Upcast 1 - The weight can be reduced by an additional 50.

entries.content: Tier 1 Academy Spell Action-Attack, Limited Conjuration | Effect | | | ----------- | ---------- | | Range | Reach | | Target/Area | - | | Save | - | | Duration | Until Rest | You create a magical piece of basic weaponry, such as a dagger or mace, or a basic shield. It deals Magic damage in addition to its original type.

entries.title: Magic Guard
entries.content: Tier 1 Academy Spell Instant Action, At-Will Abnegation | Effect | | | ----------- | ---- | | Range | - | | Target/Area | Self | | Save | - | | Duration | - | You redirect a portion of incoming damage to your Mana. When you cast this spell, you reduce an incoming instance of damage by (SP+ CL). This consumes one of your Mana Slots. You may sacrifice other prepared abilities to fuel this spell, or this ability (though if you sacrifice this one, you can't use it again until you prepare it again).

entries.title: Scholar's Hand
entries.content: Tier 1 Academy Spell Standard Action, At-Will Concentration, M (Focus): Writing Utensil, Parchment, Paper Conjuration | Effect | | | ----------- | -------------- | | Range | 30 | | Target/Area | Object or Book | | Save | - | | Duration | Concentration | This spell has two uses, the first of which does not require the focus component. You create a translucent hand that can pick up items and perform simple tasks, such as opening doors, pulling up pants, or tipping over buckets. It can carry up to 10 lbs and has a +0 bonus to Athletics. The hand can continue to act independent of you as long as you concentrate. The hand can also write as you do, and can be used to write in or copy a book used as a focus, at a rate of about one page per minute.

entries.title: Detect Magic
entries.content: Tier 2 Academy Spell Standard Action, At-Will Concentration Divination | Effect | | | ----------- | ----- | | Range | 30 Ft | | Target/Area | Cone | | Save | - | | Duration | - | While concentrating on the spell, you are detect the presence of magic in the area. This includes Spell effects, Supernatural effects, and magic items. At first, you are only aware of the presence or absence of magic. After something remains in the cone for one full round, you can tell where it is located, and details such as how many magic effects are on a creature you can see. You can tell distinguished effects apart from the general noise of magical presence. This means that new magic that enters the area will be distinguishable from what you have already detected in the area. New magic must still be in the area for a full round to detect its precise location.

entries.title: Dimensional Anchor
entries.content: Tier 2 Academy Spell Action-Attack, Recharge Abnegation | Effect | | | ----------- | ------------ | | Range | 60 | | Target/Area | One Creature | | Save | - | | Duration | 1 Minute | You fire a tangled web of green energy as a ranged attack, causing the creature struck to become Dimensionally Anchored.

entries.title: Dispel
entries.content: Tier 2 Academy Spell Action-Attack, Recharge Abnegation | Effect | | | ----------- | --------------------- | | Range | 60 | | Target/Area | One Creature or Spell | | Save | - | | Duration | - | This spell can be used in two ways. Dispel - You Roll opposed CL to immediately end a magical effect. You must be aware of which effect you are specifically trying to dispel, as blind attempts at dispelling will fail. If you try dispelling magic you know is there but aren't aware of the properties, effects, or purpose of the spell, you take a -5 penalty. Counter Spell - You Roll opposed CL to prevent a spell from being cast. This must be done as a Prepared Action in response to a spell being cast. If the spell the creature is casting has a higher CL than your Dispel, they get a +5 bonus. You can use Dispel on supernatural features, labeled (Su). The creature's CL is treated as (LV+2). Passive supernatural effects or constant innate spells can be reactivated as a Swift Action.

entries.title: Academy
entries.content: Spell Technique Tree. In the heart of every large city, the scholars and the wealthy gather around places of magical research to stay relevant in a competitive and difficult world of magic. These places focus on imparting general knowledge of best practices and methodologies to their students, a basis from which they can further the research and development in their field of magic. Those who choose to immerse themselves in the Academy skill tree embark on a journey of rigorous study and practical mastery, gaining a profound understanding of the skills and self-defense techniques needed to take on the occult world beyond the city walls.

entries.title: Charming Gaze
entries.content: Tier 1 Enthrallment Spell Standard Action, At-Will Subtle, Mind-Affecting Illusion | Effect | | | ----------- | ------------------- | | Range | 30 | | Target/Area | One Creature | | Save | Will | | Duration | 1 Minute or 8 Hours | You lock your eyes onto a target and Charm them (Will negates). If you're currently engaged in combat with the creature, the spell's duration is 1 minute. If you are not, the spell's duration is 8 hours. Entering combat against them shortens the remaining duration to 1 minute.

entries.title: Command
entries.content: Tier 2 Enthrallment Spell Action-Attack, Recharge Mind-Affecting, Language-Dependent Illusion | Effect | | | ----------- | ------------ | | Range | 30 | | Target/Area | One Creature | | Save | Will | | Duration | 1 Round | You give the subject a single command, which it obeys to the best of its ability at its earliest opportunity (Will negates). You may select from the following options. Approach - On its turn, the subject moves directly towards you 30 ft and Provokes. It cannot use its movement beyond this. Drop It - On its turn, the subject drops whatever it is holding. It can’t pick up any dropped item on the same turn it drops it. Kneel - The subject is Knocked Down. It may act normally, but takes any appropriate penalties. It may not stand up early. Begone - On its turn, the subject moves 30 ft directly away from you and Provokes. It cannot use its movement beyond this. Praise Me - The subject babbles on about your greatness, effectively leaving them Silenced for 1 round. If the subject can’t carry out your command on its next turn, it defaults to Kneel.

entries.title: Darting Duplicate

It can go around corners if you know where to turn to not hit terrain or creatures. It cannot replicate any actions besides moving and smiling. Creatures that are threatening you when you cast this spell must make an AoO on the duplicate (Will negates). If the duplicate enters a creature's space or impassable terrain, any creature that witnesses it instantly disbelieves it. A creature that identifies your spell when you cast it instantly disbelieves it.

For every sentence you speak, you can cause them to hear a different sentence. This allows you to speak to two different people at the same time and tell them two different things.

entries.title: Unnatural Lust
entries.content: Tier 1 Enthrallment Spell Standard Action, Recharge Mind-Affecting, Subtle Illusion | Effect | | | ----------- | --------------------------------------- | | Range | 30 | | Target/Area | 2 Creatures Within 30 ft of One Another | | Save | Will | | Duration | 1 Round | When you cast the spell, you choose two targets. The initial target is filled with lust. The second target doesn't get affected by anything, but rather determines where this lust is directed towards. The initial target must spend the entirety of its next turn moving towards the secondary target and then caressing, hugging, or kissing them (Will negates). A creature gets a +4 to its save if it would not normally be sexually attracted to the secondary target. By succeeding on a Monster Lore check against a creature, you can determine what an appropriate secondary target for this spell would be. After failing its save and satisfying its carnal desires, a creature becomes more resistant to the spell and always receives the +4 bonus on subsequent casts against it for one minute.
